ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
CITY OF TOLLESON, ARIZONA 
ORDINANCE NO. 482, N.S. 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF TOLLESON, MARICOPA COUNTY, ARIZONA, ADOPTING THE REVISED CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF TOLLESON, ARIZONA; PROVIDING FOR PENALTIES; PROVIDING FOR SEVERABILITY; REPEALING CONFLICTING ORDINANCES; AND ESTABLISHING AN EFFECTIVE DATE. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF TOLLESON, MARICOPA COUNTY, ARIZONA, AS FOLLOWS: 
    SECTION 1: That certain document entitled the "Revised Code of Ordinances of the City of Tolleson, Arizona", three copies of which are on file in the office of the City Clerk, which document was made a public record by Resolution No. 1036 of the City of Tolleson, Arizona, is hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this Ordinance. 
    SECTION 2: Penalties. Any person found guilty of violating any provisions of this Ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed $2,500 or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months or by both the fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues shall be a separate offense punishable as hereinabove described. 
    SECTION 3: Severability. If any section, subsection, or clause of this Ordinance shall be deemed to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, the validity of the remaining sections, subsections and clauses shall not be affected. 
    SECTION 4: Repeal of conflicting ordinances. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this Ordinance are hereby repealed. 
    SECTION 5: Effective date. That the provisions of this Ordinance shall be effective from and after 12:00 midnight on the 15th day of May, 2009. 
    PASSED by the Council of the City of Tolleson this 14th day of April, 2009. 
    APPROVED by the Mayor this 14 day of April, 2009. 
/s/   
      Adolfo F. Gámez, Mayor   APPROVED AS TO FORM: 
/s/   
      Scott W. Ruby, City Attorney   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      Chris Hagen, City Clerk   
CHAPTER 1: - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE 1-1: - RULES OF CONSTRUCTION; GENERAL PENALTY 

§ 1-1-1 - HOW CODE DESIGNATED AND CITED. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters, articles and sections shall constitute and be designated the Revised Code of the City of Tolleson, Arizona , and may be so cited. The code may also be cited as the Tolleson City Code, Revised . 
§ 1-1-2 - CONSTRUCTION OF ORDINANCES. 
    The rules and the definitions set forth in this article shall be observed in the construction of this code and the ordinances of the city unless the construction would be inconsistent with either the manifest intent of the Council, the context of this code or the ordinances of the city. 
§ 1-1-3 - DEFINITIONS. 
(A)  General rule regarding definitions. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved use of the language. Technical words and phrases and such others, as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood according to the peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(B)  Specific definitions. 
    ACTS BY AGENTS. When an act is required to be done which may, by law, as well be done by an agent as by the principal, the requirements shall be construed to include all acts when done by an authorized agent. 
    CITY. The City of Tolleson, Arizona. 
    CODE. The Revised Code of the City of Tolleson , unless the context indicates otherwise. 
    COUNCIL. The Council of the City of Tolleson. 
    COUNCIL MEMBER. A member of the Council of the City of Tolleson, other than the Mayor. 
    COUNTY. Maricopa County, Arizona, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
    DAY. The period of time between any midnight and the midnight following. 
    DAYTIME, NIGHTTIME. DAYTIME is the period of time between sunrise and sunset. NIGHTTIME is the period of time between sunset and sunrise. 
    DEPARTMENT, BOARD, COMMISSION, OFFICE, OFFICER or EMPLOYEE. Whenever any department, board, commission, office, officer or employee is referred to, it shall mean a department, board, commission, office, officer or employee of the city unless the context requires otherwise. 
    GENDER; SINGULAR AND PLURAL. Words of the masculine gender include the feminine; words in the singular include the plural and words in the plural include the singular. 
    JOINT AUTHORITY. All words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more city officers or other persons shall be construed as giving the authority to a majority of the officers or other persons unless it shall be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority. 
    KEEPER or PROPRIETOR. Includes persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through an agent, servant or employee. 
    MANAGER or CITY MANAGER. The Manager of the City of Tolleson, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    MAYOR. The Mayor of the City of Tolleson, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    MEMBER OF COUNCIL. A member of the Council of the City of Tolleson, including the Mayor. 
    MONTH. A calendar month. 
    OATH. An affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. In those cases the words SWEAR and SWORN shall be equivalent to the words AFFIRM and AFFIRMED. 
    OWNER. A building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of part of the building or land. 
    PERSON. Includes a corporation, company, partnership, association or society, as well as a natural person. 
    PERSONAL PROPERTY. Every species of property, except real property, as defined in this section. 
    PRECEDING, FOLLOWING. Next before and next after, respectively. 
    PROPERTY. Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments and personal property. 
    PUBLIC PLACE. Any thoroughfare, park, open space or building not privately owned or controlled. 
    REAL PROPERTY. Lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    SHALL, MAY. SHALL is mandatory and MAY is permissive. 
    SHALL HAVE BEEN. Includes past and future tenses. 
    SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION BY MARK. Includes a mark when the signer or subscriber cannot write, the signer's or subscriber's name being written near the mark by a witness who writes his or her own name near the signer's or subscriber's name; but a SIGNATURE or SUBSCRIPTION BY MARK can be acknowledged or can serve as a signature or subscription to a sworn statement only when two witnesses so sign their own names thereto. 
    STATE. The State of Arizona, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
    STREET. Any lane, court, boulevard, public way, public square, public place or thoroughfare. 
    TENANT or OCCUPANT. Applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or an oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or part of, the building or land, either alone or with others. 
    TENSES. The present tense includes the past and future tenses and the future includes the present. 
    TIME; COMPUTATION. The time within which an act is to be done, as provided in this code or in any order issued pursuant to any ordinance, when expressed in days, shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, except that if the last day is a Saturday, Sunday or holiday it shall be excluded. When the time is expressed in hours, the whole of Saturday, Sunday or a holiday, from midnight to midnight, shall be excluded. 
    TIME, REASONABLE. In all cases where any section of this code shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, shall be deemed to mean the time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of the duty or compliance with the notice. 
    WEEK. A week consists of seven consecutive days. 
    WRITING. Any form of recorded message capable of comprehension by ordinary visual means. Whenever any notice, report, statement or record is required or authorized by this code, it shall be made, in writing, in the English language, unless expressly provided otherwise. 
    YEAR. A calendar year, unless otherwise provided. 
§ 1-1-4 - REFERENCE TO CHAPTERS, ARTICLES OR SECTIONS; CONFLICTING PROVISIONS. 
(A)  Additional rules of construction. In addition to the rules of construction specified in §§ 1-1-2 and 1-1-3, the rules set forth in this article shall be observed in the construction of this code. 
(B)  References to this code. All references to chapters, articles or sections are to the chapters, articles and sections of this code unless otherwise specified. 
(C)  Conflicting provisions. 
(1)  If the provisions of different chapters of this code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter that is most stringent shall prevail as to all matters and questions growing out of the subject matter of the chapter. 
(2)  If conflicting provisions are found in different sections of the same chapter, the provisions of the section that is most stringent shall prevail unless the construction is inconsistent with the meaning of the chapter. 
§ 1-1-5 - SECTION HEADINGS. 
    Headings of the several sections of this code are intended as a convenience to indicate the contents of the section and do not constitute part of the law. 
§ 1-1-6 - EFFECT OF REPEAL. 
    When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, the repeal shall not be construed to revive the former ordinance, clause or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for any offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
§ 1-1-7 - SEVERABILITY OF PARTS OF CODE. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this code shall be severable and, if any provision of this code is held unconstitutional for any reason by a court of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of the code. 
§ 1-1-8 - PENALTY. 
(A)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in this code, any person found guilty of violating any provisions of this code shall be guilty of a class one misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished pursuant to the terms set forth in the A.R.S. § 13-707, § 13-802, and § 13-902, as amended. Each day that a violation continues shall be a separate offense punishable as hereinabove described. 
(B)  The penalties provided in this article shall be applicable to every provision of this city code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate provision. 
(C)  Any violation of or failure or refusal to do or perform any act required by Chapter 6 of this code constitutes a civil traffic violation. Civil traffic violations are subject to the provisions of A.R.S. Title 28, Chapter 5, Articles 3 and 4, and amendments thereto. Hearings and appeals shall be conducted in accordance with the Arizona Rules of Procedure in Civil Traffic Cases. 
(Ord. 567, N.S., passed 11-22-2016) 
§ 1-1-9 - REPEAL OF EXISTING ORDINANCES. 
(A)  Effective date of repeal. All ordinances of the City of Tolleson, except those specially exempted in this article, now in force and effect are hereby repealed effective at 12:00 noon on May 15, 2009, but all rights, duties and obligations created by the ordinances shall continue and exist in all respects as if this code had not been adopted and enacted. 
(B)  Ordinances exempt from repeal. The adoption and enactment of this code shall not be construed to repeal or, in any way, to affect or modify: 
(1)  Any special ordinance or ordinances regarding franchises, annexations, dedications, zoning, subdivisions or cable television; 
(2)  Any ordinance making an appropriation; 
(3)  Any ordinance affecting any bond issue or by which any bond issue may have been authorized; 
(4)  The running of the statute of limitations in force at the time this code becomes effective; 
(5)  The continued existence and operation of any department, agency, commission or office heretofore legally established or held; 
(6)  Any bond of any public officer; 
(7)  Any taxes, fees, assessments or other charges incurred or imposed; and 
(8)  Any ordinances authorizing, ratifying, confirming, approving or accepting any compact or contract with any other municipality, the State of Arizona, any county or subdivision thereof or with the United States or any agency or instrumentality thereof. 
§ 1-1-10 - EFFECTIVE DATE OF CODE. 
    Each section of this code as herein contained and hereby enacted shall take effect and be in force on and after 12:00 midnight on May 15, 2009, except that where a later effective date is provided it shall prevail. 
CHAPTER 2: - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE 2-1: - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 
COUNCIL 

§ 2-1-1 - ELECTED OFFICERS; TERMS. 
(A)  The elected officers of the city shall be the Mayor and six Council members. The Mayor and Council members shall constitute the City Council and shall hold its office for terms of four years each and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. 
(B)  For purposes of elections, the City Council shall be divided into two classes. The first class shall consist of the Mayor and three Council members. The second class shall consist of the other three Council members. The Mayor and Council members shall be elected by the classes at alternating regular elections and shall serve four-year overlapping terms. For the purpose of facilitating the change in election dates pursuant to § 2-1-40 and § 2-1-42 of this chapter, the term of office for the Mayor and the Council members holding office on the tenth Tuesday before the first Monday in November of 2014, whose term would have expired in June of 2015 shall be extended until their successors are elected and qualified in December of 2016 and the term of office for the Council members holding office on the tenth Tuesday before the first Monday in November of 2016, whose term would have expired in June of 2017, shall be extended until their successors are elected and qualified in December of 2018. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-271 and 9-272 
§ 2-1-2 - CORPORATE POWERS. 
    The corporate powers of the city shall be vested in the Council and shall be exercised only as directed or authorized by law. All powers of the Council shall be exercised by ordinance, resolution, order or motion. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-232 
§ 2-1-3 - DUTIES OF OFFICE. 
    The Mayor and Council members shall assume the duties of office at the first regularly scheduled meeting date in December following the date of the general election at which the Mayor or Council members were elected. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-231 and 9-232 
§ 2-1-4 - VACANCIES IN COUNCIL. 
(A)  The Council shall fill a vacancy in the Council that may occur for whatever reason, by appointment until the next regularly scheduled Council election if the vacancy occurs more than 30 days before the nomination petition deadline, otherwise the appointment is for the unexpired term. 
(B)  The member appointed shall meet the qualifications set forth in § 2-1-46 below. 
(Am. Ord. 521, N.S. , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-235 
§ 2-1-5 - COMPENSATION. 
    The compensation of elective officers of the city shall be fixed from time to time by ordinance or resolution of the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-232.01 and 9-274 
§ 2-1-6 - OATH OF OFFICE. 
    Immediately prior to assumption of the duties of office, each member of the Council shall, in public, take and subscribe to the oath of office. 
§ 2-1-7 - BOND. 
(A)  Prior to taking office, every member of the Council shall execute and file an official bond, enforceable against the principal and their sureties, conditioned on the due and faithful performance of his or her official duties, payable to the state and to and for the use and benefit of the city or any person who may be injured or aggrieved by the wrongful act or default of the officer in his or her official capacity. 
(B)  A person so injured or aggrieved may bring suit on the bond under provisions identical to those contained under state law. Bonds shall be in the sum as shall be provided by resolution and the premium for the bonds shall be paid by the city. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-302 
MAYOR AND VICE MAYOR 

§ 2-1-20 - ELECTION OF MAYOR. 
    The Mayor shall be directly elected by the qualified electors of the city. The mayoral election shall be held in accordance with the provisions of § 2-1-40 and § 2-1-42 of this article. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-272.01 
§ 2-1-21 - SELECTION OF VICE MAYOR. 
(A)  The Council shall, at the first regularly scheduled meeting in December, after its election, choose the Vice Mayor from among its number. 
(B)  The Vice Mayor shall be elected by majority vote of the Council members present at the election meeting. In the event that no candidate receives a majority vote, the two candidates receiving the highest number of votes shall run in a runoff election until the time as one candidate receives a majority. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-236 
§ 2-1-22 - TEMPORARY CHAIRPERSON. 
    In the absence or disability of both the Mayor and Vice Mayor, the Council may designate, by motion, another of its members to serve as temporary chairperson who shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities of the Mayor during the absence or disability. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-236 
§ 2-1-23 - POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE MAYOR. 
    The powers and duties of the Mayor shall include the following. 
(A)  The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city. 
(B)  The Mayor shall be the Chairperson of the Council and preside over its meetings. The Mayor may make and second motions and shall have a voice and vote in all its proceedings. 
(C)  The Mayor shall enforce the provisions of this code. 
(D)  The Mayor shall execute and authenticate, by the Mayor's signature, the instruments as the Council, or any statutes, ordinances or this code shall require. 
(E)  The Mayor shall make recommendations and suggestions to the Council as the Mayor may consider proper. 
(F)  The Mayor may exercise all powers set forth in § 4-4-4 of this code in instances of emergencies. 
(G)  The Mayor shall perform other duties required by state statute and this code as well as those duties required as chief executive officer of the city. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-236 
§ 2-1-24 - ABSENCE OF MAYOR. 
    The Mayor shall not be absent from the city for a greater period than 15 consecutive days without the consent of the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-236 
§ 2-1-25 - FAILURE TO SIGN DOCUMENTS. 
    If the Mayor refuses or fails to sign any ordinance, resolution, contract, warrant, demand or other document or instrument requiring the Mayor's signature for five days consecutively, then a majority of the Council members may, at any regular or special meeting, by motion authorize the Vice Mayor, or in the absence of the Vice Mayor, a temporary chairperson to sign the ordinance, resolution, contract, warrant, demand or other document or instrument which when so signed shall have the same force and effect as if signed by the Mayor. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-236 
COUNCIL ELECTION 

§ 2-1-40 - PRIMARY ELECTION. 
(A)  Commencing in 2014, primary elections shall be held on the tenth Tuesday before the first Monday in November of even-numbered years or on the date as otherwise prescribed by state law. 
(B)  Any candidate for the Council who shall receive at the primary election a majority of all the votes cast shall be declared to be elected to the office for which the person is a candidate effective as of the date of the general election, and no further election shall be held as to said candidate. 
(C)  In calculating the votes cast in the primary election where the office of Mayor is up for election, for purposes of determining if a candidate for the office of Mayor or Council has received a majority of the votes cast, the basis shall be the number of votes cast for the office of Mayor at that election. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-821.01 
§ 2-1-41 - NON-POLITICAL BALLOT. 
    Nothing on the ballot in any election shall be indicative of the source of the candidacy or of the support of the candidate by political parties or any group, organization or individual. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-821.01 
§ 2-1-42 - GENERAL ELECTION. 
(A)  Commencing in 2014, general elections of the city shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of even-numbered years or on the date as otherwise prescribed by state law. 
(B)  If, at any primary election held as above provided, there be any office or offices for which no candidate is elected, then as to the office or offices, the election shall be considered to be a primary election for nomination of candidates for the office or offices, and the general municipal election shall be held to vote for candidates to fill the office or offices. Candidates to be placed on the ballot at the general municipal election shall be those not elected at the primary election, shall be equal in number to twice the number to be elected to any given office or less than that number if there be less than that number named on the primary election ballot. Persons who receive the highest number of votes for the respective offices at the primary election shall be the only candidates at the general election, provided that, if there be any person who, under the provisions of this subsection, would have been entitled to become a candidate for any office except for the fact that some other candidate received an equal number of votes therefor, then all persons receiving an equal number of votes shall likewise become candidates for such office. 
( Am. Ord. 534, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 16-201 and 16-203 
§ 2-1-43 - ELECTION TO OFFICE. 
(A)  The candidates equal in number to the persons to be elected who receive the highest number of votes shall be declared elected. 
(B)  The Clerk, immediately upon the confirmation of election, shall issue certificates of election to each elected member of the Council. The certificates shall be in a form as approved by the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-821 and 16-647 
§ 2-1-44 - RECOUNT. 
(A)  In the event the vote spread between two candidates for one Council seat is less than ten votes, in either the primary or general election, an automatic recount of the votes shall be required. 
(B)  The procedure to be followed for the recount shall be pursuant to the provisions in A.R.S. Title 16, Chapter 4, Article 12, and amendments thereto. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 16-661 
§ 2-1-45 - FILING DEADLINE FOR NOMINATION PAPERS. 
(A)  A person desiring to become a candidate and to have his or her name printed on the official ballot for City Council shall file a nomination paper and other nomination materials not less than 90 days nor more than 120 days before the primary election date. 
(B)  All nomination papers must be completed and filed with the City Clerk by 5:00 p.m. on the last day for filing the papers. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 16-311 
§ 2-1-46 - ELIGIBILITY FOR OFFICE. 
    A person shall not be a member of the City Council unless, at the time of election, the person is 18 years old or older, is a qualified elector residing within the city at the time of election, and has resided in the city for one year next preceding the election, or if an area has been annexed to the city for a period of less than one year next preceding the election has resided in the area for one year next preceding the election. If an annexed area is subject to the provisions of this section, a person may meet the residency requirements if the person has resided within the existing limits of the city for a one-year period. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-232 
COUNCIL PROCEDURE 

§ 2-1-60 - REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS. 
(A)  Regular meetings. The Council shall hold regular meetings on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month at 6:00 p.m. When the day fixed for any regular meeting of the Council falls upon a day designated by law as a legal holiday, the meeting shall be held at the same hour on the next succeeding day not a holiday. All regular meetings of the Council shall be held in the City Hall of Tolleson. 
(B)  Special meetings. The Mayor, or the City Manager, upon the written/verbal request of three Council members, may convene the Council at any time by notifying the members of the date, hour and purpose of the special meeting. 
(Am. Ord. 352, N.S., passed 5-28-1996; Am. Ord. 570, N.S. , passed 3-14-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-233 
§ 2-1-61 - MEETINGS TO BE PUBLIC. 
    All proceedings of the Council shall be open to the public, except that, upon approval by a majority vote of the Council, the Council may meet in a closed executive session in the manner provided by state statute. No ordinance, order, rule, resolution, regulation, contract, appointment or other official action shall be finally approved in any executive session. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-234, 38-431.01 and 38-431.03 
§ 2-1-62 - QUORUM. 
    A majority of the Council shall constitute a quorum for transacting business, but a lesser number may adjourn from time to time and compel the attendance of absent members. No adjournment shall be to a day beyond the next stated meeting of the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-233 
§ 2-1-63 - AGENDA. 
    Prior to each Council meeting the City Clerk shall collect all written reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contracts and other documents to be submitted to the Council, and prepare an agenda according to the order of business and shall furnish a copy to each member of Council and the City Attorney at least 24 hours prior to any regular meeting. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
§ 2-1-64 - CONSENT AGENDA. 
(A)  When any item of business requires action by the Council, but is of a routine and non-controversial nature, the item may be presented at a regular meeting of the Council as part of a consent agenda. 
(B)  The consent agenda shall be introduced by a motion "To approve the Consent Agenda" and shall be considered by the Council as a single item. 
(C)  There shall be no debate or discussion by any member of the Council regarding any item on the consent agenda, beyond asking questions for simple clarification. 
(D)  All items on the consent agenda which require public hearings shall be open for hearing simultaneously, and the Mayor shall announce, or direct the City Clerk to announce, the titles of all items. 
(E)  Upon objection by any member of the Council to inclusion of any item on the consent agenda, that item shall be removed from the consent agenda forthwith. The objections may be recorded at any time prior to the taking of a vote on the motion to approve the consent agenda. All items shall be considered individually, in the order in which they were objected to, immediately following consideration of the consent agenda. 
(F)  Approval of the motion to approve the consent agenda shall be fully equivalent to approval, adoption or enactment of each motion, resolution, ordinance or other item of business thereon, exactly as if each had been acted upon individually. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
§ 2-1-65 - ORDER OF BUSINESS. 
    The business of the Council at its regular meeting shall be taken up for consideration and disposition in the following order. 
(A)  Call to order. The Mayor shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed for the meeting and shall immediately call the Council to order. In the absence of the Mayor, the Vice Mayor shall call the Council to order. In the absence of both the Mayor and Vice Mayor, the Manager shall call the Council to order and a temporary chairperson shall be selected to chair the meeting. Upon the arrival of the Mayor or the Vice Mayor, the Vice Mayor or the temporary chairperson shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately before the Council. The Mayor shall preserve order and decorum and decide all questions of order. 
(B)  Roll call. Before proceeding with the business of the Council, the Clerk or the Clerk's deputy shall enter in the minutes the names of those members of the Council present and those absent. If a quorum is not present, the members present may adjourn pursuant to § 2-1-62 of this code. 
(C)  Pledge of allegiance. At every regular Council meeting, the Mayor or chairperson of the meeting shall request someone on the Council or in the audience to lead the pledge of allegiance to the flag. 
(D)  Invocation/moment of silence. If desired, the Mayor or chairperson of the meeting shall request someone on the Council or in the audience to lead the invocation/moment of silence. 
(E)  Open call to the public. 
(1)  Persons wishing to address the Council on items not already on the agenda may do so, although each speaker is limited to no more than three minutes. The Mayor or Council may limit the total time offered speakers. At the conclusion of the open call to the public, individual members of the Council may only: 
(a)  Respond to criticism made by those who addressed the Council; 
(b)  Ask staff to review a matter; or 
(c)  Ask that a matter be placed on a future agenda. 
(2)  The Council is not permitted under state law to discuss or take legal action on matters raised during an open call to the public unless the matters were properly noticed for discussion and legal action. 
(F)  Consent agenda. The Council shall consider any items on the consent agenda in accordance with § 2-1-64 above. 
(1)  Minutes. Unless a reading of the minutes of a Council meeting is requested by a member of the Council, the minutes of the preceding meeting shall be considered approved, if correct, and errors rectified if any exist. At each meeting, the Mayor shall ask for any corrections, additions or changes in the minutes of the previous meeting. 
(2)  Claims. Each month the Clerk shall prepare a list of all claims paid by the city. The list shall be reviewed and approved when required by the Council and a copy of it shall be included in the minutes. 
(G)  Executive sessions. Any member of the Council may request an executive session pursuant to the authority of the Arizona Revised Statutes. If a majority of the members of the Council vote to have an executive session, the Mayor shall clear the Council chambers, appoint one of the remaining staff or Council members to take minutes of the meeting and proceed with the executive session. 
(H)  Adjournment. The Council may, by a majority vote of those present, adjourn from time to time to a specific date and hour. A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-234, 38-431.01 and 38-431.03 
§ 2-1-66 - EXECUTIVE SESSIONS. 
(A)  Executive sessions may be placed on an agenda under the same circumstances as any other agenda item, however approval of the City Attorney of all executive sessions shall be required to assure compliance with the open meeting law. Executive sessions may only be placed on the agenda if the issue is allowed to be considered in an executive session pursuant to state law. 
(B)  Under normal circumstances, executive sessions will be attended by the Mayor and Council, City Manager, City Clerk and City Attorney. The Mayor may direct, or a majority of the Council may vote, to have other individuals attend the executive session. 
(C)  Executive sessions are not to be tape recorded, but an individual appointed by the Mayor shall take written minutes of executive sessions to document the nature and extent of the discussions. All minutes of executive sessions shall be sealed and retained by the City Clerk. Only those individuals who were present at a particular executive session or others specifically permitted by law may review the minutes of that session. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 38-431.03 
§ 2-1-67 - PUBLIC HEARING PROCEDURE. 
(A)  A public hearing may be placed on the agenda under the same agenda item as the discussion and action of the Council. 
(B)  The normal procedure for public hearings shall be as set forth hereafter. 
(1)  Calling agenda item: The agenda item shall be called by the Mayor or his or her designee as any other agenda item. 
(2)  Declaration of public hearing: The Mayor shall declare that the Council is now in public hearing. 
(3)  Proponent presentation: The proponent may make an opening statement in order to explain the item to the Council and public. The Mayor or Council may limit the time for this statement as necessary. 
(4)  Staff report: Staff shall have an opportunity to report on the issue and answer questions by the Council. 
(5)  Written comments: Written communications filed with the city or staff shall be presented to the Council or read into the record. 
(6)  Public comments: Testimony from members of the public shall be permitted. Members of the public shall be limited to three minutes per person, or less as designated by the Mayor or Council. The total time allotted to the public on any issue may be limited by the Mayor or Council. 
(7)  Council discussion: Discussion by Council members may be held at this time of public hearing. 
(8)  Declaration of end of public hearing: Unless a majority of the Council members object, the Mayor shall declare the termination of the public hearing. 
(9)  Council discussion and vote: The agenda item will then be discussed and action taken as on any other agenda item. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
§ 2-1-68 - CONFLICT OF INTEREST. 
    Each member of Council has a responsibility for compliance with state law concerning conflicts of interest. Any member of the Council who believes he or she has a conflict of interest shall, immediately upon determining that a conflict exists, declare the conflict of interest and explain the basis for the conflict. That member of Council may then leave the room and shall refrain from taking any part in the meeting, discussion, consideration or determination of that issue. If that issue is not resolved at that meeting, that Council member shall not discuss the matter with any other Council member until the matter is finally resolved. The member who declared the conflict may return to his or her seat when that agenda item is completed. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 38-501 et seq. 
§ 2-1-69 - DISCUSSION AND VOTING PROCEDURE. 
(A)  Every Council member desiring to speak shall address the Mayor and, upon recognition by the Mayor, shall confine himself or herself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(B)  A Council member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him or her to order. If a Council member, while speaking, is called to order, he or she shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined and, if in order, he or she shall be permitted to proceed. 
(C)  While the Council is in session, the members of Council must preserve order and decorum. A member shall neither by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the Council nor disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the Council or Mayor, except as otherwise herein provided. 
(D)  In the event a person in the audience wishes to address the Council on an issue on the agenda which is not a public hearing, the Mayor may permit the person to speak or may present the request to the Council. If a majority of the Council wishes to hear from the public on the issue, that person shall be permitted to speak, however any public address shall be limited to three minutes per person and as otherwise restricted by the Mayor or Council. Written communications which were delivered to the Mayor prior to the agenda item being called will be read into the record or a copy shall be delivered to each Council member. 
(E)  Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks, or who becomes boisterous while addressing the Council, or who interferes with the order of business before the Council, and who fails upon request of the Mayor to cease the activity, shall be barred from further audience before the Council for the remainder of that meeting unless permission to continue is granted by a majority vote of the Council. 
(F)  A motion shall be made by beginning the statement with words such as, "I move that...." A motion must be stated clearly, and specifically state the contents of the motion. There can be no discussion after a motion is made until there is a second or the motion dies for lack of a second. If there is not a second, the Mayor shall announce that the motion failed for lack of a second, and the discussion may continue, or the Council may move on to the next agenda item. 
(G)  At any time before the question is called on a pending motion, the member of Council who made the motion may ask that his or her motion be amended. At the time of the amendment, he or she shall clearly state the amendment, and the amendment shall be read back by the Clerk. If the member of Council who seconded the vote agrees, then the motion shall be considered amended voluntarily. 
(H)  At any time before the question is called on a pending motion, a member of Council may make a motion to amend the motion. At that time, the discussion of the underlying issue will stop. If there is not a second to the motion to amend, then discussion on the underlying issue will continue. If there is a second to the motion to amend, then all discussion will be confined to the motion to amend, and there shall be a vote on the motion to amend. If the motion to amend is adopted by a majority of the Council, discussion will continue on the (now) amended motion. If the motion to amend fails, discussion will continue on the original motion on the floor. 
(I)  At any time before the question is called on a pending motion, the member of Council who made the motion may ask that his or her motion be withdrawn. The motion will be withdrawn only in the event that the member of Council who seconded the motion agrees with withdrawal of the motion. 
(J)  Discussion shall end at the time the question is called, or at the time the Mayor determines that there is no further discussion desired by any Council member. The Mayor shall direct the Clerk to read the motion, and the Clerk shall read the motion as made or amended. The only persons who can object to the form of the motion at this time are the members of Council who made and seconded the motion. If there is a conflict as to whether the motion as read is the motion as intended, the matter will revert to further discussion until the discrepancy is corrected. 
(K)  The Mayor shall ask Council members to designate their individual votes by announcing "aye" or "nay." If, prior to the vote or after the vote, any member of Council requests a roll call vote, the Mayor or his or designee shall call roll and each member of Council shall state his or her vote aloud. 
(L)  After the vote, the Mayor or his or her designee shall announce whether the motion failed or passed. If the vote was unanimous the Mayor or his or designee shall so state and, if it was not, the Mayor or his or designee shall state the individual votes for the record, stating the number of "aye" and "nay" votes. If any member of Council disagrees with the vote as read back by the Mayor or his or designee, he or she shall immediately request a clarification or roll call vote. After the Mayor or his or designee reads back the individual votes, silence by any member of Council indicates his or her agreement with the vote as read. 
(M)  A motion passes if it receives more "aye" votes than the combined number of "nay" votes, plus the number of members of Council abstaining from voting on the motion, regardless of the reason for the abstention. In the case of a tie in votes on any motion, the motion shall be considered lost. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
§ 2-1-70 - MOTIONS TO RECONSIDER. 
(A)  Reconsideration of any action taken (or not taken) by the City Council may be requested only by a member of Council who was on the prevailing side of the vote. A member of Council may request that the issue of reconsideration be placed on the agenda for discussion and possible action, although this request must be made prior to the start of the next regular Council meeting following the meeting at which the action was taken. If a request is made, reconsideration will be placed on the agenda for the second regular Council meeting following the meeting at which the original action was taken. The agenda will list reconsideration of the vote as one item, and the re-vote on the issue as a separate item. 
(B)  When that agenda item is called, the Council may discuss the reconsideration, however a motion to reconsider may only be made by one of the members of Council who was on the prevailing side of the vote. A motion may be seconded by any member of Council. The discussion and vote of the motion to reconsider shall be as for any other business before the Council. 
(C)  If the motion to reconsider fails, the Council will skip the next agenda item, which will be the discussion and vote of the original issue. If the motion to reconsider was successful, the Council will discuss and vote on the original issue as for any other business before the Council and any member of Council may make motions on the original issue. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
§ 2-1-71 - COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS. 
    The Council may create committees and commissions, standing or special, as it deems necessary. They shall consist of as many members and shall perform duties as the Council may require and shall exist at the pleasure of the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-239 
§ 2-1-72 - SUSPENSION OF RULES. 
    Any of the provisions of this article may be temporarily suspended in connection with any matter under consideration by a recorded vote of three-fourths of the members present, except that this section shall not be construed to permit any action that is contrary to state statutes. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-234 
ARTICLE 2-2: - CITY ORGANIZATIONS 
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION 

§ 2-2-1 - CREATION. 
    There is hereby established as an advisory body to the Council a Planning and Zoning Commission to be governed by the procedures and duties as provided in this subarticle. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.01 
§ 2-2-2 - MEMBERSHIP. 
(A)  The Commission shall be composed of a total of five members who shall be residents of the city. The members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Council. In the event of death or resignation of a member, the vacancy may be filled by the Mayor and Council for the unexpired term. The term of all members shall extend until their successors are qualified. 
(B)  All members shall serve without pay, except that members of the Commission may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their duties upon authorization or ratification by the Commission and approval of expenditures by the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.0 
§ 2-2-3 - OFFICERS. 
    The Commission shall elect the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its own members, who shall serve for one year and until their successors are elected and qualified. The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings and exercise all the usual rights, duties and prerogatives of the head of any similar organization. The Vice Chairperson shall perform the duties of the Chairperson in the latter's absence or disability. Vacancies created by any cause shall be filled by the Commission for the unexpired term by a new election. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.02 
§ 2-2-4 - DUTIES. 
(A)  It is the duty of the Commission to formulate, create and administer any lawful plan duly adopted by the governing body for the present and future growth of the city pertaining to the use of land and buildings for any purpose, together with all incidental activities usually associated therewith and commonly known as "planning and zoning;" to make or cause to be made a continuous study of the best present and future use to which land and buildings shall be put within the city and in cooperation with adjacent areas; to recommend to the governing body revisions in the plans which, in the opinion of the Commission, are for the best interest of the citizens of the city; to promulgate rules of procedure and to supervise the enforcement of rules so promulgated by the Commission and approved by the governing body. 
(B)  The Commission shall: 
(1)  Develop and maintain a general plan; 
(2)  Develop specific plans as may be necessary to implement the general plan; 
(3)  Periodically review the capital improvement program of the city; and 
(4)  Perform other planning functions as the Council may provide from time to time. 
(C)  The Commission may: 
(1)  Contract for, receive and utilize any grants or other financial assistance made available by a municipality, a county, the state or the federal government, subject to the approval of the Council; and 
(2)  Contract with the state or federal government, and any of its agencies, or the legislative body of any municipality or county subject to the approval of the Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.02 
§ 2-2-5 - HEARINGS AND MEETINGS. 
(A)  The Commission shall hold a public hearing on any proposed zoning ordinance may conduct hearings and meetings with interested property owners and residents of the city and others in other matters in carrying out its duties. 
(B)  The Commission shall provide in its rules for its meetings; provided that, special meetings may be called by the Chairperson or, in his or her absence, the Vice Chairperson. In addition, any three members of the Commission may make written request to the Chairperson for a special meeting and in the event the meeting is not called, the members may call a special meeting in a manner and form as may be provided in the Commission rules. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.02 
§ 2-2-6 - CONDUCT OF BUSINESS. 
(A)  Three members shall constitute a quorum. 
(B)  The affirmative vote of two members shall be required for passage of any matter before the Commission. 
(C)  A member may abstain from voting only upon a declaration that he or she has a conflict of interest, in which case the member shall take no part in the deliberations on the matter in question. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.02 
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT 

§ 2-2-20 - CREATION. 
    There is hereby established a Board of Adjustment for the city. The Board of Adjustment is a quasi-judicial body of the city established to hear and grant, if warranted, relief from certain provisions of the city zoning code, as specifically set forth herein, and within the limits herein established. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.06 
§ 2-2-21 - MEMBERSHIP. 
    The City Council is established as the City of Tolleson's Board of Adjustment. The Council shall convene as the Board of Adjustment whenever it is necessary to fulfill the responsibilities of the Board of Adjustment. All meetings shall be open to the public and if the Board meeting is conducted as part of a Council meeting, the agenda shall clearly indicate that the Council is acting as the Board of Adjustment on that agenda item. The Mayor or, in the Mayor's absence, the Vice Mayor shall act as the Board's Chairperson and shall have the power to administer oaths and take evidence. Minutes of the Board's proceedings showing the vote of each member and records of its examinations and other official actions shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk as a public record. 
Cross reference- For provisions concerning the Board of Adjustment, see § 12-4-167(B) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.06 
§ 2-2-22 - QUORUM AND VOTING. 
    When acting as the Board of Adjustment, the Council shall follow all rules, regulations and procedures that it follows as the City Council. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.06 
§ 2-2-23 - DUTIES. 
(A)  The Board of Adjustment shall: 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals in which it is alleged there is an error in an order, requirement or decision made by the City Zoning Administrator in the enforcement of a zoning ordinance adopted by the city; 
(2)  Hear and decide appeals for variances from the terms of a zoning ordinance only if, because of special circumstances applicable to the property, including its size, shape, topography, location or surroundings, the strict application of the zoning ordinance will deprive the property of privileges enjoyed by other property of the same classification in the same zoning district. Any variance granted is subject to the conditions as will assure that the adjustment authorized shall not constitute a grant of special privileges inconsistent with the limitations upon other properties in the vicinity and zone in which the property is located; and 
(3)  Reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the order, requirement or decision of the Zoning Administrator appealed from, and make an order, requirement, decision or determination as necessary. 
(B)  The Board of Adjustment may not: 
(1)  Make any changes in the uses permitted in any zoning classification or zoning district, or make any changes in the terms of the zoning ordinance; provided, the restriction in this division shall not affect the authority to grant variances pursuant to this subarticle; and 
(2)  Grant a variance if the special circumstances applicable to the property are self-imposed by the property owner. 
(3)  Impose stipulations and/or special conditions in granting the variance appeal. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-461.06 
COMMUNITY SERVICES ADVISORY BOARD 

§ 2-2-30 - NAME. 
    There is hereby established the Community Services Advisory Board as an advisory body to the Council. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
§ 2-2-31 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this Board is to guide the city's Community Services Department's activities in Tolleson and surrounding areas, and to serve as an advisory board to the City Council for the purpose of identifying social service needs of the community and finding resources to meet these needs through collaboration with community groups, agencies, cities and organizations. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
§ 2-2-32 - MEMBERSHIP AND COMPOSITION. 
(A)  Number of members. The Board shall be composed of seven members and one alternate. Members shall be residents of the City of Tolleson at the time of appointment. Consideration will be given to include representatives of the public and private sector in order to provide for broad community participation, and due consideration shall be given to a diverse membership on the Board. 
(B)  Appointment. Board members may be nominated by the Mayor or any Council member and shall be appointed by the City Council. 
(C)  Term. The term of office for an appointed Board member shall be three years, unless the Board member resigns sooner or is removed. For initial appointments, staggered terms of two and three years shall be designated. 
(D)  Term limits. No member of the Board may serve more than two consecutive terms. However, a member appointed to fill a vacancy may serve two consecutive terms after conclusion of the unexpired term to which he or she was appointed. 
(E)  Attendance. A Board member who has three consecutive unexcused absences is subject to removal from the Board by the City Council. Any Board member proposed to be removed shall be entitled to at least seven days notice in writing from the City Clerk. 
(F)  Removal. Board members serve at the pleasure of the City Council and any Board member may be removed upon a vote of not less than four Council members for any reason. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
§ 2-2-33 - POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BOARD. 
(A)  Ad hoc committees. The Board may appoint ad hoc committees as necessary to accomplish the Board's mission. 
(B)  Assist Department staff. The Board shall, as requested by the Department Supervisor, assist the Department's staff in initiating, prioritizing, coordinating and facilitating planning and implementation of Division programs. 
(C)  Funding. The Board shall, when requested by the City Council, seek additional funds and in-kind contributions, either public or private, for the purpose of furthering the programs of the Department. 
(D)  Authority. The Board shall not have authority to direct the Department's staff. The Board may make recommendations to the Department Supervisor and the City Council concerning staff and operations. 
(E)  Project review. The Board shall review and evaluate existing or proposed projects, policies and plans and shall review Department program evaluations, audits and other relevant studies, and make recommendations to the City Council regarding the projects, policies and plans. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
§ 2-2-34 - MEETINGS. 
(A)  Frequency. Meetings of the Board shall be scheduled quarterly, at a minimum of four times per year. Notice of meetings of the Board shall be provided to the public and its meetings shall be open to the public in compliance with the requirements of the open meeting law. A record of Board proceedings shall be filed with the City Clerk's office as a public record. 
(B)  Quorum. A meeting of the Board where a majority of its members are present shall constitute a quorum. A majority vote of those Board members present and voting shall be required to take official action. No action shall be taken at any meeting in the absence of a quorum. 
(C)  Rules of procedure. The Board will operate under the City of Tolleson Council Rules of Procedure, as applicable. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
§ 2-2-35 - BOARD OFFICERS. 
(A)  Chair and Vice Chair. The Board shall annually select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from the appointed members at the first regularly scheduled meeting of the new fiscal year. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson shall assume responsibilities at the next scheduled meeting. The term of Chairperson and Vice Chairperson shall be one year. Any member serving as Chairperson or Vice Chairperson shall be eligible for additional terms as Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. 
(B)  Duties. The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings and hearings of the Board, decide all points of order and procedure, and perform any duties as required by law, ordinance or these rules. The Chairperson shall have the right to vote on all matters before the Board and shall have the right to make or second motions in the absence of a motion or a second. 
(C)  Absence of Chairperson. The Vice Chairperson shall act as the Chairperson in the Chairperson's absence. In the absence of the Chairperson and the Vice Chairperson, the senior member, based upon years of membership, shall act as Chairperson. 
(D)  Vacancy. Any vacancy for Chairperson or Vice Chairperson, as may occur for any reason, shall be filled from the Board membership by majority vote of the Board at the next meeting where a quorum is present. Such appointment shall be for the remainder of the term. 
(E)  Removal. The Chairperson or Vice Chairperson may be removed from office at any time by a majority vote of the members of the Board. 
( Ord. 496, N.S. , passed 9-14-2010) 
ARTICLE 2-3: - CITY OFFICERS[1]

OFFICERS IN GENERAL 

§ 2-3-1 - OFFICERS. 
    There are hereby created the offices of Chief Magistrate, City Attorney, City Clerk, City Engineer, City Manager, Assistant City Manager, Chief Financial Officer, Community Services Director, Economic Development Director, Field Operations Director, Fire Chief, Human Resources Director, Information Technology Director, Library Director, Police Chief and Utilities Director. The Chief Magistrate, the City Attorney and the City Manager shall be appointed by the Council and, with the exception of the Chief Magistrate, shall serve at the pleasure of the Council. The City Clerk, City Engineer, Assistant City Manager, Chief Financial Officer, Community Services Director, Economic Development Director, Field Operations Director, Fire Chief, Human Resources Director, Information Technology Director, Library Director, Police Chief and Utilities Director shall be appointed by the City Manager as provided in this article. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-271, 9-303 and 22-403 
§ 2-3-2 - ADDITIONAL OFFICERS. 
    The City Manager may appoint and remove, from time to time, other officers as the City Manager may deem necessary and that are not provided for in this code or state statute. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239 and 9-271 
§ 2-3-3 - BOND. 
(A)  The City Manager may require any officer of the city to give bond for the due discharge of his or her duties in sums and with security as the City Manager may direct and approve. The city shall pay the costs of the bond. The provided bond may be provided by the city's insurer. 
(B)  At the discretion of the City Manager, the bond may be in the form of a blanket bond with the coverage as deemed necessary. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-239 
§ 2-3-4 - VACANCIES; HOLDING MORE THAN ONE OFFICE. 
(A)  Any vacancy that shall occur in any city office appointed by the Council shall be filled by appointment by the Council. Any vacancy that shall occur in any city office appointed by the City Manager shall be filled by appointment by the City Manager. 
(B)  One person may hold more than one office at the discretion of the Council. 
(C)  The functions of a city official may be validly performed and discharged by a deputy or another city official, or an otherwise qualified individual not holding office, but employed at the pleasure of the Council. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-271, 9-303 and 9-274 
§ 2-3-5 - ADDITIONAL POWERS AND DUTIES. 
    In addition to any powers and duties prescribed in this code, each officer shall have further powers, perform further duties and hold other office as may be provided by the City Manager or Council through ordinance, resolution or order and as may be required by law. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-231 and 9-274 
OFFICERS 

§ 2-3-20 - CHIEF MAGISTRATE. 
(A)  Office created. The office of the Chief Magistrate of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The Chief Magistrate shall be appointed by the Council to serve a term of two years. 
(B)  Compensation. The Chief Magistrate shall receive compensation as the Council shall fix from time to time by ordinance, resolution, motion or contract and the compensation shall not be decreased during the Chief Magistrate's term of office. 
(C)  Removal procedure. Unless otherwise provided in an employment agreement, the Council may suspend or remove the Chief Magistrate if the Chief Magistrate: 
(1)  Pleads guilty or no contest or is found guilty of a crime punishable as a felony under any law of this state or a federal law, or of any other crime that involves moral turpitude under the law; 
(2)  Has a disability that seriously interferes with the performance of the Chief Magistrate's duties and is, or is likely to become, permanent; or 
(3)  Engages in actions that constitute willful misconduct in office, willful and persistent failure to perform the Chief Magistrate's duties, habitual intemperance or conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice that brings the judiciary and judicial office into disrepute. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Chief Magistrate shall include: 
(1)  The powers and duties set forth and conferred upon the Chief Magistrate under the provisions of the state constitution and statutes, this code and the ordinances and resolutions of the city. 
(2)  The keeping of a docket in which shall be entered each action and the proceedings of the Court therein. 
(3)  The responsibility for fixing and receiving all bonds and bails and receiving all fines, penalties, fees and other monies as provided by law. 
(4)  Payment of all fees, fines, penalties and other monies collected by the Court to the Treasurer. 
(5)  Submitting a quarterly report to the Council summarizing Court activities for that quarter. 
(6)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the Council, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-274 and 22-403 
§ 2-3-21 - CITY ATTORNEY. 
(A)  Office created. The office of the City Attorney of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The City Attorney shall be appointed by the Council wholly on the basis of professional experience, ability and qualifications and shall hold office for and at the pleasure of the Council. 
(B)  Compensation. The City Attorney shall receive compensation as the Council shall fix from time to time by ordinance, resolution or motion. 
(C)  Removal procedure. Unless otherwise provided in an employment agreement, the City Attorney may be removed with or without cause by a majority vote of the Council. If requested, the Council shall grant the City Attorney a public hearing within 30 days following notice of removal. During the interim, the Council may suspend the City Attorney from duty but shall continue his or her salary. If the removal becomes final, the Council may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the City Attorney shall include: 
(1)  Acting as the legal counselor and advisor of the Council and other city officials, and as such, giving his or her opinion in writing when requested. 
(2)  Drafting all deeds, contracts, conveyances, ordinances, resolutions and other legal instruments when required by the Council. 
(3)  Approving as to form, in writing, all drafts of contracts and all official or other bonds before final approval or acceptance thereof by the Council. 
(4)  Returning, within ten days, all ordinances and resolutions submitted to him or her for consideration by the Council, with his or her approval or disapproval as to form noted thereon, together with his or her reasons therefor. 
(5)  Prosecuting and defending, or designating an attorney to prosecute and defend, all suits, actions or causes where the city is a party and reporting to the Council, when required, the condition of any suit or action to which the city is a party. 
(6)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the Council, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239 and 9-274 
§ 2-3-22 - CITY CLERK. 
(A)  Office created. The office of the City Clerk of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The City Clerk shall be appointed by the City Manager wholly on the basis of professional experience, ability and qualifications. 
(B)  Compensation. The City Clerk shall receive compensation as the City Manager shall fix from time to time. 
(C)  Removal procedure. The City Clerk may be removed with cause by the City Manager subject to city personnel policies. The City Manager may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the City Clerk shall include: 
(1)  Keeping a true and correct record of all the business transacted by the Council and a permanent record of the Council's proceedings. 
(2)  Providing notice of all Council meetings. 
(3)  Authenticating by his or her signature and maintaining, as permanent records of the city, all ordinances and resolutions passed by the Council. 
(4)  Compiling and maintaining the City of Tolleson Code. 
(5)  Keeping convenient for public inspection all public records and public documents under the City Clerk's control, as provided by state statute. 
(6)  Countersigning all contracts approved by the Council and executed by the Mayor, numbering and registering the same, and maintaining them in accordance with state records retention laws. 
(7)  Preparing or causing to be prepared all minutes of Council proceedings and ensure their correctness and accuracy. 
(8)  Serving as the elections official for the city and conducting all municipal elections to ensure conformity with the City Code, city ordinances, Arizona Revised Statutes, and the Voter's Rights Act. 
(9)  Administering the city's records management program to ensure consistency and compliance with state law, and to protect and preserve the permanent records of the city. 
(10)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014; Am. Ord. 565, N.S. , passed 8-23-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-274 and 9-302

(A)  Office created. The office of the City Engineer of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The City Engineer shall be appointed by the City Manager wholly on the basis of professional experience, ability and qualifications. 
(B)  Compensation. The City Engineer shall receive compensation as the City Manager shall fix from time to time. 
(C)  Removal procedure. The City Engineer may be removed with cause by the City Manager subject to city personnel policies. The City Manager may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the City Engineer shall include: 
(1)  Planning, developing and managing the City Engineering Department's goals, objectives and work plans to perform those duties set forth by state law, as well as city ordinance, resolution, order or directive. 
(2)  Planning, directing and coordinating the design, construction and inspection of activities related to streets, storm drains, water distribution and wastewater collection facilities, improvement districts and land divisions. 
(3)  Being responsible for the review, approval and inspection of permitted private site and subdivision improvements. 
(4)  Being responsible for the review and approval, and the development of policies and procedures, for work in the public rights-of-way. 
(5)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014; Am. Ord. 565, N.S. , passed 8-23-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-274 and 9-302 
§ 2-3-24 - CITY MANAGER. 
(A)  Office created. The office of the City Manager of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The City Manager shall be appointed by the Council wholly on the basis of administrative and executive ability and qualifications and shall hold office for and at the pleasure of the Council. The Council may enter into an employment contract with the City Manager upon the terms and conditions deemed appropriate. 
(B)  Compensation. The City Manager shall receive compensation as the Council shall fix from time to time by ordinance, resolution, motion or contract. 
(C)  Removal procedure. Unless otherwise provided in an employment agreement, the City Manager may be removed with or without cause by a majority vote of the Council. If requested, the Council shall grant the City Manager a public hearing within 30 days following notice of removal. During the interim, the Council may suspend the City Manager from duty but shall continue the City Manager's salary. If the removal becomes final, the Council may provide severance pursuant to the terms of an employment contract, or otherwise, in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed six months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The City Manager shall be the administrative head of the government of the city under the direction and control of the Council except as otherwise provided in this article. The City Manager shall be responsible to the Council for the proper administration of all affairs of the city. In addition to the City Manager's general powers as administrative head and not as a limitation thereon, it shall be the City Manager's duty and the City Manager shall have the powers set forth in the following subsections: 
(1)  Appoint, and, when necessary for the good of the city, suspend or remove all officers and employees of the city not appointed by the Council. The City Manager may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint, suspend or remove subordinates in the department or office. 
(2)  Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the Council together with a message describing the important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption. 
(3)  Prepare and submit to the Council as of the end of the fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the city during the preceding year. 
(4)  Keep the Council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city and make recommendations as are deemed appropriate. 
(5)  Recommend to the Council merit provisions and a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the city service, including minimum, intermediate and maximum rates. 
(6)  Recommend to the Council from time to time adoption of the measures deemed necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services. 
(7)  Consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments or units under the City Manager's jurisdiction, with the approval of the Council. The City Manager may be the head of one or more departments. 
(8)  Attend all meetings of the Council unless excused therefrom and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the Council. The City Manager shall be entitled to notice of all regular and special meetings of the Council. 
(9)  In case of accident, disaster or other circumstance creating a public emergency, the City Manager may award contracts and make purchases for the purpose of meeting the emergency, but the City Manager shall file promptly with the Council a certificate showing the emergency and the necessity for the action, together with an itemized account of all expenditures. 
(10)  See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced. 
(11)  Investigate the affairs of the city or any department or division thereof. Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government of the city and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the city, and see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the city are faithfully observed. 
(12)  If the Assistant City Manager is unable or unavailable to perform the duties of the City Manager during the temporary absence or disability of the City Manager, designate a qualified administrative officer of the city to perform such duties. If the City Manager is unable to make such designation during the temporary absence or disability of the permanent City Manager and if the Assistant City Manager is unable or unavailable to perform such duties, the Council may designate a qualified administrative officer of the city to perform such duties. 
(13)  Perform any other duties as may be required by the Council, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
(E)  Council not to interfere with appointments or removals. With regard to officers and employees appointed by the City Manager, neither the Council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to, or removal or suspension from the office by the City Manager or any of the City Manager's subordinates, or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of the officers and employees in the administrative services of the city. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the Council and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the City Manager. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-274, 9-302 and 9-303

(C)  Removal procedure. The Assistant City Manager may be removed with cause by the City Manager subject to city personnel policies. The City Manager may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Assistant City Manager shall include: 
(1)  Exercising administrative authority. 
(2)  Making reports. 
(3)  Preparing budget estimates. 
(4)  Providing services. 
(5)  Directing and supervising employees. 
(6)  Maintaining necessary records. 
(7)  Performing the duties of the City Manager during the temporary absence or disability of the City Manager. 
(8)  Performing any additional duties relating to the conduct of city affairs as may be assigned by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014; Am. Ord. 565, N.S. , passed 8-23-2016)

(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Chief Financial Officer shall include: 
(1)  Taking charge of the city's Finance Department. 
(2)  Accepting, recording and depositing all cash received into the city. 
(3)  Disbursing cash as required to satisfy all claims against the city and required debt incurred by the city. 
(4)  Providing an efficient financial management system to account for all transactions of a financial nature. 
(5)  Investing all idle funds in accordance with the City Code to enhance interest earnings. 
(6)  Preparing and administering an annual budget in accordance with the City Code and the laws of the state. 
(7)  Procuring goods and services through the most efficient process available consistent with the mandates of the City Code. 
(8)  Preserving and accounting for all fixed assets acquired by the city. 
(9)  Performing any additional duties as may be required by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances.

§ 2-3-30 - FIRE CHIEF. 
(A)  Office created. The office of Fire Chief of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the City Manager wholly on the basis of professional experience, ability and qualifications. 
(B)  Compensation. The Fire Chief shall receive compensation as the City Manager shall fix from time to time. 
(C)  Removal procedure. The Fire Chief may be removed with cause by the City Manager subject to city personnel policies. The City Manager may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Fire Chief shall include: 
(1)  Being accountable to the City Manager for the personnel, morale and general efficiency of the Fire Department. 
(2)  Directing the operations of the Fire Department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
(3)  Assisting the proper authorities in suppressing the crime of arson by investigating or causing to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all fires. 
(4)  Inspecting buildings and premises and serving written notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any and all fire hazards that may be found. For the purpose of conducting the inspection, the Fire Chief is hereby empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises within the city at any reasonable hour. Any person served with the written notice shall comply and notify the Fire Chief of compliance within a reasonable time. 
(5)  Making a complete annual report, in writing, to the City Manager at a time as may be specified by the City Manager, including a record of all fires, inspections, apparatus and equipment, personnel and other information about the work of the Fire Department, together with comparative data for previous years and recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the Fire Department. Reports may be required to be submitted more frequently, at the discretion of the City Manager. 
(6)  Enforcing or causing to be enforced all ordinances, laws and regulations of the city and state, insofar as they pertain to fire and safety. 
(7)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014; Am. Ord. 565, N.S. , passed 8-23-2016) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-240, 9-274 and 9-302
