§ 2-3-33 - POLICE CHIEF. 
(A)  Office created. The office of Police Chief of the City of Tolleson is hereby created and established. The Police Chief shall be appointed by the City Manager wholly on the basis of professional experience, ability and qualifications. 
(B)  Compensation. The Police Chief shall receive compensation as the City Manager shall fix from time to time. 
(C)  Removal procedure. The Police Chief may be removed with cause by the City Manager subject to city personnel policies. The City Manager may provide severance in an amount deemed appropriate but not to exceed three months' salary. 
(D)  Powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Police Chief shall include: 
(1)  Enforcing the ordinances of the city and seeing that the rules and regulations of the Police Department are obeyed. 
(2)  Directing the operation of the Police Department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
(3)  Arresting any person violating any of the city ordinances and taking the violator before the Magistrate Court for trial. 
(4)  Taking charge of the city jail and all prisoners confined therein and seeing that orders and sentences with reference to all those who are sentenced to labor on the streets or public works of the city are fully executed and complied with. 
(5)  Delivering any persons that may be confined in the jail upon conviction of a crime committed under the jurisdiction of the Magistrate Court, to an authorized officer of the city who shall at any time demand the prisoners. Any authorized person so demanding and receiving the prisoners shall work the prisoners on the streets or alleys of the city or on any and all authorized work as may be determined by the Council. 
(6)  Collecting license fees if ordered to do so by city ordinance and pay over to the Treasurer all moneys received, taking receipts therefore. 
(7)  Rendering the accounts of the Police Department, his or her duties and receipts, as may be required by the City Manager. 
(8)  Keeping the records of the Police Chief open to inspection by the City Manager at any time. 
(9)  Performing any other duties as may be required by the City Manager, not inconsistent with state law or city ordinances. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014; Am. Ord. 565, N.S. , passed 8-23-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. 565, N.S. , passed August 23, 2016, repealed § 2-3-33 and renumbered the former §§ 2-3-34 and 2-3-35 as §§ 2-3-33 and 2-3-34 as set out herein. The former § 2-3-33 pertained to the Library Director and derived from Res. 2167, passed March 11, 2014. The historical notation has been retained with the amended provisions for reference purposes.

LIABILITY INSURANCE 

§ 2-3-50 - PROCUREMENT. 
    The city shall, at all times, procure liability insurance in type and amount deemed necessary and appropriate and at rates deemed reasonable covering its officers, employees and agents while employed in their governmental or proprietary capacities. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-497 
§ 2-3-51 - NOTICES OF CLAIM. 
    Every city officer, employee and agent shall, upon receipt of any service of process commencing litigation against them or written notice of a possible claim, promptly give notice of the pendency of the action or the presentation of the claim to the City Clerk, who shall in turn present the actual or possible claim to the City Manager and City Attorney. 
( Res. 2167 , passed 3-11-2014) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-497 
ARTICLE 2-4: - PERSONNEL POLICIES 

§ 2-4-1 - CREATION AND SCOPE. 
(A)  The City Manager shall recommend, and the City Council shall adopt, a personnel system for the employees of the city, the provisions of which shall apply to all employees of the city as set forth in the personnel policies, except elected officials, persons engaged under contract to supply expert, professional or technical services and volunteer personnel who receive no regular compensation from the city. 
(B)  The Council may adopt rules and procedures pertaining to the officers of the city appointed directly by the Council. 
(C)  The Human Resources Director is authorized on behalf of the city to receive criminal history record information from the Department of Public Safety ("DPS") for the purpose of evaluating the fitness of current or prospective licensees, employees, contract employees or volunteers, upon submission of the subject's fingerprints and any fees as may prescribed by DPS. 
(1)  Notwithstanding any other provision of the City Code, all current and prospective employees, contract employees and volunteers of the City of Tolleson who, as a result of their positions, may come into contact with or be in the proximity of children or vulnerable adults, as defined in A.R.S. § 13-3623, or whose positions involve fiduciary responsibilities or access to safety-sensitive, private or confidential information, including but not limited to Information Technology, Finance, Senior Center, Community Action Program, Library, Fire, Police, Volunteer and the City Court, shall furnish a full set of fingerprints on a standard fingerprint card to the Human Resources Director to enable the city to conduct a criminal history record investigation to determine the suitability of the individual for such a position pursuant to A.R.S. § 41-1750 and Public Law 92-544. 
(2)  The City shall bear the cost of obtaining such criminal history record information and shall use it solely for the purpose of evaluating the fitness of prospective employees, volunteers, or promotional employees of the city. 
( Am. Ord. 499, N.S. , passed 10-12-2010) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239 and 9-274 
§ 2-4-2 - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT. 
(A)  The appointment, promotion and tenure of every employee shall be conditioned solely on merit and fitness and the satisfactory performance of the duties and responsibilities assigned. 
(B)  No employee or applicant for employment shall be discriminated against on the basis of race, color, national origin, religion, gender, age, disability, marital or familial status, veteran status or political affiliation. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 41-1461 et seq. 
§ 2-4-3 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The City Council and City Manager may adopt rules, regulations and policies to give effect to this article, which may be modified and changed from time to time. 
(Ord. 298, N.S., passed 10-10-1989; Am. Ord. 375, N.S., passed 11-24-1998; Am. Ord. 383, N.S., passed 6-22-1999; Am. Ord. 436, N.S., passed 2-14-2006; Am. Ord. 452, N.S., passed 3-13-2007; Am. Ord. 457, N.S., passed 5-22-2007; Am. Ord. 459, N.S., passed 7-24-2007; Am. Ord. 461, N.S., passed 8-14-2007) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239 and 9-274 
§ 2-4-4 - POLITICAL ACTIVITIES. 
(A)  The city shall not use its personnel, equipment, materials, buildings or other resources for the purpose of influencing the outcomes of elections. Notwithstanding this section, the city may distribute informational reports on a proposed bond election as provided in state law. Nothing in this section precludes the city from reporting on official actions of the City Council. 
(B)  No city employee shall use the authority of his or her position to influence the vote or political activities of any subordinate employee. 
(C)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as denying the civil and political liberties of any employee as guaranteed by the United States and Arizona Constitutions. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-500.14 
ARTICLE 2-5: - FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE FOR PUBLIC OFFICIALS 

§ 2-5-1 - INTRODUCTION. 
    Pursuant to state law, the city is required to adopt standards of financial disclosure consistent with those set forth in state law, and the Council has determined that the standards of financial disclosure hereinafter adopted are with respect to the city consistent with the standards of financial disclosure. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 38-545 
§ 2-5-2 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    BUSINESS. Includes any enterprise, organization, trade, occupation or profession, whether or not operated as a legal entity or for profit, including any business trust, corporation, partnership, joint venture or sole proprietorship. 
    COMPENSATION. Anything of value or advantage, present or prospective, including the forgiveness of debt. 
    CONTROLLED BUSINESS. Any business in which the member of Council or any member of his or her household has an ownership or beneficial interest, individually or combined, amounting to more than a 50% interest. 
    DEPENDENT BUSINESS. Any business in which the member of Council or any member of his or her household has an ownership or beneficial interest, individually or combined, amounting to more than a 10% interest, and during the preceding calendar year the business received from a single source more than $10,000 and more than 50% of its gross income. 
    GIFT. Includes any gratuity, special discount, favor, hospitality, service, economic opportunity, loan or other benefit received without equivalent consideration and not provided to members of the public at large. 
    MEMBER OF HOUSEHOLD. A member of Council's spouse and any minor child of whom the member of Council has legal custody. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 38-541 
§ 2-5-3 - DUTY TO FILE DISCLOSURE STATEMENT; CONTENTS; EXCEPTIONS. 
(A)  In addition to other statements and reports required by law, each member of Council as a matter of public record shall file with the City Clerk, on a form prescribed by the City Clerk, a verified financial disclosure statement covering the preceding calendar year ending December 31 disclosing: 
(1)  The name and address of the member of Council and each member of his or her household and all names and addresses under which each does business; 
(2)  The name and address of each employer and of each other source of compensation other than gifts amounting to more than $1,000 received during the preceding calendar year by the member of Council and members of his or her household in their own names, or by any other person for the use or benefit of the Council member or members of his or her household, a description of the services for which the compensation was received and the nature of the employer's business. This division shall not be construed to require the disclosure of individual items of compensation that constituted a portion of the gross income of the business from which the member of Council or members of his or her household derived compensation; 
(3)  For a controlled business, a description of the goods or services provided by the business, and if any single source of compensation to the business during the preceding calendar year amounts to more than $10,000 and is more than 25% of the gross income of the business, the disclosure shall also include a description of the goods or services provided to the source of compensation. For a dependent business, the statement shall disclose a description of the goods or services provided by the business and a description of the goods or services provided to the source of compensation from which the dependent business derived the amount of gross income described in § 2-5-2 above. If the source of compensation for a controlled or dependent business is a business, the statement shall disclose a description of the business activities engaged in by the source of compensation; 
(4)  The names and addresses of all businesses and trusts in which the member of Council or members of his or her household, or any other person for the use or benefit of the member of Council or members of his or her household, had an ownership or beneficial interest of over $1,000 at any time during the preceding calendar year, and the names and addresses of all businesses and trusts in which the member of Council or any member of his or her household held any office or had a fiduciary relationship at any time during the preceding calendar year, together with the amount or value of the interest and a description of the interest, office or relationship; 
(5)  All Arizona real property interests and real property improvements, including specific location and approximate size, in which the member of Council, any member of his or her household or a controlled or dependent business held legal title or a beneficial interest at any time during the preceding calendar year, and the value of any interest, except that this division does not apply to a real property interest and improvements thereon used as the primary personal residence or for the personal recreational use of the member of Council. If a member of Council, any member of his or her household or a controlled or dependent business acquired or divested any interest during the preceding calendar year, he or she shall also disclose that the transaction was made and the date it occurred. If the controlled or dependent business is in the business of dealing in real property interests or improvements, disclosure need not include individual parcels or transactions as long as the aggregate value of all parcels of the property is reported; 
(6)  The names and addresses of all creditors to whom the member of Council or members of his or her household, in their own names or in the name of any other person, owed a debt of more than $1,000 or to whom a controlled business or a dependent business owed a debt of more than $10,000 which was also more than 30% of the total business indebtedness at any time during the preceding calendar year, listing each creditor. This division shall not be construed to require the disclosure of debts owed by the member of Council or any member of his or her household resulting from the ordinary conduct of a business other than a controlled or dependent business. Nor shall disclosure be required of credit card transactions, retail installment contracts, debts on residences or recreational property exempt from disclosure under division (A)(5) above, debts on motor vehicles not used for commercial purposes, debts secured by cash values on life insurance or debts owed to relatives. It is sufficient disclosure of a creditor if the name and address of a person to whom payments are made is disclosed. If the member of Council, any member of his or her household or a controlled or dependent business incurred or discharged a debt which is reportable under this division during the preceding calendar year, the report shall disclose that the transaction was made and the date it occurred; 
(7)  The identification and amount of each debt exceeding $1,000 owed at any time during the preceding calendar year to the member of Council and members of his or her household in their own names, or to any other person for the use or benefit of the member of Council or any member of his or her household. The disclosure shall include the identification and amount of each debt exceeding $10,000 to a controlled business or dependent business which was also more than 30% of the total indebtedness to the business at any time during the preceding calendar year. This division shall not be construed to require the disclosure of debts from the ordinary conduct of a business other than a controlled or dependent business. If the member of Council, any member of his or her household or a controlled or dependent business incurred or discharged a debt which is reportable under this division during the preceding year, the report shall disclose that the transaction was made and the date it occurred; 
(8)  The name of each source of any gift, or accumulated gifts from a single source, of more than $500 received by the member of Council and members of his or her household in their own names during the preceding calendar year, or by any other person for the use or benefit of the member of Council or any member of his or her household except gifts received by will or by virtue of intestate succession, or received by way of distribution from any inter vivos or testamentary trust established by a spouse or by an ancestor, or gifts received from any other member of the household or relatives to the second degree of consanguinity. Political campaign contributions shall not be construed as gifts if otherwise publicly reported as political campaign contributions as required by law; 
(9)  A list of all business licenses issued to, held by or in which the member of Council or any member of his or her household had an interest at any time during the preceding calendar year, including the name in which the license was issued, the type of business and its location; and 
(10)  A list of all bonds, together with their value, issued by this state or any political subdivision of this state held at any time during the preceding calendar year by the member of Council or any member of his or her household, which bonds issued by a single entity had a value in excess of $1,000. If the member of Council or any member of his or her household acquired or divested any bonds during the preceding calendar year which are reportable under this division, the fact that the transaction occurred and the date shall also be shown. 
(B)  If an amount or value is required to be reported pursuant to this section, it is sufficient to report whether the amount or value of the equity interest falls within: 
(1)  Category 1: $1,000 to $25,000; 
(2)  Category 2: more than $25,000 to $100,000; and 
(3)  Category 3: more than $100,000. 
(C)  This section does not require the disclosure of any information that is privileged by law. 
(D)  The statement required to be filed pursuant to division (A) above shall be filed by all persons who qualified as a member of Council at any time during the preceding calendar year on or before January 31 of each year with the exceptions that a member of Council appointed to fill a vacancy shall, within 60 days following his or her taking of office, file a financial disclosure statement covering as his or her annual period the 12-month period ending with the last full month prior to the date of his or her taking office. 
(E)  The City Clerk shall provide forms for completing the financial disclosure statement required by this section. The forms shall be distributed to each member of Council and shall be made available to each candidate required to file a financial disclosure statement pursuant to A.R.S. § 38-543. 
(F)  The statement required to be filed pursuant to division (A) above shall be filed by each member of Council on or before January 31 of each year. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 38-542 
§ 2-5-4 - DUTY TO FILE FINAL FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE STATEMENT BY A CANDIDATE. 
    A candidate for Mayor or Council shall file a financial disclosure statement containing the information required as set forth in this article on a form prescribed by the City Clerk, at the time of filing his or her signed nomination papers. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 38-543 
ARTICLE 2-6: - MAGISTRATE COURT 

§ 2-6-1 - MAGISTRATE COURT ESTABLISHED; JURISDICTION. 
    There is hereby established in the city the Magistrate Court, which shall have jurisdiction of all violations of this code, and jurisdiction concurrently with justices of the peace of precincts in which the city is located of violation of laws of the state committed within the limits of the city. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 22-402 
§ 2-6-2 - PRESIDING OFFICERS. 
(A)  Magistrate. The presiding officer of the Magistrate Court shall be the Magistrate, who shall be appointed by the Council, shall receive compensation, shall have powers and duties and be subject to removal from office as provided in Article 2-3 of this chapter. 
(B)  Substitute Magistrates. In the event a substitute or alternate magistrate is required in any case in the Magistrate Court in which the Chief Magistrate cannot serve, the City Manager, is hereby authorized to bring in a duly appointed city or town magistrate or justice of the peace from some other jurisdiction to hear the case in question. The substitute magistrate may be compensated with the approval of the City Manager in an amount not to exceed a maximum established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. 475, N.S., passed 5-27-2008; Am. Ord. 518, N.S., passed 11-8-2011) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 9-239, 9-274 and 22-403 
§ 2-6-3 - PROCEEDINGS OF COURT. 
(A)  All proceedings shall be conducted in accordance with the state's Constitution, the applicable state statutes and rules of the state's Supreme Court pertaining to municipal courts including the code of judicial conduct. The proceedings shall also be conducted in accordance with the rules of criminal procedure for the Superior Court, unless otherwise prescribed, and providing this code and resolutions of the city are not in conflict therewith. 
(B)  The Magistrate Court proceedings shall be commenced by complaint under oath and in the name of the state setting forth the offense charged with and the particulars of time, place, person and property as to enable the defendant to understand distinctly the character of the offense complained of and to answer the complaint. 
(C)  If the Magistrate is satisfied that the offense complained of has been committed by the person charged, the Magistrate shall issue a summons or a warrant of arrest. Before issuing a summons or warrant of arrest on a complaint, the Magistrate may subpoena and examine witnesses as to the truth of the complaint. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 22-421, 22-422 and 22-423 
§ 2-6-4 - JURY TRIALS. 
(A)  Trial by jury. The right of trial by jury shall be granted in all cases as are triable by jury under the Constitution and laws of the state. 
(B)  Formation of jury. The formation, summoning, drawing, disposition of names and the impaneling of jurors shall be accomplished in the same manner as courts of record. 
(C)  Selection of jurors. For the selection of potential jurors, lists of registered voters shall be furnished by the Maricopa County Recorder. In addition to the voters list, the Magistrate Court shall use a list of the names and addresses of all persons in the city who are at least 18 years of age and who have been licensed pursuant to A.R.S. Title 28, Chapter 8, Articles 4 or 5, and amendments thereto. Only persons residing within the city limits are eligible for jury service in Magistrate Court. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 22-425 
§ 2-6-5 - COURT FEES AND CHARGES. 
(A)  Fee schedule. In addition to any other fees and charges authorized by law to be charged including, but not limited to, fees for filing, copying and certification, the Magistrate Court is authorized to impose the following fees and allocate charges to the parties who have caused the charges to be incurred. 
(1)  Administrative fee. A Court user fee in the amount of $20 is hereby established. The Magistrate shall direct a defendant or a Court user to pay the Court user fee in all cases processed by the Court which result in an order or agreement to pay any fine, sanction, penalty or assessment or participate in any Court authorized diversion program. The Court user fee shall not be imposed on civil parking violations. The Court user fee shall be collected by the Court for deposit in the city's General Fund. 
(2)  Court improvement fee. The Court shall impose a Court improvement fee in the amount of $5 per citation which shall be applied by the Court on all fines, sanctions, penalties and assessments imposed by the Court with the exception of civil parking violations. The Court improvement fee shall be collected by the Court for deposit in a Court improvement fund account maintained by the city and shall be used exclusively to enhance the Court's technological, operational and security capabilities. The city shall invest the monies in the same manner as other city funds. Interest earned on the monies shall be deposited in the fund. 
(3)  Prosecution fee. Upon a defendant's conviction at trial or by plea agreement, the Court shall impose a one-time prosecution fee per citation against each defendant in an amount set forth below. 
(a)  The prosecution fee for a misdemeanor citation shall be $10. 
(b)  The prosecution fee for a violation of A.R.S. Title 28, Chapter 4, shall be $35. 
(c)  A prosecution fee of a higher or lower amount may be imposed as set forth in a written plea agreement and based upon the actual cost of prosecuting the citation and/or the indigent status of the defendant. 
(4)  Default judgment fee. The Court shall order the payment of a $50 fee by each defendant who fails to appear on a civil traffic violation filed in the Court or fails to pay the civil sanction as ordered, unless the default is set pursuant to the Rules of Procedure in Civil Traffic Violation Cases. 
(5)  Order to show cause fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $50 by any defendant for whom the Court issues an order to show cause to enforce any Court order. 
(6)  Warrant administrative fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $50 by each defendant for whom the Court enters an arrest warrant for failure to appear, or for failure to pay any fine, restitution or other Court imposed fee or obligation, or failure to comply with any other Court order. This fee shall be added to any amounts owed by the defendant. 
(7)  Abstract fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $10 by each person requesting a Court abstract for the purpose of reinstating a driver's license whether the license was suspended as a result of a civil or criminal violation. 
(8)  Suspension fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $15 by any defendant for the suspension issued by the Court of the defendant's driver's license. Any defendant who has had a suspension issued by the Court for failure to appear in a civil traffic violation case or for failure to satisfy in full a civil sanction imposed in a civil traffic violation case shall be required to pay this fee to the Court for the cost of issuing and servicing the suspension. This fee shall be applied to each suspension issued. 
(9)  Jury cancellation fee. A jury cancellation fee shall be imposed by the Court on any party who requests a jury trial in the Magistrate Court, if within five days of trial and after the Court has arranged for the paneling of a jury, the party decides to not proceed with the jury trial. The amount of the jury cancellation fee shall be the actual costs incurred in connection with the canceled paneling and shall not be less than $100 nor more than $500. 
(10)  Probation monitoring fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $30 per month by all defendants who are placed on monitored probation. The fee shall be paid to and collected by the probation monitor. The probation monitor in his or her discretion may waive or reduce the fee. The fee may be terminated if the probation becomes unsupervised. 
(11)  Jail cost fee. The Court may, pursuant to state law, as a part of a sentence imposed by the Court order a person sentenced to serve time in jail to reimburse the city for all or part of the actual cost of his or her incarceration incurred by the city as a result of that incarceration at the daily rates charged to the city by the jail. 
(12)  Community service monitoring fee. Each defendant allowed to complete community service in lieu of paying any fine, fee or surcharge shall be charged a fee of $10 to cover part of the cost of monitoring his or her progress on completing the community service. 
(13)  Diversion monitoring fee. Each defendant who is allowed to enter a diversion program or deferred prosecution agreement, will be charged a $25 fee to cover the added cost of monitoring his or her compliance with the diversion program or agreement. This shall not apply to those entering the Defensive Driving School or the Suspended Driver License Diversion Program. 
(14)  Debt setoff fee. A fee of $9 shall be assessed to each defendant when the defendant's case is entered into the Debt Setoff System. 
(15)  Returned check fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $25 by any person paying the Court with a check that is dishonored by a financial institution. This fee will be in addition to any fees imposed on the Court by the bank or financial institution for processing the dishonored check or financial instrument. 
(16)  Collection fees. A defendant who defaults in his or her obligation for the payment of monies owed or due to the Magistrate Court, including, but not limited to, restitution, fines, sanctions, surcharges, assessments, penalties, bonds, costs and fees is liable for any fees and charges assessed by a collection agency that is licensed pursuant to state law, and that is engaged by the Magistrate Court to collect and enforce the payment. The collection fees and charges assessed by the collection agency shall be added to the sum or sums from and chargeable against the defendant. 
(17)  Research fee. The Court shall order the payment of a fee of $17 by any person requesting research in locating a document. 
(B)  Waiver of fees. Notwithstanding division (A) above, a Magistrate may waive part or all of any fee imposed by this section if the Court finds the defendant is indigent, it would cause a hardship on the defendant or his or her family, or if the Magistrate is of the opinion the waiver would be in the interests of justice. 
(C)  Civil action to recover fees. In addition to any other remedies which may be allowed by law, the City Attorney is authorized to institute any appropriate civil suit in a Court of competent jurisdiction for recovery of the fee(s) referred to in this article. 
(Am. Ord. 405, N.S., passed 6-10-2003; Am. Ord. 450, N.S., passed 2-13-2007; Am. Ord. 520, N.S., passed 12-13-2011) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 22-404 and 22-406 
ARTICLE 2-7: - LIBRARIES 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 

§ 2-7-1 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The City Manager is authorized to establish library rules and regulations to govern the use of library facilities and materials. 
§ 2-7-2 - FEES AND FINES. 
    The City Manager is authorized to establish library card issuance fees, renewal fees and user fees and to change the fees from time to time. Additionally, the City Manager may establish a schedule of fines and penalties for violation of any library rule or regulation. 
§ 2-7-3 - COMMUNITY SERVICES DIRECTOR. 
    The public library shall be administered by the Community Services Director who shall be appointed by the City Manager. The Community Services Director shall administer the library and its staff. 
( Am. Ord. 538, N.S. , passed 4-8-2014) 
§ 2-7-4 - MUTILATION OF BOOKS AND LIBRARY PROPERTY. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mar, deface, mutilate or in any way damage any books, paper, periodicals or newspapers which are the property of or contained in the public library, or to mar, deface, mutilate or in any way damage any other real or personal library property, including furniture and fixtures. 
LIBRARY ADVISORY BOARD 

§ 2-7-15 - CREATED. 
    There is hereby created a Library Advisory Board for the city. 
§ 2-7-16 - PURPOSE. 
    The Library Advisory Board shall: 
(A)  Promote the interests of the city's libraries; 
(B)  Coordinate fundraising activities to enhance the use of the city's libraries; 
(C)  Educate the community regarding planned giving; and 
(D)  Advise the City Council on matters and issues pertaining to library services, including, but not limited to planning of future libraries and library activities. 
§ 2-7-17 - MEMBERS; VACANCIES; REMOVAL; ATTENDANCE. 
(A)  The Library Advisory Board shall have seven regular members and one alternate member. The members shall be appointed by the City Council and shall be appointed for three-year, staggered terms. 
(B)  The Mayor, City Manager and Community Services Director shall be ex officio members of the Library Advisory Board and shall have no vote in the matters to come before the Board. 
(C)  In the event of death, resignation or removal of any member of the Library Advisory Board, the Mayor and Council shall appoint a new member to serve for the unexpired portion of the term vacated. Reappointment or a new appointment shall be made by the City Council at the end of the expired term. The City Council may, without cause, remove any member of the Library Advisory Board. The absence from three consecutive regular meeting without consent of the Board shall be deemed to constitute a resignation of the absent member, and the position shall thereupon be deemed vacant. 
§ 2-7-18 - QUORUM. 
    A majority of the Library Advisory Board shall constitute a quorum, and the affirmative vote of the majority of the Board members present shall be required to take action. 
§ 2-7-19 - MEETINGS; RULES; AND THE LIKE. 
    The Library Advisory Board shall: 
(A)  Establish the rules and regulations as it deems necessary for its government and for the faithful performance of its duties; 
(B)  By vote, set a time for regular, quarterly meetings; 
(C)  Establish a manner in which special meetings may be held and the notice to be given thereof; and 
(D)  Require attendance of the members at regular meetings. 
ARTICLE 2-8: - COMMUNITY CENTER AND PARKS 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 

§ 2-8-1 - DEFINITIONS. 
    COMMUNITY CENTER shall mean all city-owned or leased facilities open either in whole or in part to the public for recreational use. 
§ 2-8-2 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The City Manager is authorized to establish community center rules and regulations to govern the use of community centers. 
§ 2-8-3 - FACILITY USE PERMITS. 
(A)  A facility use permit shall be obtained from the city's community services office by any person, organization or group desiring to reserve any portion of a community center for any activity. 
(B)  Applicants must apply for a facility use permit at least two weeks prior to the requested date(s) of use. Facility use permit applications shall reflect the use date(s), hours of use, age group and anticipated number of participants and type of activity proposed. 
(C)  Permitted activities shall be confined to the specific area of the community center designated in the permit. 
(D)  All facility use permits shall be immediately revocable by the City Manager or authorized designee upon determination that a violation of any rule, city ordinance or state statute has occurred. 
(E)  All persons, organizations or groups using any portion of a community center under a facility use permit must vacate the premises by 11:00 p.m. unless otherwise authorized, in writing, by the City Manager or authorized designee. 
§ 2-8-4 - INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY. 
    Any organization, group or person using a community center under a use permit shall indemnify the city for any and all damage to any part of the community by any person attending the activity and all liability and damages to any person for injuries, including death. If insurance is required by the City Manager or authorized designee, failure to provide proof of insurance will result in the permit being denied or revoked. 
§ 2-8-5 - PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO USE. 
    Use of the community centers is not limited to residents, however, Tolleson residents may have preferential use of and reservation rights for community centers as determined by the City Manager or authorized designee. 
§ 2-8-6 - FEES. 
    The City Manager is authorized to establish community center use fees and to change fees from time to time. 
§ 2-8-7 - CANCELLATION OF REQUEST TO USE. 
    If notice of cancellation of a request to use a community center is not received in the Community Services office at least 48 hours prior to the date of the event, the use permit holder, at the discretion of the City Manager or authorized designee, may be held responsible for any expenses incurred by the city. 
USE RESTRICTIONS 

§ 2-8-20 - SUPERVISION OF ACTIVITIES; RESPONSIBILITY FOR DAMAGE. 
(A)  At the discretion of the City Manager or authorized designee, all activities at community centers may be required to be supervised by an adult, and the use permit holder shall assume full responsibility for any damage to the community center or equipment therein that is caused by participants under the use permit. 
(B)  The City Manager may designate a city employee to oversee activities of permit holders. 
§ 2-8-21 - EXCEEDING SEATING CAPACITY. 
    The total number of people admitted to the community center for any use shall not exceed the seating capacity of the community center or designated area. 
§ 2-8-22 - USE OF EQUIPMENT. 
    The use of equipment at any community center shall be permitted only when specified in the use permit application. 
§ 2-8-23 - ATTACHMENTS TO STRUCTURE, AND THE LIKE. 
    No material of any kind shall be attached to any part of the community center without express, written approval from the City Manager or authorized designee. 
§ 2-8-24 - CONCESSION RIGHTS. 
    Concession rights at community centers shall be reserved to the city unless specifically requested by the applicant and approved in the use permit. 
§ 2-8-25 - KITCHEN FACILITIES. 
    Use of kitchen facilities, if any, shall be permitted only if specifically requested in the application for a use permit. Kitchen facilities must be cleaned after use. 
§ 2-8-26 - TOBACCO. 
    The use of tobacco at community centers is restricted to designated smoking areas, if any. 
§ 2-8-27 - POLITICAL ACTIVITIES. 
    No partisan political activities for any party or candidate shall take place in any community center. 
§ 2-8-28 - INTOXICATING BEVERAGES. 
    The use or consumption of intoxicating beverages at the community centers is prohibited, except where a license has been issued. 
§ 2-8-29 - COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER LAWS AND ORDINANCES. 
    Persons or groups utilizing the community centers must obey all federal, state, county and city laws and ordinances. 
PARKS AND RECREATION 

§ 2-8-40 - DEFINITIONS. 
    PARK means all lands and water heretofore and hereafter acquired by or controlled by the city for park, open space amenity or recreational purposes, including privately or publicly owned lands, the use of which has been granted to and accepted by the city for park, open space amenity, recreational purposes. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-41 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The City Council shall approve park rules and regulations to govern the use of parks. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-42 - FEES. 
    The City Council shall establish recreational user fees for parks and recreational programs or for use of park facilities and may change said fees from time to time. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-43 - PARK HOURS OF OPERATION. 
    No person shall enter upon or be upon the grounds, other than public streets located therein, of any park or playground, without the express written permission of the City Manager or his designee, between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m.; provided, however, that with respect to any park or playground that is equipped with either general area or athletic lighting which is functioning, the closing time may be extended by the prior written approval of the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-44 - RESERVATION OF PARK FACILITIES. 
(A)  A permit shall be obtained from the City Manager or designee by any person, organization or group desiring to reserve any ramada, athletic playing field or other park facility. 
(B)  An application for a permit shall be submitted to the city prior to the requested date(s) as stipulated in the park polices. All applications for use of the facilities shall, along with any additional information requested by the City Manger, reflect the date, hours to be used, age of group, type of activity and anticipated number of participants. 
(C)  Functions shall be confined to the specific area of the park assigned to the permit holder. 
(D)  All permits shall be immediately revocable by the City Manager or his designee upon determination that a violation of any rule, city ordinance or state statute, has occurred. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-45 - INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY. 
    Any person, organization or group using the park facilities pursuant to a permit issued under this chapter shall indemnify the city for, from and against any and all damage to any part of the park facility caused by a person attending or participating in the activity and for any and all personal injuries caused by a person attending or participating in the activity. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-46 - PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO USE PARK FACILITIES. 
    Use of the park facilities is not limited to residents, however, Tolleson residents may have preferential use of and reservation rights for the park facilities as determined by the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-47 - SUPERVISION OF ACTIVITIES. 
(A)  At the discretion of the City Manager or his designee, all activities at park facilities may be required to take place under competent, adult supervision. 
(B)  The City Manager or his designee may designate a person to oversee the activity. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-48 - DOGS IN PARKS. 
    Unless in a designated park off-leash area, all dogs in any parks must be restrained by a leash, chain, rope or cord of not more than six feet in length and of sufficient strength to control the action of said dog. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-49 - OFF-LEASH AREAS. 
    The City Manager shall set rules and regulations for use of designated off-leash areas within city parks. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-50 - MOTORIZED VEHICLES AND SKATEBOARDS. 
    Unless otherwise permitted by the City Manager or authorized designee, no motorized vehicle or motorized skateboard, as defined in A.R.S. Title 28, may enter upon or park in any park area, except in designated parking areas or designated parking spaces. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-51 - REFUSE; VIOLATION. 
(A)  No person shall discard or throw paper, lunch boxes, refuse or litter on any park property, but the same shall be placed in receptacles provided for such purposes. If receptacles do not exist, paper lunch boxes, refuse or litter shall be packed out of the park and disposed of properly. 
(B)  No person shall bring trash, refuse, litter or similar pollutants onto park property for deposit in park trash receptacles. 
(C)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class one misdemeanor to be punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500 or by imprisonment for not more than six months in jail. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-52 - DAMAGE; VIOLATION. 
(A)  No person, except with the prior, written permission of the city, shall take, carry away, remove, dig, cut, disturb, destroy, mar, or damage any soil or mineral substance or any form of vegetation, whether living or dead, on park property. 
(B)  No person, except with prior, written permission of the city, shall take, carry away, remove, disassemble, destroy, mar, deface, mark, damage or attach anything to any equipment, building or structure on park property. 
(C)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class one misdemeanor to be punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500 or by imprisonment for not more than six months in jail. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-53 - GLASS CONTAINERS PROHIBITED. 
    Glass beverage containers are strictly prohibited in any park located within the city. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-8-54 - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates a provision of this chapter may be subject to a civil penalty of $50 for the first violation, $100 for a second violation, $250 for a third violation and $500 for a fourth violation in any two-year period. 
(A)  Civil Citation. The civil citation shall direct the defendant to appear in municipal court within ten days of the issuance of the citation or pay the fine imposed pursuant to this section. The citation shall also include the date and location of the violation, a reference to the City Code provision or ordinance violated and a notice that if the defendant fails to appear as directed, a default judgment will be entered in the amount of the fine designated on the citation for the violation charged, in addition to a default fee for failure to appear as set forth in division (C) below of this section. 
(B)  Citation Service. Service of the citation may be accomplished and will be deemed proper and complete by any of the following methods: 
(1)  Hand delivering a copy of the citation to the defendant. 
(2)  Mailing a copy of the citation to the defendant by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the defendant's last known address. 
(3)  In the event service cannot be accomplished as set forth above, the defendant may be served by any means allowed by the Arizona Rules of Civil Procedure for the Superior Court. 
(C)  Appearance: Penalty for Failure to Appear. Within ten days of the issuance of the citation, the defendant shall appear in person or through his or her attorney in municipal court and shall either admit or deny the allegations contained in the complaint or the defendant may proceed as provided in division (D) of this section. If the defendant admits the allegations, the court shall immediately enter judgment against the defendant in the amount of the fine for the violation charged. If the defendant denies the allegations contained in the citation, the court shall set a hearing date for trial of the matter. If the defendant fails to appear as directed on the citation, the court, upon request by the code official or authorized designee, shall enter a default judgment for the amount of the fine indicated for the violation charged. Additionally, the defendant may be fined up to $100 for failure to appear at the time and place set for any trial of a matter arising under this code. 
(D)  Payment by Mail. The defendant may admit the allegations in the citation and pay the fine indicated by mailing the citation, together with a check for the amount of the fine to and made payable to the Tolleson City Court. 
(E)  Rules of Procedure. The Arizona Rules of Procedure in Civil Traffic Violation Cases shall be followed by the Tolleson City Court for civil violations of this code, except as modified or where inconsistent with the provisions of this code, local rules of the municipal court or rules of the Arizona Supreme Court. 
(Ord. 479, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
ARTICLE 2-9: - REMOVAL AND STORAGE OF DEADLY WEAPONS AT PUBLIC ESTABLISHMENTS AND EVENTS 

§ 2-9-1 - DEFINITIONS. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    DEADLY WEAPON shall mean anything designed for lethal use. 
    PUBLIC ESTABLISHMENT shall mean any structure, vehicle or craft that is owned, leased or operated by the city. 
    PUBLIC EVENT shall mean any specifically named or sponsored event of limited duration that is either conducted by the city or conducted by a private entity with a permit or license granted by the city. Public event does not include an unsponsored gathering of people in a public place. 
(Ord. 481, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
§ 2-9-2 - CARRYING OF DEADLY WEAPONS. 
    Any person other than a peace officer on duty carrying a deadly weapon, upon entering any public establishment or attending a public event, shall upon request of the city or sponsor of an event, as applicable, remove any deadly weapon carried by such person and place it in the custody of the city or sponsor, as applicable. The city or sponsor, as applicable, shall provide temporary and secure storage for such deadly weapon and shall allow for the immediate retrieval of such deadly weapon upon the person's exit from the public establishment or public event. 
(Ord. 481, N.S., passed 10-14-2008) 
CHAPTER 3: - CITY POLICIES AND PROCEDURES; FEES 
ARTICLE 3-1: - ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND CONTRACTS 

§ 3-1-1 - PRIOR APPROVAL. 
(A)  All ordinances, resolutions and contract documents shall, before presentation to the Council, have been reviewed as to form by the Attorney and shall, when there are substantive matters of administration involved, be referred to the person who is charged with the administration of the matters. 
(B)  The person shall have an opportunity to present his or her objections, if any, prior to the passage of the ordinance, resolution or acceptance of the contract. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-240 
§ 3-1-2 - INTRODUCTION. 
    Ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects requiring action by the Council shall be introduced and sponsored by a member of the Council, except that the City Manager or City Attorney may present ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects to the Council and any member of the Council may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that the ordinance, resolution, matter or subject be adopted; otherwise, they shall not be considered. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-240 
§ 3-1-3 - REQUIREMENTS FOR AN ORDINANCE. 
    Each ordinance shall have but one subject, the nature of which is clearly expressed in the title. Whenever possible, each ordinance shall be introduced as an amendment to this code or to an existing ordinance and, in that case, the title, numbers and pages in this code of the sections to be amended shall be included in the ordinance. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-240 
§ 3-1-4 - READING OF PROPOSED ORDINANCE. 
    Ordinances shall be read prior to adoption, but may be read by title only provided that the Council has before it printed or electronic copies of the ordinance. A member of the Council may request that the ordinance under consideration be read in full and, in that case, the ordinance shall be read in full. 
( Am. Ord. 535, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-240 
§ 3-1-5 - EFFECTIVE DATE OF ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND FRANCHISES. 
    No city ordinance, resolution or franchise that would be subject to the provisions of Title 19, Chapter 1 of the Arizona Revised Statutes, as amended shall become operative until 30 days after its passage by the Council, except emergency measures necessary for the immediate preservation of the peace, health or safety of the city. An emergency measure shall not become immediately operative unless it states in a separate section the reason why it is necessary that it should become immediately operative, and unless it is approved by the affirmative vote of three-fourths of all the members elected to the City Council, taken by ayes and nays, and also approved by the Mayor. Unless otherwise set forth therein, all other resolutions, ordinances or franchises shall be effective immediately upon passage by the Council. 
( Am. Ord. 535, N.S. , passed 11-18-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 19-142 
§ 3-1-6 - SIGNATURES REQUIRED. 
    Every ordinance passed by the Council shall, before it becomes effective, be signed by the Mayor, attested by the Clerk and approval signed as to form by the Attorney. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-240 
§ 3-1-7 - PUBLISHING REQUIRED. 
    Only orders, resolutions, motions, regulations or proceedings of the Council shall be published as may be required by state statutes or expressly ordered by the Council. All notices of election, invitation for bids, notices of letting contracts, laws and ordinances, and other notices of a public character issued by the Council shall be published as provided in state law. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-812 
§ 3-1-8 - POSTING REQUIRED. 
    Any ordinance imposing any penalty, fine, forfeiture or other punishment shall, in addition to the publication requirements of § 3-1-7 of this code, be published after its enactment by posting in three or more public places within the city and shall be in force from and after the date of posting. An affidavit of the person who posted the ordinance shall be filed in the office of the Clerk as proof of posting. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 9-813 
ARTICLE 3-2: - INITIATIVES AND REFERENDUMS 

§ 3-2-1 - POWER RESERVED; TIME OF ELECTION. 
    There is reserved to the qualified electors of the city the power of the initiative and the referendum as prescribed by the state's Constitution. Any initiative or referendum matter may be voted on at the next ensuing primary or general election or at a special election called by the Council for that purpose. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. Const. Art. 4, Part 1, § 1 
§ 3-2-2 - NUMBER OF SIGNATURES FOR INITIATIVE. 
    The total number of registered voters qualified to vote at the municipal election, whether regular or special, immediately preceding the date upon which any initiative petition is filed, shall be the basis upon which the number of qualified electors of the city required to file an initiative petition shall be computed. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 19-143 
§ 3-2-3 - NUMBER OF SIGNATURES FOR REFERENDUM. 
    The whole number of votes cast at the city election at which a Mayor or Council member was chosen last preceding the submission of the application for a referendum petition against an ordinance, franchise or resolution shall be the basis on which the number of electors of the city required to file a referendum petition shall be computed. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 19-142 
§ 3-2-4 - TIME OF FILING. 
(A)  Initiative petitions shall be filed at least four months prior to the election at which they are to be voted upon. 
(B)  Referendum petitions shall be filed within 30 days of the adoption of the ordinance, franchise or resolution to be referred. If the City Clerk is unable to provide petitioners with a copy of the ordinance, franchise or resolution at the time of application for an official number or on the same business day of the application, the 30-day period shall be calculated from the date the ordinance, franchise or resolution is available. 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. § 19-142 and A.R.S. Const. Art. 4, Part 1, § 1 
§ 3-2-5 - SAMPLE BALLOTS AND PUBLICITY PAMPHLETS. 
    The following procedures relating to sample ballots and publicity pamphlets are hereby adopted for conducting elections at which an initiative or referendum is to be voted on. 
(A)  A publicity pamphlet, containing the entire text of the official ballot, shall be mailed by the City Clerk to each household within the city in which a registered voter resides, so far as possible, not less than ten days prior to the election to which the sample ballot pertains. 
(B)  The pamphlet shall contain the proposition as it will appear on the ballot together with a summary of each proposition. Each summary shall be followed by any arguments supporting the proposition followed by any arguments opposing the proposition. 
(C)  Arguments supporting and opposing propositions appearing on the ballot shall be filed with the office of the City Clerk by the date required by law or such other date as may be established by the City Clerk or governmental agency conducting the election. Arguments supporting or opposing propositions appearing on the ballot shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Arguments must relate to the propositions proposed by initiative or referred by referendum which will appear on the ballot. 
(2)  Arguments must identify the proposition to which they refer and indicate whether the argument is in support of or opposition to the proposition. 
(3)  Arguments may not exceed 300 words in length. 
(4)  Arguments must be signed by the person submitting them. Arguments submitted by organizations shall be signed on behalf of the organization by two executive officers of the organization authorized to take action or, if sponsored by a political committee, it shall be signed by the committee's chairperson or treasurer. All persons signing documents shall indicate their residence or post office address. 
(5)  No person or organization shall submit more than one argument for each proposition to be voted on. 
(6)  Each argument shall be accompanied by a deposit in the amount of $250 to offset a portion of the proportional costs of the paper and printing of the argument. This requirement shall not be waived on any account. 
( Am. Ord. 530, N.S. , passed 10-23-2012) 
State Law reference- Authority, see A.R.S. §§ 19-123, 19-124 and 19-141 
ARTICLE 3-3: - FEES 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 

§ 3-3-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS. 
    The purpose of this article is to set forth various fees to be charged by the city in administering its municipal functions. Separate sections of the city code, the zoning code or the various building codes used by the city may have a fee schedule in conflict with this article in which case it is the intention of the Council that this article shall govern. If this article is silent and fees are set forth in other sections of the various city codes, the fees in those sections shall govern. 
(Ord. 235, N.S., passed 11-27-1984) 
§ 3-3-2 - WAIVER. 
    The City Manager may, with the approval of the Council, waive or modify any of the fees charged under this article or any other codes of the city, if benefits to the city are to be provided by the applicant to offset the charges waived. 
(Ord. 235, N.S., passed 11-27-1984) 
§ 3-3-3 - COLLECTION. 
    The fees provided by this article shall be collected by the City Manager or his or her designated representative. Separate bank accounts, when appropriate and required, shall be maintained by the city. 
(Ord. 235, N.S., passed 11-27-1984) 
FEES 

§ 3-3-21 - PUBLIC RECORDS. 
    The city shall be authorized to set fees with regard to the copying of public records subject to disclosure for a non-commercial purpose and a commercial purpose. The amount of fees charged by the city departments for the copying of public records, including the cost of the time, equipment and personnel used in producing copies of records for a non-commercial purpose and including the cost of time, equipment, personnel and value used in producing copies of records for a commercial purpose, shall be adopted by City Council resolution. 
(Ord. 467, N.S., passed 3-11-2008; Am. Ord. 523, N.S., passed 7-24-2012) 
Cross reference- Public records request policy, see §§ 3-7-1 and 3-7-2 
ARTICLE 3-4: - TAX CODE 

§ 3-4-1 - ADOPTION OF TAX CODE. 
    That certain code entitled the City Tax Code of The City of Tolleson is hereby adopted and made a part of this code the same as though the code was specifically set forth in full herein. At least three copies of the code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk. 
(Am. Ord. 369, N.S., passed 5-12-1998; Am. Ord. 403, N.S., passed 5-13-2003; Am. Ord. 439, N.S., passed 5-23-2006; Am. Ord. 448, N.S., passed 11-28-2006; Am. Ord. 458, N.S., passed 7-10-2007; Am. Ord. 464, N.S., passed 12-11-2007; Am. Ord. 581, N.S. , passed May 8, 2018) 
ARTICLE 3-5: - PROCUREMENT 
GENERAL PROVISIONS 

§ 3-5-1 - APPLICABILITY. 
    The purpose of this article is to set forth the rules governing procurement by the city. This article sets forth the general guidelines for the competitive selection of materials, services and construction and applies to expenditure of public monies under any contract, except as provided below. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from complying with the terms and conditions of any grant, gift, bequest or cooperative agreement. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-2 - EXCEPTIONS. 
    The provisions of this article are not applicable to contracts for: 
(A)  Procurement of experts to provide testimony or other professional services relating to a pending or anticipated litigation or judicial proceedings; 
(B)  Appointment, by the Mayor and Council, of the City Engineer and City Attorney; 
(C)  Intergovernmental payments, purchases and agreements, except as set forth in § 3-5-7; 
(D)  Public utility purchases of water, power and related services; and 
(E)  Specialized seminar, training and educational classes. 
(F)  Entertainment act, artistic performers, artists, musicians, actors or other persons or groups providing unique entertainment. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 544, N.S. , passed 10-14-2014) 
§ 3-5-3 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    BUSINESS. Any corporation, partnership, individual, limit liability company, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture or any other private legal entity authorized to do business. 
    CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION. That portion of a bid, proposal, offer, specification or protest that contains information that the person submitting the information believes should be withheld, provided the person submits a written statement advising the Procurement Officer of this fact at the time of the submission and the information shall be so identified wherever it appears. The Procurement Officer shall review the statement and information and shall determine in writing whether the information shall be withheld. The determination statement may be reviewed by the City Attorney and shall be approved by the Procurement Administrator; and if the Procurement Officer determines to disclose the information, the Procurement Officer shall inform the person, in writing, of the determination prior to the disclosure. 
    CONSTRUCTION. All work subject to the requirements of A.R.S. Title 34, including building, improving, altering, repairing, maintaining or demolishing any public building, highway, bridge or other structure. 
    CONTRACT. All types of city agreements, regardless of what they may be called, for the procurement of materials, services or construction. 
    CONTRACTOR. Any person who has a procurement contract with the city. 
    DEPARTMENT. A department of the city. 
    DESIGNEE. A duly authorized representative of a responsible party. 
    INVITATION FOR BID. All documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, which are used for soliciting bids. 
    LATE BID. A bid or proposal response that is received by the city after the due date and time stated in the city's solicitation document or as may be modified by any supplemental addendum; and late bids or proposals shall be rejected and not considered. 
    MATERIALS. All property, including, but not limited to, equipment, supplies, printing, insurance and leases of personal property, but does not include land, an interest in land, or leases of land or buildings. 
    MINOR INFORMALITY. A mistake, excluding judgmental errors, which have negligible material effect on price, quantity, delivery or contractual terms and waiver or correction of the mistake does not prejudice other bidders or offerors. 
    PROCUREMENT. Buying, purchasing, renting, leasing or otherwise acquiring any materials, services or construction. Procurement also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any material, services or construction, including description of requirements, selection and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
    PROCUREMENT ADMINISTRATOR. The Chief Financial Officer or the person designated by the City Manager to act as the Procurement Administrator and to which the City Procurement Officers report. 
    PROCUREMENT OFFICER. Any person, duly authorized to enter into and administer contracts and make written determinations with respect to city contracts; and includes an authorized representative acting within the limits of the Officer's authority. 
    PROFESSIONAL SERVICES. Those services requiring specialized knowledge, education, skill or expertise and where the qualifications of the person(s) rendering the services are of primary importance. PROFESSIONAL SERVICES shall include, but not be limited to, appraisers, land surveyors, attorneys, architects, engineers, psychologists, physicians, health practitioners, auditors, systems and software analysts and professional consultants. 
    REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS. All documents whether attached or incorporated by reference, which are used for soliciting proposals in accordance with procedures prescribed within this article. 
    REQUEST FOR QUALIFICATIONS. A request by the city for detailed information concerning the qualifications of firms to provide professional services. 
    REQUEST FOR QUOTATIONS. The documentation or method used in the process of competing for purchases that are lower than the dollar amount requiring submission of sealed bids or proposals. 
    RESPONSIBLE BIDDER OR OFFEROR. A person who has the capability to perform the contract requirements and the integrity and reliability, which will assure good faith performance. 
    RESPONSIVE BIDDER OR OFFEROR. A person who submits a bid, which conforms in all material respects to the invitation for bids or request for proposals, subject to minor informalities. 
    SERVICES. The furnishing of labor, time or effort by a contractor or subcontractor which does not involve the delivery of a specific end product other than required reports, plans, documents and performance. 
    SOLICITATION. An invitation for bids, a request for proposals, a request for quotations, a request for qualifications or any other invitation or request by which the city invites a person to participate in a procurement. 
    SPECIFICATION. Any description of the physical or functional characteristics, or of the nature of a material, service or construction item. SPECIFICATION may include a description of any requirement for inspecting, testing or preparing a material, service or construction item for delivery. 
    SUBCONTRACTOR. A person who contracts to perform work or render services to a contractor or to another subcontractor as a part of a contract with the city. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 544, N.S. , passed 10-14-2014) 
§ 3-5-4 - AUTHORITY OF THE PROCUREMENT ADMINISTRATOR. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the Procurement Administrator, under the direction of the City Manager, may adopt operational procedures, consistent with this article, governing the procurement and management of all materials and services. The Procurement Administrator shall supervise and administer the procurement of all procurements in general conformity to practices that promote competitive selection of persons to provide materials, services and construction for the city. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-5 - SOLE SOURCE PROCUREMENT. 
    A procurement may be made or contract awarded by the Procurement Administrator without competition when the using department director determines, in writing, after conducting a good faith review of available sources, that there is only one reasonable and practicable source for the required material or service. The using department requesting the sole source procurement shall provide written evidence to support a sole source determination. The Procurement Officer will participate with the using department in the conduct of negotiations, as appropriate, to price, delivery and terms. The Procurement Officer may require the submission of cost or pricing data in connection with a purchase or award under this article. Sole source procurement shall be avoided, except when no reasonable alternative sources exist. A record of sole source procurements shall be maintained as a public record. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-6 - EMERGENCY PROCUREMENT. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, a using department director or designee may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements of materials, services or construction (provided any construction-related procurements comply with A.R.S. Title 34 requirements) when there exists a threat or severe impairment to the quality of public health, welfare or safety, or if a situation exists which makes compliance with established procurement processes impracticable, unnecessary or contrary to the public interest; provided that, the emergency procurements shall be made with the competition as is practicable under the circumstances. An emergency procurement shall be limited to those materials, services or construction necessary to satisfy the emergency need. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be submitted to the procurement office and included in the purchase file. Any emergency procurement exceeding the dollar limit for Council approval shall be scheduled for review at the next available Council meeting. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-7 - COOPERATIVE PROCUREMENT. 
    The city may (1) participate with a state, other political subdivisions of a state and the federal government and other units of government for the procurement of materials or services with cooperative purchasing agreements and (2) directly enter into agreements with vendors who have been awarded contracts with other governmental entities for materials and services, provided the procurement methods of the other party comply with the intent of this procurement code. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 546, N.S. , passed 9-9-2014) 
PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES BY DOLLAR VALUE 

§ 3-5-20 - GENERAL. 
    Any contract not exceeding $50,000 may be made by the City Manager, Procurement Administrator or department directors in accordance with this article. Contract requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to create a small purchase under this section. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-21 - SMALL PURCHASES $10,000 OR LESS. 
    All procurement made pursuant to this § 3-5-21 shall be reported to the Procurement Administrator who shall maintain records showing the cumulative amount of purchases in each fiscal year for each vendor or supplier. In addition to the requirements of this section, the Procurement Administrator may adopt operational procedures for making small purchases. 
(A)  Petty cash purchases: $1.00-$250.00. Petty cash may be used for expendable items only. Such expenditures shall not exceed $250.00 and must be pre-approved by the department director. A request for petty cash reimbursement shall be accompanied by a valid receipt and a description of the public purpose for the item purchased. 
(B)  Open market purchases: Less than $2,500.00. Open market purchases do not require sealed competitive quotations or bids as prices are generally known or quoted to the marketplace; however, the price paid should be fair and reasonable as verified by the department director. Usually, these purchases are routine in nature and requiring sealed competitive quotations or bids generally consumes more time than is worthwhile spending. Citywide purchases under this subsection, from any vendor shall not cumulatively exceed $10,000.00 during the fiscal year. There shall be no fragmentation or division of contracts or purchase orders in order to circumvent the requirements of this subsection. 
(C)  Small purchases: $2,500.00-$10,000.00. The procuring department shall obtain at least three written competitive quotations; however, oral quotations may be acceptable provided the quotations are documented by the department director in writing. A lesser number of quotations may be acceptable, if there are an insufficient number of competitive vendors, as determined by the department director. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Procurement Administrator may require departments to obtain sealed competitive quotations, bids or proposals. Citywide purchases under this subsection, from any vendor shall not cumulatively exceed $10,000.00 during the fiscal year. There shall be no fragmentation or division of contracts or purchase orders in order to circumvent the requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 544, N.S. , passed 10-14-2014) 
§ 3-5-22 - SMALL PURCHASES OVER $10,000 AND NOT MORE THAN $50,000. 
    The City Manager and the Procurement Administrator are each authorized to approve and execute purchases and contracts not exceeding $50,000.00. For small purchases over $10,000.00, but less than $50,000.00, a request for quotations shall be used and written quotations from no less than three businesses shall be obtained. The City Manager or Procurement Administrator may award a contract to the responsible bidder submitting the quotation that is most advantageous to the city and conforms in all material respects to the solicitation. The names of the businesses submitting quotations, and the date and amount of each quotation, shall be recorded and maintained as a public record. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 539, N.S. , passed 5-13-2014) 
§ 3-5-23 - PROCUREMENTS OVER $50,000. 
    Procurements of materials and services in excess of $50,000 shall be procured by formal, written solicitation as set forth in this article and submitted to the City Council for approval. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-24 - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS. 
    Construction contracts shall be procured as set forth in §§ 3-5-105 et seq. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
COMPETITIVE SEALED BIDDING 

§ 3-5-40 - CONDITIONS FOR USE. 
    All contracts of the city shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding except as otherwise provided in §§ 3-5-20 through 3-5-22. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000; Am. Ord. 544, N.S. , passed 10-14-2014) 
§ 3-5-41 - INVITATION FOR BIDS. 
    An invitation for bids shall be issued and shall include specifications and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-42 - PUBLIC NOTICE. 
    The Procurement Office shall develop and maintain a method for providing adequate notice of public bid solicitations, which shall identify the place, date and time of bid opening. Notice of the bid solicitation shall be posted for public inspection and a copy of the bid solicitation shall be available for public inspection review in the procurement office. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-43 - LATE BIDS. 
    A bid is late if it is received at the location designated in the invitation for bids after the time and date set for bid opening. A late bid shall be rejected and not considered, regardless of the reason for lateness, including circumstances beyond the control of the bidder. A late bid shall not be opened, except if necessary for identification purposes. If delivered in person, a late bid shall be rejected and returned to the bidder. If not delivered in person, a late bid shall be filed unopened within the procurement office and a late bid notice shall be mailed or electronically sent to the late bidder. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-44 - BID OPENING. 
    Bids shall be opened publicly in the presence of at least one witness at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids. The amount of each bid, and any other relevant information as the Procurement Administrator deems appropriate, together with the name of each bidder, shall be recorded. This record shall be open to public inspection. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-45 - BID ACCEPTANCE AND BID EVALUATION. 
    Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or correction, except as authorized in this article. Minor informalities may be waived or corrected in the discretion of the city. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitations for bids. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-46 - CORRECTION OR WITHDRAWAL OF BIDS; CANCELLATION OF AWARDS. 
    Correction or withdrawal of inadvertently erroneous bids before or after bid opening, or cancellation of awards or contracts based on bid mistakes, may be permitted where appropriate. Mistakes discovered before bid opening may be modified or withdrawn by written notice received in the procurement office prior to the time set for bid opening. After bid opening, corrections in bids shall be permitted only to the extent that the bidder can show by clear and convincing evidence that a mistake of a non-judgmental character was made, the nature of the mistake, and the bid price actually intended. After bid opening, no changes in bid prices or other provisions of bids prejudicial to the interest of the city or fair competition shall be permitted. All decisions to permit the correction or withdrawal of bids, or to cancel awards or contracts based on bid mistakes, shall be supported by a written determination approved by the Procurement Administrator. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-47 - CONTRACT AWARD. 
(A)  If the city, in its sole discretion, decides to award a contract, the contract shall be awarded by appropriate written notice to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder whose bid conforms in all material respects to requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids. If the bidder designates a portion of its proposal as confidential information, the bidder shall isolate and identify, in writing, the confidential portions. 
(B)  A contract may not be awarded to a bidder submitting a higher quality item than that designated in the invitation for bid unless the bidder is also the lowest bidder. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-48 - IDENTICAL BIDS. 
    If there are two or more low responsive bids from responsible bidders that are identical in price and that meet all the requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids, award may be made by a coin toss. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
MULTI-STEP SEALED BIDDING 

§ 3-5-60 - GENERAL. 
    When it is considered impractical or not advantageous to initially prepare a specification to support an award based on price, an invitation for bids or request for qualifications may be issued requesting the submission of unpriced offers to be followed by an invitation for bids or request for qualifications limited to those bidders whose offers have been determined to be technically acceptable under the criteria set forth in the first step of the solicitation. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
§ 3-5-61 - INITIATION OF NEXT STEP. 
    The Procurement Officer may initiate the next step of the procedure if, in the Procurement Officer's opinion, there are sufficient acceptable unpriced offers to assure effective price competition in the second step without technical discussions. If the Procurement Officer finds that such is not the case, the Procurement Officer shall issue an amendment to the invitation for bids or engage in technical discussions. 
(Ord. 393, N.S., passed 7-11-2000) 
COMPETITIVE SEALED PROPOSALS 

§ 3-5-75 - REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.
