"Carrying a firearm in this developed or improved area is limited to persons who possess a permit issued pursuant to A.R.S. § 13-3112." 
(C)  Definition of "developed or improved area." 
(1)  For the purposes of this section, DEVELOPED OR IMPROVED AREA means an area of property developed for public recreation or family activity, including picnic areas, concessions, playgrounds, amphitheaters, racquet courts, swimming areas, golf courses, zoos, horseback riding facilities and boat landing and docking facilities. 
(2)  DEVELOPED OR IMPROVED AREA does not include campgrounds, trails, paths or roadways except trails, paths and roadways directly associated with and adjacent to designated developed or improved areas. 
(D)  Notice. Any notice that is required by this section shall be conspicuously posted at all public entrances and at intervals of one-fourth mile or less where the park, preserve or developed or improved area has an open perimeter. 
(E)  Exceptions. Any limitation imposed pursuant to this section shall not apply to a person: 
(1)  Engaged in a permitted firearms or hunter safety course conducted in a park by a certified hunter safety instructor or certified firearms safety instructor; 
(2)  At a properly supervised range, as defined in A.R.S. § 13-3107, and amendments thereto, at a permitted shooting event, at a permitted firearms show or in a permitted hunting area; 
(3)  Legally transporting, carrying, storing or possessing a firearm in a vehicle; 
(4)  Going directly to or from an area where the person is lawfully engaged in hunting, marksmanship practice or recreational shooting; 
(5)  Traversing a trail head area in order to gain access to areas where the possession of firearms is not limited; and/or 
(6)  Using trails, paths or roadways to go directly to or from an area where the possession of firearms is not limited and where no reasonable alternate means of access is available. 
§ 7-4-4 - DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS IN PARKS AND PRESERVES. 
    It is unlawful for any person to discharge a firearm in a city park or preserve except: 
(A)  As allowed pursuant to A.R.S. Title 13, Chapter 4, and amendments thereto; 
(B)  On a properly supervised range, as defined in A.R.S. § 13-3107 and amendments thereto; 
(C)  In an area recommended as a hunting area by the Arizona Game and Fish Department and approved and posted as required by Chief of Police. Any area may be closed when deemed unsafe by the Chief of Police or the Director of the Arizona Game and Fish Department; 
(D)  To control nuisance wildlife by permit from the Arizona Game and Fish Department or the United States Fish and Wildlife Service; 
(E)  By special permit of the Chief of Police; 
(F)  As required by an animal control enforcement agent in performing duties specified in Chapter 9 of this code; and 
(G)  In self-defense or defense of another person against an animal attack if a reasonable person would believe that deadly physical force against the animal is immediately necessary and reasonable under the circumstances to protect oneself or the other person. 
§ 7-4-5 - VIOLATIONS. 
    Violations of any provision of this article are a class 2 misdemeanor subject to the penalties prescribed in § 1-1-8 of this code. 
CHAPTER 8: - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
ARTICLE 8-1: - REFUSE COLLECTION; GARBAGE AND TRASH REMOVAL 
IN GENERAL 

§ 8-1-1 - PURPOSE AND SCOPE. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(A)  Protect the health and safety of the citizens of the city; 
(B)  Protect the environment by establishing minimum standards for the safe and sanitary collection, storage, treatment, transportation, processing and disposal of refuse and recyclables generated within the city; and 
(C)  Establish fees for the city's refuse, green waste and recycling program, inspection, collection and disposal services to recover the city's costs to provide the services. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-2 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    ALLEY. A public passageway affording a secondary means of access to abutting property for utility and emergency vehicles. 
    ANIMAL WASTE. All waste from household pets, stables, kennels, pet pens, chicken coops, veterinary establishments and other waste of a similar nature. 
    ASHES. All residue from the burning of any combustible material, specifically excluding ashes from medical waste or hazardous waste. 
    AUTOMATED COLLECTION PROGRAM. The city's automated refuse collection program, automated recycling program and/or automated green waste collection program. 
    AUTOMOTIVE PARTS. Any part or combination of parts of any kind of motor vehicle, including but not limited to tires, batteries, seats, engines, fuel tanks, doors, auto glass and upholstery. 
    AUTHORIZED REFUSE COLLECTOR. The city or any contractor operating within the city under a valid refuse service permit. 
    BUILDING MATERIALS. All garbage, trash, debris, rubble, soil and excess materials from any construction, demolition, repair or remodeling operations, whether on private, public, residential or commercial premises, whether to the primary structure or any other structure, and whether produced by the work or at the direction of the property owner, contractor, subcontractor, agent, or any other party. 
    BULK TRASH. Residential refuse and yard waste produced by city residents on or in their residential premises within the city, that has been properly prepared for collection by the city's residential bulk trash collection program, if any. BULK TRASH shall specifically exclude building materials, commercial refuse, contaminated material, hazardous material, household food waste, cement/concrete, dirt or landscape material and medical waste. 
    BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENT. Any public or private place, building or enterprise utilized for the conduct of business or industry, including non-profit organizations, schools and multiple dwelling units and specifically excluding single family residential units and duplexes. 
    CHAPTER. Article 8-1 of the Tolleson City Code, as amended. 
    COMMERCIAL REFUSE. Any refuse produced by the operation of or as a byproduct of any business, without regard to whether the business is licensed in the city, or whether the business activity is conducted in a public business, private residence, within the city, or any other location. 
    CONTAMINATED MATERIALS. Any materials which, when prepared for one of the acceptable forms of collection described in this chapter, contain materials which are not acceptable under that particular form of collection. 
    CONTRACTOR. Any person or entity other than the city, who removes, collects, hauls, or transports within the city any refuse of another person or entity, including recyclable materials, hazardous materials, or medical waste, or any other types of waste, for disposal, salvage, recycling or any other purpose. 
    DIRECTOR. The Director of the Field Operations Department or the Director's authorized designee, as applicable. 
    GARBAGE. All putrescible materials, except sewage and body wastes, including all organic wastes that have been prepared for or intended to be used as food or have resulted from the preparation of food, including all substances from all public and private establishments and residences. 
    GREEN WASTE. Yard waste and other refuse produced as the result of typical residential or commercial yard installation and maintenance, including all brush, tree trimmings, grass, leaves or similar landscaping or plant material of an organic nature, but specifically excluding lumber, rigid pipe, dirt, rock, brick, cement and concrete. 
    HAZARDOUS MATERIAL. Any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate agency of the state to be hazardous, as that term is defined by or pursuant to federal or state law. HAZARDOUS MATERIAL includes but is not limited to medical wastes, herbicides, pesticides, explosives, and radioactive, toxic, flammable or corrosive materials. 
    LITTER. All garbage, trash and debris not properly prepared for collection under this code. 
    MEDICAL WASTE. Materials defined as medical waste by A.R.S. § 49-701. 
    MULTIPLE DWELLING UNITS. Properties with three or more dwelling units on one parcel of property, specifically excluding duplexes, and specifically including triplexes, apartments, condominiums, town homes, mobile home parks, trailer parks, rooming houses and boarding houses. 
    PRIVATE PREMISES. Any land and/or structure owned by any person(s) other than the United States, a state, a county, the city, or any political subdivision of the United States. 
    PUBLIC PLACE. Any and all public streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    PUTRESCIBLE MATERIALS. Solid waste which is capable of being decomposed by microorganisms with sufficient rapidity as to cause nuisances from odors or gases and capable of providing food for or attracting birds, insects, snakes, rodents or animals capable of transferring a diseased bacterium or virus from one organism to another. 
    RECYCLABLE MATERIALS. Refuse that has been set aside or separated from other refuse for the purpose of being collected and recycled, and which is, at the Director's discretion, acceptable recyclable material. ACCEPTABLE RECYCLABLE MATERIAL may include the following materials if clean and dry: paper, cardboard, chipboard, plastic containers made from polyethylene terephthalate ("PETE") or high density polyethylene ("HDPE"), steel food cans, aluminum cans, disposable aluminum bake ware and aluminum foil. ACCEPTABLE RECYCLABLE MATERIAL shall specifically exclude: 
(1)  Garbage, hazardous materials and medical waste; 
(2)  Plastic bags, film or sheeting; 
(3)  Any plastic not made from PETE or HDPE; 
(4)  Any organic material other than acceptable paper, newsprint, cardboard and chipboard; 
(5)  Contaminated materials; 
(6)  Any foam products; 
(7)  Any type of automotive parts; and 
(8)  Any other trash which, at the Director's discretion, is deemed unacceptable. 
    RECYCLING CONTAINER. A container owned by the city for use as part of the city's recycling program, if any. 
    REFUSE. Garbage and trash acceptable for collection and placed in city-issued containers under the provisions of this code, including recyclable materials. 
    REFUSE CONTAINER. A container owned by the city and made available for use as part of the city's automated refuse collection program. 
    REFUSE SERVICE PERMIT. A permit issued to a contractor under the provisions of this code. 
    RESIDENTIAL REFUSE. Household garbage and trash produced by city residents on or in their residential premises within the city, specifically excluding: 
(1)  Building materials, whether from construction, demolition, repair or remodeling, whether on or off the residential premises, and whether to the primary residential structure or any other structures; 
(2)  Commercial refuse, whether produced at the residence or at any other location; 
(3)  Hazardous materials; 
(4)  Medical waste; 
(5)  Car parts or metal waste; and 
(6)  Landscape waste such as but not limited to soil, rocks, cement or concrete. 
    SOLID WASTE INSPECTOR. Any police officer, code enforcement officer, or other city employee with written authorization from the Director to inspect public and private properties, to issue citations and to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
    TRASH. All nonputrescible solid waste, including both combustible and noncombustible solid waste material, excluding ashes, hazardous waste and medical waste. 
    WHITE GOODS. Appliances acceptable for collection under the city's white goods collection program, if any. WHITE GOODS shall include ovens, stoves, washers, dryers and water heaters, and shall specifically exclude smaller household appliances such as refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners and electronic equipment. 
    YARDWASTE. Refuse produced as the result of typical residential or commercial yard installation and maintenance, including grass, brush and tree trimmings, but specifically excluding lumber, rigid pipe, dirt, rock, brick, cement and concrete. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-3 - COLLECTION AGENCY. 
    The city, or other authorized refuse collector, shall collect, remove, salvage, transport and dispose of all refuse within the city. 
§ 8-1-4 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
    The Director shall make the schedules, rules and regulations concerning the collection, disposal and hauling of refuse, recyclable materials and other wastes by any party; or relating to the operation of any transfer station, disposal site, recycling or waste reduction program or other similar activities or facilities. Copies of the rules and regulations shall be filed with the office of the City Clerk and in the office of the Director. The rules and regulations shall be made available to the public upon request. 
§ 8-1-5 - USE OF SERVICE REQUIRED. 
    No person or business establishment within the city shall be permitted to avoid or refuse to accept refuse collection service, and the failure of any party to accept the service shall not exempt that party from the payment of the charges for the service. 
(A)  Substitution of service. In the event that the Director determines that the city is unable to reasonably and safely provide collection services to certain residents, establishments or areas, the Director may substitute another means of collection or require the person to seek service from another source. Any person providing the service shall comply with all applicable provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  Producers conditionally exempt. This chapter shall not prohibit the actual producers of refuse, or the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated, from personally salvaging, collecting, conveying and disposing of the refuse without a permit, provided the producers or owners comply with the provisions of this chapter and with any governing law or ordinance. 
(C)  Contractors conditionally exempt. Every person engaging in the business of contracting, except refuse collection, is authorized to personally collect, remove and appropriately dispose of wastes incidental to the contracting business without a permit. 
§ 8-1-6 - TYPES OF SERVICE. 
(A)  Single family residences. The city shall provide weekly automated residential refuse, residential green waste and residential recyclable materials collection services to single-family residences. Each residence receiving service under this division shall be provided containers for individual use and curbside collection. Additionally, the residents may request additional collections and/or containers, subject to the discretion of the Director. Any bulk trash services shall be provided as determined by the Director. 
(B)  Duplexes. The city shall provide weekly automated residential refuse, residential green waste and residential recyclable materials collection services to duplex residences. Each residence receiving automated collection services under this division shall be considered a single unit for the purposes of this chapter, and shall be provided containers for individual use and curbside collection. Any bulk trash services shall be provided as determined by the Director. 
(C)  Multiple dwelling units. An authorized refuse collector shall provide commercial refuse collection service to multiple dwelling units with three or more dwelling units on one parcel of property, unless otherwise permitted by the Director. 
(D)  Business establishments. An authorized refuse collector shall provide commercial refuse collection service to business establishments as required by state, county and city regulations. If the business establishment is serviced by an authorized refuse collector other than the city, the service schedule shall be set by the contractor and customer subject to approval by the Director. 
(E)  Miscellaneous services. The city may provide additional or variant services, including, but not limited to residential bulk trash and white goods collection, for a reasonable fee, as shall be determined by the Director. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-7 - COLLECTION HOURS. 
    The hours of refuse collection shall be as designated by the Director. 
§ 8-1-8 - FEES. 
    Fees for city's automated refuse, green waste and recyclable materials collection services shall be established by the City Council as part of the annual budget process or as otherwise adopted by City Council resolution. 
(A)  Collection. Fees for city's automated refuse, green waste and recyclable materials collection services shall be collected monthly and charged against the occupant or owner of each premises within the city after the time that the occupant or owner requests collection service from the city. The city shall be authorized to collect fees and fines in the following manner. 
(1)  Water service provided by city. On all premises where water service is provided by the city, fees for the city's automated refuse, green waste and recyclable materials collection services and associated fines shall be added to and collected as a part of the city water bill, and the sum shall become delinquent upon the same date as the water bill. If the balance is not paid when due, the water service to the premises may be shut off and the service shall not be restored without payment in full. 
(2)  Water service not provided by city. On all premises where water service is not provided by the city, fees for the city's automated refuse, green waste and recyclable materials collection services and associated fines shall be paid to the City Water Department in the manner provided for the payment of water bills. 
(B)  Penalty for late payment. A delinquent bill shall be subject to a penalty equal to one and one- half percent per month on any outstanding unpaid balance. 
(C)  Lien for unpaid charges. Any charges imposed by the city pursuant to this article, if not paid by the date on which they are due, shall constitute a lien on the property, lot or tract of land to which service was rendered. 
(1)  Notice of lien. Upon delinquency, the city shall give notice to the user and the owner, if known, of the property, which notice shall indicate that the city will record a lien against the subject property unless all past due charges are paid. 
(2)  Costs added; lien recorded. If delinquent charges are not paid within 30 days of notice, the city shall record in the office of the Maricopa County Recorder a notice and claim of lien. The city shall then promptly send by certified mail, a copy to the user, and the owner if known at their last known mailing address. The notice and claim of lien shall contain the following: 
(a)  A description of the property sufficient for identification; 
(b)  The name of the utility user and recorded owner of the property if known; and 
(c)  The amount owed. At the time as the lien is recorded, the cost of preparing, processing and releasing the lien shall be added to the amount then due. 
(3)  Effect of lien. From and after the date of its recording in the office of the County Recorder, the lien shall attach to the property until paid. A sale of the property to satisfy the lien shall be made upon judgment of foreclosure and order of sale. The city shall have the right to bring an action to enforce the lien in the Superior Court at any time after its recording, but failure to enforce the lien by the action shall not affect its validity. The recorded notice and claim of lien shall be prima facie evidence of the truth of all matters recited therein and the regularity of all proceedings prior to the recording thereof. 
(4)  Prior recording no bar to lien. A prior recording for the purposes provided in this section shall not be a bar to the subsequent recording of a lien for the purposes, and any number of the liens on the same property may be enforced and in the same action. 
(5)  No lien if account in tenant's name. Notwithstanding any provision hereof to the contrary, no lien shall be recorded against any single-family residence which is occupied by a tenant in whose name the account has been established. 
(D)  Collection by civil suit. Delinquent charges may also be collected by a civil suit instituted at the request of the City Manager at any time after the charges become delinquent, notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary. The remedies provided by this article shall be cumulative and supplemental to other remedies provided under this chapter. 
(Am. Ord. 500 N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-9 - CONTAINERS. 
    All materials prepared for collection shall be stored in a city-approved container until removed by the city or an authorized refuse collector, unless those materials are properly prepared for the city's bulk trash collection service, if any. 
(A)  City ownership of city-provided containers. The city may furnish refuse and recyclable containers for the accumulation, storage and collection of refuse. All the containers are owned by the city, and the city may remove or replace the container without notice to the user. 
(B)  Users responsible for maintenance and proper use. Any user of a city-provided container shall be required to use and maintain the container as follows: 
(1)  Cleaning. The user shall be responsible for keeping the container reasonably clean. This means that the user shall maintain the container free of intense odors, evidence of flies in any stage of development, and any other nuisance or threat to public health. 
(2)  Reporting damage or loss. The user shall be responsible for reporting any container damage or loss to the city. 
(3)  Proper and safe use. The user shall not damage the container intentionally, or use the container for any purpose other than those specified in this code. The user shall not use the container in any manner which is unsafe, or which a reasonably prudent person would believe is unsafe. 
(4)  Should a resident or user move then the container is to remain with the property. At no time shall the container be removed if the resident/user moves. 
(C)  Unauthorized use. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, or cause to be deposited, any refuse in any container which that person is not entitled to use as a property owner, resident or tenant. 
COLLECTION 

§ 8-1-20 - ACCEPTABLE MATERIALS. 
    Only properly prepared materials shall be acceptable for collection under this chapter. 
§ 8-1-21 - UNACCEPTABLE MATERIALS. 
    Unacceptable materials will not be collected under this article, may subject the producer to a fine under this chapter, and may be removed by the city at the producer's expense as set forth in this chapter. 
(A)  Prohibited materials. The following materials are unacceptable for collection under any collection program described in this chapter: 
(1)  Improperly prepared materials. No material which would be acceptable if properly prepared for collection shall be acceptable if not properly prepared for collection. Improperly prepared for collection shall include otherwise acceptable materials which are set out for collection at the wrong time or in the wrong place. 
(2)  Tires and other automotive parts. No tires or other auto parts shall be acceptable. Automotive parts includes any part or combination of parts of any kind of motor vehicle, including but not limited to tires, batteries, seats, engines, fuel tanks, doors, auto glass and upholstery. 
(3)  Dirt, rock, masonry, and the like. No waste soil, sod, dirt, rocks, gravel, cement, concrete, masonry blocks, bricks, tile or any other similar materials shall be acceptable. 
(4)  Gardening and landscape business waste. No landscapers, tree trimmers, lawn maintenance businesses or similar operators may dispose of yardwaste or any other refuse in refuse containers unless the waste is generated solely from the grounds of the property and the property owner or manager has approved the disposal. 
(5)  Fire hazards. No hot ashes, hot cinders, burning matter, loose sawdust, flammable or volatile liquids, or any other material which presents a fire hazard shall be acceptable. 
(6)  Hazardous material. Hazardous material such as but not limited to fluorescent bulbs. 
(7)  Medical waste. Medical waste. 
(8)  Contaminated materials. Contaminated material. 
(9)  Building material. Building materials such as but not limited to roofing material. 
(10)  Paint, varnish and the like. Paint, varnish or any other liquid item. 
(B)  Special prohibitions for residential collections. Commercial refuse shall be unacceptable for collection under any of the city's residential collection programs. Residences receiving collection under any of the city's collection programs are limited to one inversion of the container being serviced, per collection day. 
§ 8-1-22 - AUTOMATED RESIDENTIAL REFUSE COLLECTION. 
(A)  Generally. All materials prepared for the city's automated residential refuse collection program shall be prepared for collection and disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(B)  Proper preparation for collection. All residential refuse prepared for collection by the city's automated residential refuse collection program shall be prepared for collection as follows. 
(1)  Placement. Containers set out for collection must be placed in the street in front of the house to which they are assigned, with the wheels adjacent to the curb of the sidewalk, and the lid opening toward the street. Where there is no sidewalk, the container must be placed at the edge of the street, within two feet of the pavement or improved road, as applicable. Containers will not be collected from private property, or when placed within ten feet of a vehicle, mailbox or other obstruction to safely perform collection as determined by the Director. At no time may containers be left on the sidewalk. Containers must also be pulled back onto property the same day that collection occurs. 
(2)  Time. Containers must be placed in the proper location for collection by 5:00 a.m. on the designated collection day. Containers set out late will not be serviced. Containers may be set out after 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding collection and must be removed from the collection location by sunset on the same day of collection. 
(3)  Lid must be closed. The lids of containers set out for residential refuse collection must be entirely closed. 
(4)  Refuse must be bagged. All refuse prepared for residential refuse collection must be bagged and securely tied to exclude flies and other pests. Spillage during collection of unbagged refuse will be the responsibility of the resident. 
(5)  Weight limit. The contents of the container must weigh no more than 250 pounds. 
(6)  Container contents. The contents of the container must be arranged so that they fall out easily when inverted by authorized collection vehicles. The city shall not be required to remove any materials which remain in the container after one inversion. 
(7)  One dump. Only one dump per customer for each of the scheduled collections. 
§ 8-1-23 - AUTOMATED RESIDENTIAL GREEN WASTE COLLECTION. 
(A)  Generally . All materials prepared for the city's automated residential green waste collection program ("Green Collection") shall be prepared for collection and disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(B)  Proper preparation for collection. All residential green waste prepared for collection by the city's automated residential green waste collection program shall be prepared for collection as follows. 
(1)  Placement . Containers set out for automated residential green waste collection service must be placed in the street in front of the house to which they are assigned, with the wheels adjacent to the curb of the sidewalk, and the lid opening toward the street. Where there is no sidewalk, the container must be placed at the edge of the street, within two feet of the pavement or improved road, as applicable. Containers will not be collected from private property, or when placed within ten feet of a vehicle, mailbox or other obstruction to safely perform collection as determined by the Director. At no time may containers be left on the sidewalk. Containers must also be pulled back onto property the same day that collection occurs. 
(2)  Time . Containers must be placed in the proper location for collection by 5:00 a.m. on the designated collection day. Containers set out late will not be serviced. Containers may be set out after 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding collection and must be removed from the collection location by sunset on the same day of collection. 
(3)  Lid must be closed . The lids of containers set out for automated residential green waste collection must be entirely closed. 
(4)  Green waste must be bagged. All green waste prepared for automated residential green waste collection, except for tree limbs and brush longer than one foot in length, must be bagged and securely tied to exclude flies and other pests. Spillage during collection of unbagged green waste will be the responsibility of the resident. 
(5)  Weight limit . The contents of the container must weigh no more than 250 pounds. 
(6)  Container contents . The contents of the container must be arranged so that they fall out easily when inverted by authorized collection vehicles. The city shall not be required to remove any materials which remain in the container after one inversion. 
(7)  One dump. Only one dump per customer for each of the scheduled collections. 
(Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-24 - AUTOMATED RESIDENTIAL RECYCLING COLLECTION. 
(A)  Generally. All materials prepared for the city's automated residential recycling collection program shall be prepared for collection and disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(B)  Proper preparation for collection. All residential recyclable materials prepared for collection by the city's automated residential recycling collection program shall be prepared for collection or disposal as follows: 
(1)  Placement. Containers set out for collection under this section must be placed in the same location and manner as described for the placement of containers set out for automated residential refuse collection. 
(2)  Time. Containers must be placed in the proper location for collection by 5:00 a.m. on the designated collection day. Containers set out late will not be serviced. Containers may be set out after 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding collection and must be removed from the collection location by sunset on the same day of collection. 
(3)  Lid must be closed. The lids of containers set out for residential recycling collection must be entirely closed. 
(4)  Recyclable materials must not be bagged. Recyclable materials must not be bagged and must be placed in the container in a manner that they separate under the normal operating procedures of the applicable materials recovery facility. 
(5)  Weight limit. The contents of the container must weigh no more than 250 pounds. 
(6)  Free from obstructions. The contents of the container must be arranged so that they fall out easily when inverted by authorized collection vehicles. The city shall not be required to remove any materials which remain in the container after inversion for collection. Cardboard must be cut down in a manner where it allows for material to flow out of the container. 
(7)  No contamination. Only recyclable materials shall be collected by the city's residential recycling collection program. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-25 - RESIDENTIAL BULK TRASH COLLECTION. 
(A)  Generally. All materials prepared for the city's residential bulk trash collection program, if a program exists, shall be prepared for collection and disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(B)  Proper preparation for collection. All residential bulk trash materials prepared for collection by the city's residential bulk trash collection program shall be prepared for collection or disposal as follows. 
(1)  Placement. Materials set out for bulk trash collection must be placed in the street in front of the producer's property. At no time may bulk trash be left on the sidewalk, if any. Other than as described in this section, materials will not be collected from private property, or when placed within ten feet of a vehicle, mailbox or other obstruction to safe collection as determined by the Director. 
(2)  Time. Materials set out for collection under this section must be placed in the proper location for collection no later than 5:00 a.m. on the first day of the designated collection period. Materials set out late will not be collected. Materials may be set out no more than 48 hours before the first day of the designated collection period. 
(3)  Frequency. Frequency of shall be determined by Council, City Manager or Director. Once city staff has completed a particular area they will not return until the next scheduled collection period for that area. 
(4)  White goods. If white goods collection service is provided by the city, the doors on the goods must be removed or secured. White goods which may contain refrigerant, such as refrigerators and air conditioners, shall not be acceptable for collection under this section. Disposal is the responsibility of the resident. 
(5)  Yardwaste. Yardwaste must be properly prepared for collection as follows: 
(a)  Grass, leaves and the like. Any small, light yardwaste such as grass and leaves must be secured in bags or boxes in a manner so as to prevent litter. 
(b)  Brush, limbs, trunks and the like. Long items, such as tree limbs, trunks and the like, must be free of metal such as stakes, staples and wire, and must be stacked roughly parallel to the street. Other than palm fronds, each piece must be no more than four feet in length, no more than six inches in diameter, and weigh no more than 50 pounds. 
(c)  Palm fronds. Palm fronds may exceed four feet in length, and must be neatly stacked, roughly parallel to the street. 
(d)  Cactus and the like. Cactus and other thorned plants must be set out for collection in cardboard boxes or other sturdy containers which are sufficiently strong to protect the public and work crews from injury. 
(6)  Weight and volume limits. Any bag, box or other container set out for collection under this section, together with its contents, shall weigh no more than 50 pounds and have a volume of no more than 20 gallons. The volume of all materials set out for collection from a residence for any one collection period shall not exceed three cubic yards, excluding acceptable white goods. At the Director's discretion, the city may remove materials in excess of the limits described in this section. 
(7)  Free from hidden hazards. Any materials set out for collection must be clearly visible and identifiable. No materials shall be commingled in a way that presents a safety hazard to the public or work crews. Any glass must be set out for collection in cardboard boxes or other sturdy containers which are sufficiently strong to protect the public and work crews from injury. 
(8)  Box or container will be removed. Any box or container placed out for collection under this section will be removed as part of the uncontained material. Any containers of glass, cactus or other sharp material must not be covered by any other material. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-26 - COMMERCIAL REFUSE COLLECTION SERVICE. 
(A)  Generally. All commercial refuse prepared for commercial refuse collection shall be prepared in accordance with this section. This section shall apply to all business establishments serviced within the City of Tolleson, whether serviced by the city or any other authorized refuse collector. Business establishments shall be required to contract with an authorized refuse collector to dispose of all trash produced onsite. 
(B)  Proper preparation for collection. All commercial refuse shall be prepared for collection or disposal as follows. 
(1)  Placement. Containers set out for collection in a manner which poses a safety hazard is prohibited and the containers shall not be serviced. The placement of commercial refuse containers shall not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic and shall be reachable by the automated collection vehicles without danger to persons or property. If the commercial refuse is to be collected by the city, the placement of commercial refuse containers shall be at a location designated by the Director or authorized designee. 
(2)  Time. Commercial refuse bins must be accessible from the proper location for collection by 5:00 a.m. on the designated collection day(s). 
(3)  Lid(s) must be closed. The lids of containers set out for commercial refuse collection must be entirely closed. Any spillage shall be the responsibility of the owner/manager to clean. 
(4)  Garbage and litter hazards must be bagged. All refuse prepared for commercial refuse collection must be bagged and securely tied to exclude flies and pests. 
(5)  Weight limit. If the business establishment is serviced by the city, the container, together with its contents, must weigh no more than 400 pounds per container. 
(6)  Container contents. The contents of the container must be arranged so that they fall out easily. Items that are found in the container that are on the listed in the unacceptable materials list will result in no service until the time as the business owner/manager returns the container to acceptable compliance. 
(Am. Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
§ 8-1-27 - COMMERCIAL REFUSE COLLECTION PERMIT. 
    Any contractor, before providing any type of commercial refuse collection service within the city, shall first obtain a valid business license and refuse collection permit from the city. The permits must be renewed annually. 
(A)  Obtaining a refuse collection permit. Permits for collection of refuse or recycling from business establishments within the city may be issued by the city under the following conditions. 
(1)  Application. The contractor must submit a properly completed application for commercial refuse collection permit to the city. The contractor's application shall include the name, business address and telephone numbers of all owners, partners, general managers and the principal officer, as well as emergency telephone numbers, business references and any other information as deemed necessary. The application shall identify each vehicle(s) to be licensed for operation under the permit, and be amended as necessary any time the contractor's vehicle use changes. 
(2)  Approval of equipment and qualifications. The contractor is required to supply evidence satisfactory to the Director that the contractor possesses the necessary equipment and qualifications to collect, transport and dispose of commercial refuse or any other wastes in a manner satisfactory to the Director and in conformity with all applicable federal, state, county and city laws, rules and regulations. 
(3)  Vehicle requirements. All vehicles used for refuse collection, hauling or transporting within the city must be inspected at the time of initial permit application, and, at the time of each permit renewal, be approved by the city and meet the following requirements. 
(a)  All vehicles must be in good condition and may be subject to Maricopa County Vector Control inspections just as city refuse vehicles are required. 
(b)  Vehicles shall be maintained and operated in a clean and neat manner so as to prevent refuse from spilling, leaking and blowing from the vehicle. 
(c)  The outside of each vehicle must be clearly identified by a number unique to the vehicle in letters no smaller than six inches in height and the name and telephone number of the contractor operating the vehicle. 
(d)  Any open-top roll-off container must have a cover which prevents refuse or contents from spilling or flowing onto the roadway. 
(e)  When driven and operated by one person, front loading refuse packers used in the collection, transportation, disposal of refuse shall be equipped with an approved backup protection device. Audible backup alarms do not meet this requirement. 
(f)  No vehicle shall be painted or identified in a manner which may lead an ordinarily observant person to confuse the equipment with the city's sanitation division. 
(4)  Permit surety. Before issuing a permit under the provisions of this section, the city shall require the contractor, as a condition to the issuance of the permit, to post a cash performance surety in the amount of $5,000. This surety shall be conditioned upon the payment of any charges incurred by the city in correcting any failure by the contractor to perform in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. At the time that the contractor ceases to collect refuse or recyclables within the city, the contractor shall request a refund of the surety and, if appropriate pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the full amount of $5,000 will be refunded. 
(5)  Vehicle fee. Before issuing a permit under this section, the contractor shall pay a nonrefundable fee of $1,000 per vehicle used in the collection of refuse within the City of Tolleson. The vehicle fee is thereafter due annually. 
(6)  Certificate of insurance. 
(a)  The contractor obtains and maintains in full force and effect public liability and property damage insurance in the sum of: 
1.  One million dollars for personal injury or death to any one person; 
2.  One million dollars for personal injuries or death sustained by all persons in any one accident; and 
3.  Five hundred thousand dollars for property damage; arising from any single occurrence, arising from any error, omission or act, negligent or intentional, by the contractor or its employees or agents in collection, hauling and/or disposal activities within the city. 
(b)  The city shall be named as an additional insured. A certificate of insurance shall be furnished to the city at the time of permit application, and at any time when so requested by the city. The form and coverage shall be subject to city approval. 
(B)  Operations under permit. At all times, contractors operating under a commercial refuse collection permit shall display the permit through the front windshield of each vehicle providing service under the permit. 
(1)  Permit not transferable. Permits issued pursuant to this chapter shall not be transferable. Permits shall be issued for one year commencing July 1 and ending June 30. Applications for renewal shall be made at least 60 days prior to expiration of current permit. Applicable fees may be prorated monthly on permits issued during the fiscal year. 
(2)  Allowances for charities. The vehicle fees, and/or surety requirements of this section may be waived by the Director for any charitable or philanthropic organization engaged in salvaging or recycling, provided that no part of the revenue from the operation insures to the personal benefit of any person. Charities shall be required to meet all other requirements of this section. 
(C)  Cause for revocation and suspension. The city may revoke or suspend a commercial refuse collection permit and claim the permit surety as follows. 
(1)  Failure to comply with permit requirements. The city may suspend or revoke a contractor's permit at any time the contractor is not in compliance with every requirement of permit approval under this chapter. 
(2)  Failure to give proper notice. The city may suspend a contractor's permit at any time the contractor fails to give notice of intent to commence or discontinue service, according to this division. Except in an emergency or other situation approved by the Director, the contractor shall provide the city with written notice of intent to service any business establishment at least 30 days before commencing service. The notice shall include the name and address of the establishment, number and size of refuse containers, roll-off bodies, or compactors, the intended days of collection, a copy of the contractor's valid commercial refuse collection permit, and a copy of the valid collection vehicle license for each vehicle to be used in service of that business establishment. The contractor shall provide the city and the business establishment with 30 days written notice before discontinuance of service. The Director may, at the Director's discretion, waive the time requirements of this division. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the law. The city may suspend or revoke any permit authorized or required by this chapter, whenever it is found that the holder of the permit, or user of the collection, recycling, or disposal services, commits a violation of the laws of the state, the county, this chapter, or any rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, or fails to fully reimburse the city its costs associated with the remedying of any violation of any applicable health codes and ordinances of the city, county, state, and federal government. 
(D)  Suspension or revocation of permit. When a permit has been suspended under this chapter, the permit shall remain suspended until the time as the permit surety is fully reimbursed, all related outstanding fees and fines are received, and any application, notice, or permit required is received and approved by the Director. When a permit has been revoked under this chapter, the contractor shall pay all related outstanding fees and fines immediately, but shall not be required to reimburse the permit surety until the time as the contractor applies for reinstatement. 
(E)  Reinstatement. A contractor whose permit is revoked may not re-apply for a permit under this chapter for 36 months after the effective date of the revocation. 
(Ord. 500, N.S., passed 1-18-2011) 
ENFORCEMENT 

§ 8-1-40 - AUTHORITY. 
(A)  Authority to inspect. Prior to collection, the city shall have the right to inspect containers and their contents. Any solid waste inspector shall have the authority to perform inspections, report violations to the Director for enforcement and issue civil citations pursuant to this chapter. 
(B)  Authority to proceed civilly or criminally. The city may proceed civilly or criminally against a person, firm or corporation acting in violation of this code. Any solid waste inspector may issue a civil citation pursuant to this chapter. 
(C)  Authority to remove container. In addition to issuing a civil citation or pursuing a complaint for criminal sanctions, the city shall have the authority to remove city owned refuse and/or recycling containers from the property of users who fail to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(D)  Authority to abate. The imposition of penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the city from instituting appropriate action to restrain, correct or abate a violation of this chapter in order to terminate an existing or imminent public health hazard. The city may assess the costs of the abatement against the property of the person, firm or corporation acting in violation of this code in the form of a lien on the property. The abatement of violations of this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the city's property maintenance code. 
§ 8-1-41 - VIOLATIONS. 
    Violations of this chapter include, but are not limited to: 
(A)  Failing to remove construction waste. It shall be unlawful for a generator of construction waste to fail to remove the construction waste from the premises within 5 days from the date on which it was placed upon the premises, or not later than the final building inspection, the clearance of public utilities, or the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whichever comes first. 
(B)  Burning refuse, yardwaste, green waste and litter. No person shall burn refuse, yardwaste, green waste or litter unless expressly permitted by the Maricopa County Air Quality Department and with a valid Maricopa County Air Quality Department permit, if applicable. Any burning of refuse, yardwaste, green waste or litter must comply with the rules and regulations established by the Arizona Department of Health Services, Maricopa County Air Quality Department and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
(C)  Interfering with collection. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with authorized collection of refuse in any way. 
(D)  Mishandling hazardous waste. No person, business, contractor or licensee shall knowingly collect, place or cause to be placed or collected any hazardous waste or similar materials from or in any container or from or upon any public or private property, except as specifically permitted by the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality or the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. 
(E)  Failing to contain refuse in transit. No person shall collect, transport or receive any refuse or other wastes within or upon any public or private streets in the city, or anywhere in the city, except in leak proof containers or vehicles so constructed that no refuse or other wastes leak or sift through, fall out or be blown from the container or vehicle. Any person collecting or transporting any refuse or other wastes shall immediately pick up all refuse or waste which drops, spills, leaks or is blown from the collecting or transporting container or vehicle, and shall otherwise clean the place onto which any refuse or wastes were dropped, spilled, blown or leaked. 
(F)  Contaminating recyclable materials. No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited, in any recycling container, anything other than acceptable recyclable materials. 
(Am. Ord. 529, N.S., passed 10-23-2012; Am. Ord. 573 , N.S., passed 5-30-2017) 
§ 8-1-42 - PENALTY. 
    Unless specified otherwise, any person violating any of the provisions of this code shall be guilty of a class one misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $2,500 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both a fine and imprisonment. 
§ 8-1-43 - CIVIL ENFORCEMENT ACTION; PENALTY FOR CONTAINED REFUSE AND UNCONTAINED REFUSE. 
    The civil penalty for a violation of this code shall be $250 per violation, and all penalties are subject to all surcharges and fees imposed by state law. The Court shall not suspend any portion of the civil penalty provided by this division. 
(A)  Civil citation. The civil citation shall direct the defendant to appear in Court within ten days of the issuance of the citation or pay the fine imposed pursuant to § 8-1-42 of this code. The citation shall also include the date and location of the violation, a reference to the city code provision or ordinance violated and a notice that if the defendant fails to appear as directed, a default judgment will be entered in the amount of the fine designated on the citation for the violation charged, in addition to a fine for failure to appear as set forth in division (C) below of this code. 
(B)  Citation service. Service of the citation may be accomplished and will be deemed proper and complete by any of the following methods: 
(1)  Hand delivering a copy of the citation to the defendant; 
(2)  Mailing a copy of the citation to the defendant by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the defendant's last known address; 
(3)  In the event service cannot be accomplished as set forth above, the defendant may be served by any means allowed by the Arizona Rules of Civil Procedure for the Superior Court. 
(C)  Appearance; penalty for failure to appear. Within ten days of the issuance of the citation, the defendant shall appear in person or through his or her attorney in Court and shall either admit or deny the allegations contained in the complaint or the defendant may proceed as provided in division (D) of this code. If the defendant admits the allegations, the Court shall immediately enter judgment against the defendant in the amount of the fine for the violation charged. If the defendant denies the allegations contained in the citation, the court shall set a hearing date for trial of the matter. If the defendant fails to appear as directed on the citation, the court, upon request by the code official or authorized designee, shall enter a default judgment for the amount of the fine indicated for the violation charged. Additionally, the defendant may be fined up to $100 for failure to appear at the time and place set for any trial of a matter arising under this code. 
(D)  Payment by mail. The defendant may admit the allegations in the citation and pay the fine indicated by mailing the citation, together with a check for the amount of the fine to and made payable to the Tolleson City Court. 
(E)  Rules of procedure. The Arizona Rules of Procedure in Civil Traffic Violation Cases shall be followed by the Tolleson City Court for civil violations of this code, except as modified or where inconsistent with the provisions of this code, local rules of the municipal court or rules of the Arizona Supreme Court. 
RESIDENTIAL RECYCLING PROGRAMS 

§ 8-1-55 - COLLECTION OF RESIDENTIAL RECYCLABLE MATERIALS. 
(A)  The collection of recyclable materials from residential properties by a person or contractor other than the city is prohibited. 
(B)  Under the residential sanitation service recycling program, the city will provide residential customers a second clearly identified recycling container in which to place specified residential recyclable materials. The recycling container will remain the property of the city. 
(C)  The specified residential recyclable materials are approved by City Council and may change from time to time after notification to all residential customers. No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited, in any recycling container, anything other than the approved specified recyclable materials. 
(D)  Residential customers participating in the residential sanitation service recycling program shall receive from the city once-per-week collection of residential recyclable materials placed into recycling containers, and once-per-week collection of nonrecyclable materials placed into refuse containers. The Administrator will designate specific collection days each week, including holidays. 
(E)  Residential recyclable materials placed inside a recycling container shall not be bagged or contained and should conform to all residential recycling program guidelines consistent with this article. 
(F)  Residential customers participating in the residential recycling program shall bag and securely tie their refuse and place it inside a refuse container. 
§ 8-1-56 - RECYCLING PROGRAM NONPARTICIPANTS. 
(A)  A nonparticipant shall not receive nor retain a recycling container, shall receive twice-per-week refuse collection, and an extra fee will be charged. The city will assess this fee on a monthly basis in addition to the regular monthly service fee. The entire regular monthly service fee which includes recycling program costs shall be paid by all residential customers whether participating in the recycling program or not. 
(B)  Residential customers not complying with this article will be notified in writing by the city of their status as nonparticipants. After a minimum of two notifications have been given explaining their lack of compliance with this article, the recycling container will be retrieved by the city. 
(1)  The city may make the notification based upon a determination that a violation of this article has occurred, including any of the following actions: 
(a)  Placing anything other than the specified residential recyclable materials into a recycling container; 
(b)  Placing dangerous or hazardous waste in a recycling container; and 
(c)  Depositing specified residential recyclable materials into a refuse container. 
(2)  The Administrator or designee may deliver twice-per-week collection to any residential customer, subject to the appropriate additional monthly service fee, if in the Administrator's judgment a health hazard exists. 
§ 8-1-57 - RE-ENTRY AS A PARTICIPANT. 
(A)  Residential customers determined by the city to be nonparticipants may notify the city that they desire to re-enter the residential sanitation service recycling program. The notification may occur no earlier than three months after being designated by the city as a nonparticipant. The Administrator may waive this three month period upon a determination that special circumstances exist and that it would be in the best interest of the city to allow re-entry sooner. 
(B)  The city also may designate a fee to recover costs associated with distributing recycling containers and information by city personnel to residents re-entering the recycling program. 
§ 8-1-58 - APPEAL PROCESS. 
    Any person who has been designated by the city as a nonparticipant may file, within seven calendar days after receipt of notice from the city of the designation, in the Administrator's office a written request for a hearing before the Administrator. The request shall contain the name and address of the person, together with a brief statement as to why the designation should be reversed. The decision of the Administrator is final. 
ARTICLE 8-2: - LITTER 

§ 8-2-1 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    LITTER. Any rubbish, trash, weeds, filth and debris which shall constitute a hazard to public health and safety and shall include all putrescible and non-putrescible solid wastes including garbage, trash, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial waste; any deposit, accumulation, pile or heap of brush, grass, debris, weeds, cans, cloth, paper, wood, rubbish or other unsightly or unsanitary matter of any kind whatsoever; and any growth of weeds, brush, grass or other vegetable growth to a height of over six inches. 
    PRIVATE PREMISES. Any dwelling, house, building or other structure, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps or vestibules belonging or appurtenant to the dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    PUBLIC PLACE. Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
§ 8-2-2 - LITTER ON PRIVATE PREMISES. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any private premises within the city, whether owned by the person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private premises may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place. 
§ 8-2-3 - OWNER TO MAINTAIN PREMISES. 
(A)  Generally. All land including exterior premises and vacant land, whether improved or unimproved, shall be maintained free from any accumulation of garbage or blight, which includes, but is not limited to, graffiti on walls, fences, mail boxes, and the like, accumulation of litter; rubbish, refuse, waste material, bottles, papers, glass, cans, organic or inorganic material; inoperable vehicles, discarded appliances; discarded furniture, broken glass, piles of mixed material (dry vegetation, rags, empty barrels, boxes, crates, packing cages, mattresses, bedding, excelsior, packing straw, packing hay or other packing material, lumber not neatly piled (and if neatly piled in no event for more than 5 days), lumber stored in front yards, scrap iron, tin and other metal not neatly piled (and if neatly piled in no event for more than 5 days) or anything whatsoever in which insects, rodents, snakes or other harmful pests may live, breed or multiply or which may otherwise create a fire hazard. It is an affirmative defense to a violation of this article based on the presence of an inoperable vehicle that the vehicle was registered to a resident of the property, that the vehicle was undergoing repair, and that the total period during which the vehicle was inoperable did not exceed 15 days. This affirmative defense may not be raised more than three times in any combination of civil or criminal proceedings in any one calendar year. 
(B)  Sidewalks, streets and alleys. The owner and any responsible party in control of any land abutting a sidewalk, alley or street shall maintain the sidewalk, alley or street in the same manner as provided in division (A). The areas required to be maintained pursuant to this section are as follows: 
(1)  Any portion of a street, which has been opened for public use, between the curb line and the abutting property line including sidewalks and landscaped areas; 
(2)  One half of the width of abutting alleys, from the property line to the center line of the alley; and 
(3)  Any portion of a street abutting the boundaries of a parcel of land, which street has not been dedicated to the City or Maricopa County or otherwise opened for public use, shall be maintained by those persons who created or are served by the street or their successors in interest, including lessees and other persons in control of the land abutting the street; provided, that if the abutting land on either side of the street is owned by different persons and each person has an obligation to maintain the street hereunder, then the owner, lessee or other person in control of the land shall only be required to maintain one-half of the width of the street abutting their land. 
(C)  Swimming and architectural pools and spas. All swimming and architectural pools and spas shall be properly maintained so as not to create a safety hazard or harbor insect infestation, or create a visible deteriorated or blighted appearance. Water shall not be allowed to stagnate. Fencing or other barriers required for swimming pool and spa enclosures shall be maintained as required by law. The premises shall be free from safety hazards inclusive of, but not limited to, lack of security, water stagnation, or abandoned pools, regardless of whether or not there is water in the pools. All pools will also be free from visible deterioration or blighted appearance. 
(D)  Dry vegetation, tumbleweeds, weeds, bushes and tall grass and trees. All exterior property areas shall be kept free from dry vegetation, tumbleweeds, weeds, bushes and tall grass and trees which present a visual blight upon the area, which may harbor insect or rodent infestations and, dry vegetation, or which may likely become a fire hazard or result in a condition which may threaten the health and safely or the economic welfare of adjacent property owners or occupants. The premises shall be free from visual blight, potential fire hazards, dead trees and branches, palm fronds, lawn grass, tumbleweeds or weeds higher than six inches tall. 
(E)  Dumping. 
(1)  Vacant lots or lands which have been subject to dumping on more than one occasion shall be secured to prevent future occurrences of dumping. 
(2)  Methods of securing vacant lots or lands may include the following: 
(a)  Permanent fencing; 
(b)  Ditch and berm; 
(c)  Placing four foot high posts at four foot intervals; and 
(d)  Other equally effective methods. 
(3)  Signs stating "no dumping" shall be erected in accordance with applicable laws on vacant lots or lands which have been subject to dumping on more than one occasion. 
(E)  Excavations. 
(1)  Excavations and other like or similar conditions must be filled with clean fill. On a temporary basis, excavations shall be maintained in a secure manner so as to prevent a hazard to public health and safety. 
(2)  An excavation is considered secure when: 
(a)  The excavation is protected by a free-standing, stable and complete six foot minimum height enclosure that surrounds the excavation or property; and 
(b)  A well, pit, abandoned swimming pool, or similar excavation is completely and permanently covered, fenced securely or protected in an equivalent manner. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 573 , N.S., passed 5-30-2017) 
§ 8-2-4 - PROCEDURE TO COMPEL REMOVAL OF LITTER. 
    The Zoning Administrator, or his or her designee, may enforce the provisions of this article through one or more of the following methods: 
(A)  Prosecuting violators of the article in the Tolleson Magistrate's Court pursuant to the criminal provisions of this code; 
(B)  Proceeding civilly against violators of the article pursuant to this code; or 
(C)  Compelling the removal of litter by the procedure outlined in §§ 8-2-5 through 8-2-6 hereof. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012) 
§ 8-2-5 - NOTICE TO REMOVE. 
    If a person owning, leasing, or occupying any property fails, neglects, or refuses to comply with this article, the Zoning Administrator, or his or her designee, may compel the person to comply by giving written notice to comply not less than 5 days before the day set for compliance. The "day set for compliance" means 5 days from the date of the notice. The notice shall contain: 
(A)  The legal description of the property; 
(B)  An estimate of the cost to the city to bring the property into compliance; 
(C)  A statement that the city will perform the necessary work at the expense of the person owning, leasing, or occupying the property unless the person complies on or before the day set for compliance; and 
(D)  A statement that the person may appeal in writing to the Council before the day set for compliance. If the person appeals within the time limit, unless the removal or abatement is ordered by a court, the person is entitled to a hearing before the Council. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012; Am. Ord. 573 , N.S., passed 5-30-2017) 
§ 8-2-6 - SERVICE OF NOTICE. 
    Notice shall be personally served on the owner, the owner's authorized agent, or the owner's statutory agent and on the person occupying or leasing the property, by a police officer of the city or by a private process server registered with the clerk of the court in the manner provided in the Arizona Rules of Civil Procedure, or shall be mailed by certified mail to the last known address of the owner, the owner's authorized agent, or the owner's statutory agent and to the address to which the tax bill for the property was last mailed. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012) 
§ 8-2-7 - REMOVAL BY CITY. 
    When any person to whom notice, as aforesaid, has been given and on or before the day set for compliance, fails, neglects or refuses to comply with this article, the Zoning Administrator, or his or her designee, is authorized and directed to cause the property to be brought into compliance with this article at the expense of the owner or person leasing or occupying the property. Upon completion of the work, the Zoning Administrator, or his or her designee, shall prepare a verified statement of account of the actual cost of the removal or abatement, including the actual costs of any additional inspection and other incidental connected costs, the date the work was completed, and the street address and the legal description of the property on which the work was done, and shall serve a duplicate copy of the verified statement upon, or mail the same to, the person owning, leasing or occupying the property in the manner prescribed in § 8-2-6 hereof. The cost of removal, abatement, or injunction, and associated legal costs for abatement or injunctions, shall be assessed on the property on which the work was done. The owner, lessee, or occupant of the property shall have 30 days from the date of service, or, if mailed, the date of receipt, of the verified statement to appeal in writing from the amount of the assessment as contained in the verified statement. If the person appeals within the time limit, unless the removal or abatement is ordered by a court, the person is entitled to a hearing before the Council. If an appeal is not filed within the 30-day period, then the amount of the assessment shall become final and binding. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012) 
§ 8-2-8 - ASSESSMENT FOR REMOVAL. 
    If no appeal is taken from the amount of the assessment, or if an appeal is taken and the amount of the assessment has been affirmed or modified, the original assessment or the assessment as so modified, including the city's name, the date and amount of the assessment, and the legal description of the property, shall be recorded in the office of the Maricopa County Recorder and from the date of its recording shall be a lien on the lot or tract of land until paid. The lien is prior and superior to all other liens, obligations, mortgages or other encumbrances, except for liens for general taxes. A sale of the property to satisfy an assessment obtained under the provisions of this section shall be made upon judgment of foreclosure and order of sale. The city shall have the right to bring an action to enforce the assessment in Maricopa County Superior Court at any time after the recording of the assessment, but failure to enforce the assessment by such action shall not affect its validity. The recorded assessment shall be prima facie evidence of the truth of all matters recited therein, and of the regularity of all proceedings prior to the recording thereof. A prior assessment for the purposes provided in this section shall not be a bar to a subsequent assessment or assessments for those purposes, and any number of liens on the same lot or tract of land may be enforced in the same action. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012) 
§ 8-2-9 - PLACEMENT OF DEBRIS. 
    Any person, firm or corporation that places any rubbish, trash, filth or debris upon any private or public property not owned or under the control of that person, firm or corporation shall be guilty of a class I misdemeanor or a civil violation and, in addition to any fine or penalty which may be imposed for violation of any provision of this article, shall be liable for all costs which may be assessed pursuant to this article for the removing, abating, or enjoining the rubbish, trash, filth or debris. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998; Am. Ord. 525, N.S., passed 9-11-2012) 
ARTICLE 8-3: - LANDFILLS 

§ 8-3-1 - SUPERVISION BY CITY'S MANAGER. 
(A)  The use of the city landfill shall be subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager or the Manager's designee. 
(B)  The Council shall have the authority to make regulations concerning the use of the landfill, as it shall deem necessary, and to change and modify the same. The Council shall have the power to alter any existing regulation, create new regulations or permit the non-compliance with any regulation if the same is deemed by them to be necessary to protect health and safety or to carry out the purpose and intent of this article. 
§ 8-3-2 - NO CHARGE TO RESIDENTS. 
    There will be no charge for use of city landfill facilities by residents of the city so long as the trash or other items deposited in the landfill originate in the city. 
§ 8-3-3 - USE OF LANDFILL. 
(A)  (1) The city landfill facilities shall be used exclusively by residents of the city and no special permits shall be granted. 
(2)  The City Manager or the Manager's designee is authorized to issue appropriate identification to residents for use of the city landfill. The City Manager or the Manager's designee is further authorized to post appropriate "no trespassing" signs and erect fences and gates to enforce this section. 
(B)  It is unlawful for a non-resident to use the landfill facilities. It is unlawful for any person to allow a non-resident of the city to use his or her landfill identification card or to bring trash to the city landfill that originates outside the city limits. 
ARTICLE 8-4: - JUNK 

§ 8-4-1 - DEFINITION. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definition shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    JUNK. Includes all old appliances or parts thereof, all old iron or other metal, glass, paper, cardboard, old lumber, old wood, old mattresses and all other waste or discarded material. 
(Ord. 236, N.S., passed 10-23-1984) 
§ 8-4-2 - KEEPING OF JUNK UNLAWFUL. 
    It is unlawful for any person to keep, store or allow to accumulate or to permit any other person to keep, store or allow to accumulate any junk on any privately-owned property within the city, or to keep, store or allow to accumulate any junk in a building that is not wholly enclosed, except for doors for ingress or egress, and any person violating this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day that this article is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 236, N.S., passed 10-23-1984) 
§ 8-4-3 - VIOLATORS TO BE NOTIFIED. 
    Before any person is charged with a violation of this article, the person shall be advised by certified or registered letter that a complaint is contemplated and by the letter shall be given not less than 5 days to cause removal of the junk. Copies of the letters shall be kept and filed by the city along with any complaint filed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. 236, N.S., passed 10-23-1984; Am. Ord. 573 , N.S., passed 5-30-2017) 
§ 8-4-4 - REMOVAL BY CITY. 
    Junk may be removed following the procedures set forth in §§ 8-2-5, 8-2-6, 8-2-7 and 8-2-8 of this code. 
(Ord. 236, N.S., passed 10-23-1984) 
§ 8-4-5 - EXCEPTIONS. 
    This article shall not apply to any appliance dealer who, in a proper zone, has screened his or her old appliances from general view and from access by children or trespassers, nor to material stores on the premises of any manufacturing enterprise for use in connection with the enterprise so long as the enterprise is conducted in accordance with zoning and other codes. 
(Ord. 236, N.S., passed 10-23-1984) 
ARTICLE 8-5: - NON-DUST FREE LOTS 

§ 8-5-1 - PARKING ON NON-DUST FREE LOTS. 
    No person shall park, or permit to be parked, any motor vehicle upon any lot or area within the city which is not dust free. Violation of this section shall constitute a civil traffic violation, and the violator shall be subject to a civil sanction of not less than $65 or more than $250. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998) 
§ 8-5-2 - DEFINITION OF DUST FREE. 
    DUST FREE shall mean that a lot or area is maintained by paving with one of the following methods: asphaltic concrete, cement concrete, penetration treatment of bituminous material and seal coat of bituminous binder and a mineral aggregate, or the equivalent as approved by the Zoning Administrator. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998) 
§ 8-5-3 - RESIDENTIAL LOTS. 
    An area which encompasses all or part of a residential lot which contains one single family or duplex residential unit is also dust free if covered by a smooth layer of crushed rock or gravel maintained to a minimum depth of three inches and contained within a permanent border or an alternative surface treatment as approved by the Development Services Department that will equal or exceed the dust free characteristic of contained crushed rock or gravel. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998) 
§ 8-5-4 - AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation of this article that the condition of the lot was in compliance with a stipulation made by the Zoning Commission permitting temporary parking for civic events and that the vehicle was parked by or on behalf of an attendee of an event. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998) 
§ 8-5-5 - IMPOUND. 
    The Police Department may remove and impound any vehicle parked or stored found to be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. 364, N.S., passed 2-10-1998) 
ARTICLE 8-6: - DUST AND AIRBORNE PARTICULATE CONTROL 

§ 8-6-1 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this article is to improve air quality by regulating practices that contribute to the air pollution caused by particulate matter. 
(Ord. 516, N.S., passed 9-13-2011) 
§ 8-6-2 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    LEAF BLOWER. A device that generates a stream of air to move landscape debris. 
    MOTOR VEHICLE. A self-propelled conveyance, including vehicles designed for use on roadways and those designed for off-road use. 
    PARTICULATE MATTER. Fine dust particles that contribute to air pollution and can harm human health. 
    PERSON. Any public or private corporation, company, partnership, firm, association or society of persons, the federal government and any of its departments or agencies, the state and any of its agencies, departments or political subdivisions, as well as a natural person. 
    PUBLIC ROADWAY. A street, alley, road, highway or thoroughfare that is used by the public or is open to public use for vehicular travel, including roadways in gated communities. 
(Ord. 516, N.S., passed 9-13-2011) 
§ 8-6-3 - LEAF BLOWER USE RESTRICTIONS. 
(A)  No person may use a leaf blower to blow leaves, grass cuttings, other landscape debris, trash, soil or dust into a public roadway. 
(B)  No person may operate a leaf or air blower for landscape maintenance that has a 50 cubic centimeter engine or larger. 
(C)  No person may operate a leaf blower except on stabilized surfaces, which are stabilized with asphaltic concrete, cement concrete, penetration treatment of bituminous material and seal coat of bituminous binder and a mineral aggregate, granite cover, aggregate cover, gravel cover, grass or other continuous vegetative cover, or any combination of those stabilizers. 
(D)  No person may operate a leaf blower during any high pollution advisory day forecast for particulate matter. 
(E)  The provisions of this section do not apply to any site that has a permit issued by a control officer as defined in A.R.S. § 49-471, as amended, for the control of fugitive dust from dust generating operations. 
(Ord. 516, N.S., passed 9-13-2011) 
§ 8-6-4 - UNPAVED AREAS. 
(A)  Parking, maneuvering, ingress, and egress areas at developments other than residential buildings with four or fewer units shall be maintained with one or more of the following dustproof paving methods: 
(1)  Asphaltic concrete; 
(2)  Cement concrete; 
(3)  Penetration treatment of bituminous material and seal coat of bituminous binder and a mineral aggregate; or 
(4)  A stabilization method approved by the city. 
(B)  Parking, maneuvering, ingress, and egress areas 3,000 square feet or more in size at residential buildings with four or fewer units shall be maintained with one or more of the following dustproof paving methods: 
(1)  Asphaltic concrete; 
(2)  Cement concrete; 
(3)  Penetration treatment of bituminous material and seal coat of bituminous binder and a mineral aggregate; or 
(4)  A stabilization method approved by the city.
