ARTICLE 10-4: - CONSUMER RESPONSIBILITIES 

§ 10-4-1 - CONSUMER WATER FACILITIES. 
    The consumer shall have complete responsibility for the installation and maintenance of adequate water facilities on the premises, and the city shall not in any way be responsible for the installation, maintenance, inspection or damage of the facilities or damage caused by any defect in the facilities on the consumer's premises. The facilities shall be maintained by the consumer in full compliance with any and all rules and regulations of the city in addition to applicable state statutes. 
§ 10-4-2 - CONSUMER NEGLIGENCE. 
    When any damage to the city water system or injury to city employees is caused by the negligence of any consumer and requires any repairs, replacements or damages, the cost of that shall be added to that consumer's bill and, if the charges are not paid, water service may be discontinued. 
§ 10-4-3 - RIGHT-OF-WAY. 
    Each consumer shall provide to the city the easement and right-of-way as is necessary to provide water service to that consumer. 
§ 10-4-4 - PROTECTION OF CITY PROPERTY. 
    The consumer shall guarantee proper protection for city property placed on the consumer's premises and shall permit access to it only to authorized representatives of the city. 
§ 10-4-5 - SUPPLYING WATER TO OTHERS PROHIBITED. 
    No occupant or owner of any building into which water is introduced will be allowed to supply water to other persons or families or for use on any other property. The city reserves the right to shut off the supply for abuses of water privileges. 
§ 10-4-6 - COMMERCIAL USE. 
    Any water service for commercial use shall not be included in a residential service account and shall have a separate meter and connection. 
§ 10-4-7 - SPRINKLING RESTRICTIONS. 
    In case of water shortage or scarcity, the Council may, by resolution, place any restrictions which it deems necessary upon the use of water for irrigation or sprinkling purposes. 
§ 10-4-8 - WASTE OF WATER PROHIBITED. 
(A)  Consumers shall prevent unnecessary waste of water and keep all water outlets closed when not in actual use. 
(B)  All water outlets, including those used in conjunction with hydrants, urinals, water closets, bathtubs and other fixtures, must not be left running for any purpose other than the use for which they were intended. 
(C)  In addition to the penalty provided herein for code violations, the water supply may be turned off where any waste occurs. 
§ 10-4-9 - INSPECTIONS. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the city, it is deemed necessary, it may provide for the inspection of the premises or buildings of any water consumer for the purpose of examining the condition of all pipes, motors, meters and fixtures, or the manner in which the facilities are used. 
ARTICLE 10-5: - LIABILITY 

§ 10-5-1 - INTERRUPTION OF SERVICE. 
    The city shall notify the consumer in advance of any anticipated interruption of service when the advance notice is possible. The city shall not be responsible for any interruption of water service caused by forces beyond its control. 
§ 10-5-2 - LIABILITY LIMITED. 
    No liability shall attach to the city for any injury or damages that may result from turning on or shutting off the water in any main, service connection or pipe, or the restriction of use or discontinuance of any water service, or any failure of the water supply, regardless of any notice or lack of notice thereof. The city shall not be held liable, in any respect, for the condition, defects, failure or use of any pipe, connection, fixture or appurtenance, not belonging to the city, on any premises, or for loss or damage resulting therefrom. If repairs are necessary due to unauthorized turn on or turn offs, the city has the right to charge the home owner for all time and materials related to repair. 
ARTICLE 10-6: - WATER CONSERVATION 

§ 10-6-1 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish for the city a water conservation policy and guidelines to be used hereafter in the city. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-2 - AUTHORITY DELEGATED TO CITY'S MANAGER. 
    The following programs will be directly implemented by policy directives of the City Manager after review and approval by the Council: 
(A)  Water meter testing; 
(B)  Leak detection and repairs; 
(C)  Feasibility study to use reclaimed wastewater for irrigation; and 
(D)  Other programs as the Council or the Arizona Department of Water Resources may from time to time recommend. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-3 - ELIMINATION OF WATER THEFT. 
(A)  The receipt of any water from the city's water system by any means other than through an authorized, functioning, metered service connection shall be considered theft and shall be prosecuted as a class one misdemeanor subject to the general penalty clause of § 1-1-8. 
(B)  This article will permit certain exceptions: 
(1)  For emergency use, such as fire fighting; 
(2)  For Water and Sewer Department maintenance, e.g. flushing and testing of water lines; 
(3)  For accidental releases, e.g. line breaks; and 
(4)  For temporary operations for the receipt of water such as for construction use, administered through a permit process and the installation of temporary meters by the city staff. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988; Ord. 567, N.S., passed 11-22-2016) 
§ 10-6-4 - ELIMINATION OF WATER WASTE DUE TO EXCESS RUN-OFF. 
    The city staff shall have the authority to enforce regulations which will prevent groundwater run-off and waste from landscape areas due to poor grading or over irrigation; operation of automatic irrigation systems during periods of rain and from car washing and similar operations on impervious surfaces. A violator shall be given one warning, in writing, by the city staff or Police Department. A second violation within 30 days of the warning and all subsequent violations shall constitute a class one misdemeanor subject to the general penalty clause of § 1-1-8. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988; Ord. 567, N.S., passed 11-22-2016) 
§ 10-6-5 - FLOW RESTRICTION DEVICES. 
(A)  This section shall apply to water-cooled refrigerating systems using water, entirely or in part, as a means of condensing a refrigerant installed after May 1, 1988. 
(B)  Water-cooled refrigerating systems, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall be equipped with one of the following devices: 
(1)  Cooling tower; 
(2)  An evaporative condenser; or 
(3)  An acceptable water-circulating device. 
(C)  The provisions of division (B) above shall not apply to systems with an aggregate total of two tons or less or a rating of two horsepower or less and located or installed at one street address. Multiple dwelling unit structures are considered as one street address. However, the systems should be equipped with water regulation valves adjusted to use a minimum amount of water. 
(D)  All new installations of evaporative coolers shall be fitted with recirculation pumps. 
(E)  Penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine of up to $300 per day until the proper device has been installed. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-6 - NEW CONSTRUCTION. 
(A)  New developments and major renovations are to be fitted with low flow plumbing fixtures and devices. 
(B)  The plumbing fixtures and devices required to be installed pursuant to this article shall be certified by the International Association of Plumbing and Mechanical Officials and comply with all applicable American-National Standards Institute standards. 
(C)  The plumbing fixtures and devices specified in this section shall be installed, unless otherwise indicated herein, in every new building or addition to an existing building for which a building permit has been issued after May 1, 1988, and when a replacement fixture or device is required in any building. 
(1)  Faucets (general). All lavatory, kitchen and bar sink faucets shall be designed, manufactured, installed or equipped with a flow control device or aerator which will not allow a water flow rate in excess of two and seventy-five-hundredths gallons per minute. 
(2)  Faucets (public restrooms). In addition to the general requirements set forth in division (C)(1) above, lavatory faucets located in restrooms intended for use by the general public shall be of the metering or self-closing type. 
(3)  Showerheads. Showerheads, except where provided for safety reasons, shall be designed, manufactured and installed with a flow limitation device which will not allow a water flow rate in excess of two and seventy-five-hundredths gallons per minute. The flow limitation device must be a permanent and integral part of the showerhead and must not be removable to allow flow rate in excess of two and seventy-five-hundredths gallons per minute. 
(4)  Urinals. Urinals shall be designed, manufactured and installed so the maximum flush will not exceed one and one-half gallons of water. Adjustable type flushometer valve may be used provided they are adjusted so the maximum flush will not exceed one and one-half gallons of water. 
(5)  Water closets. Water closets shall be designed, manufactured and installed so the maximum flush will not exceed one and one-half gallons of water. 
(D)  New or major renovations to non-residential, commercial and industrial facilities shall, where possible, comply with the provisions of this section or demonstrate to the City Building Inspector that the most efficient water control devices are being utilized. 
(E)  Developers of new non-residential facilities shall employ the best available technology for water conservation. The conservation requirements apply to all uses within the facility including processes, potable use, maintenance and operations. The developer will be responsible for demonstrating that the best available technology is to be used as part of the project approval and building permit process. The developer will submit a report with the project documents. The report shall be prepared by an engineer licensed in the State of Arizona. The report shall detail all potential water use points within the facility, the type of system fixtures, devices and controls to be employed to reduce the water consumption at these points to a minimum; estimates of what the annual water consumption would be, with and without the water conservation technology, and a certification that the technology proposed is the best available at the time of facility design. 
(F)  City staff will have the right to conduct actual usage audits after the facility is occupied to ensure ongoing compliance. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-7 - USE OF LOW WATER CONSUMPTION LANDSCAPING FOR NEW DEVELOPMENTS. 
(A)  All new developments submitted for approval within the city shall employ a system of low water consumption landscaping and watering. 
(B)  The list of plants dated December, 1984, is to be used for minimum water consumption for new developments and major renovations (requiring a building permit) for landscaping purposes. The plant list prepared by the Arizona Department of Water Resources dated December, 1984, and any updates thereto appear in Article 10-8. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-8 - WATER SERVICE CONNECTIONS AND METERS. 
(A)  The Council shall adopt a resolution which will require all water service connections both existing and future, to be fitted with meters. 
(B)  Service connections for the exclusive use of fire sprinkler systems in non-residential facilities may be exempt from this requirement. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-9 - CONVERTING LANDSCAPING OF PUBLIC AREAS TO LOW WATER CONSUMPTION TYPES. 
    The city shall adopt a resolution to convert the landscaping of public areas to low water consumption types. This conversion shall be in accordance with the technical standards of this article. Public areas shall include but not be limited to city, county, state as well as elementary and high school property. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-10 - RETROFIT OF EXISTING PLUMBING FIXTURES. 
(A)  The city shall adopt a resolution to institute a voluntary program to install low-flow devices on existing fixtures. 
(B)  The city shall adopt a resolution to institute a voluntary program to fit existing flow through evaporative coolers with re-circulating pumps. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-11 - PUBLIC AWARENESS AND EDUCATION PROGRAM. 
    The Council shall adopt a resolution to implement an ongoing public awareness and education program to help achieve the city's water conservation objectives. The program will be developed by the city staff and will take advantage of a wide range of techniques and resources available from other programs in the Phoenix Active Management area and the Arizona Department of Water Resources. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-12 - WATER USE AUDIT OF EXISTING NON-RESIDENTIAL USERS. 
(A)  The Council shall adopt a resolution to conduct a voluntary water use audit of existing non-residential water users to encourage conversion to the best available technology. 
(B)  This program will consist of the following steps: 
(1)  Send letter signed by Mayor to each user. Publish the letter and program highlights; 
(2)  Conduct the actual audit by city staff or independent contractors; and 
(3)  Submit report with recommendations. Recommendations may include providing a one time economic incentive to encourage conversions. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-13 - RESTRICTION ON USE OF WATER FOR LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION. 
    The city staff is authorized to prepare and implement regulations which will restrict the use of groundwater for landscape irrigation to periods of low evaporative loss. The permitted periods will include seasonal conditions as well as daily conditions. These regulations shall be adopted by the Council by appropriate resolution. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-14 - WATER USE RATE SCALE TO DISCOURAGE WASTE. 
(A)  In order to reduce discretionary consumption of water, it is proposed to change the water use rates to provide an economic incentive to do so without restricting development. 
(B)  A new water rate structure will be developed by the City Manager and approved by Council resolution after conducting a study of the other local water use rates to arrive at a rate structure which has the following characteristics: 
(1)  Does not cause hardship to present users; 
(2)  Has an incentive to reduce the discretionary consumption; and 
(3)  Does not restrict desirable new development with the city. 
(C)  This article provides annual authorization for the city staff to analyze the city's water rates and prepare changes for adoption by Council resolution. The city staff is also authorized to conduct an initial study and prepare a new rate structure which increases progressively with the amount of water use and which also has a seasonal adjustment factor to be used during the high consumption season. This annual review shall follow the guidelines set forth in this section and article and the guidelines and goals given to the city by the Arizona Department of Water Resources. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-15 - ANNUAL WATER USE QUOTAS. 
(A)  The Council shall adopt an annual resolution which would permit the establishment of quotas for water consumption by non-residential users and provides authority to implement them. The quotas would be based on individual user's record of consumption, their progress towards implementing conservation programs, their estimated discretionary consumption (to be defined) and the city's overall progress towards meeting its annual conservation objectives. These quotas would be enforced by the city as a last resort. 
(B)  The city shall use this annual quota review to attain quotas passed on to the city by the Arizona Department of Water Resources. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-16 - VIOLATION; PENALTIES. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein a violation of this article shall be a civil infraction. A single citation shall be issued for each building regardless of the actual number of non-compliances within the building. The owner of the building or the person who acquired the building permit shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $500 per citation. The City Court shall also order the persons to correct all non-compliances within the building for which the citation was issued. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
§ 10-6-17 - WAIVER OF REQUIREMENTS. 
    In the event any low flow fixture or other water conservation device, required by this article, will be unavailable from any reasonable source for a period in excess of 90 days, the developer or contractor of a new building or addition to an existing building may request a temporary waiver of the requirements of this article. The request for a temporary waiver shall be in writing, shall contain sufficient documentation to support the claim that the device or fixture will not be available for a period in excess of 90 days, and shall be delivered to the City Manager either personally or by certified mail. The City Manager may request or solicit additional information in order to determine if the request is valid. If the City Manager finds that the device or fixture will be unavailable from any reasonable source for a period in excess of 90 days, the City Manager may grant to the developer or contractor a permit waiving compliance with the requirements of this article for a period of 180 days from the date of issuance of the permit. If the fixtures or devices become available before the 180-day period expires, the waiver shall terminate automatically. The decision of the City Manager will be final. 
(Ord. 285, N.S., passed 3-22-1988) 
ARTICLE 10-7: - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

§ 10-7-1 - PURPOSE; RESPONSIBILITY. 
(A)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to protect the public water supply of the city from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating within the user's system the contaminants or pollutants which could backflow into the public water supply; and to provide for the monitoring and enforcement of a continuing program of backflow prevention, which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the city's potable water supply. 
(B)  Responsibility. 
(1)  The Department. The Building Department (hereinafter called the "Department") of the city is vested with the authority and responsibility for the implementation of an effective cross-connection control program and for the enforcement of the provisions of this article and to prevent water from unapproved sources to enter the potable water system. No water service connection to premises of a type specified in this article shall be installed or maintained unless the public water supply is protected as required by this article. 
(2)  The user. The user shall not allow any pollutants and contaminants to enter the public potable water system, from the point of delivery from the public potable water system. The user shall, at his or her own expense, install, operate, test and maintain approved backflow preventive assemblies as directed by the Department. 
§ 10-7-2 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    APPROVED. Accepted by the Department as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this article, and as suitable for the proposed use. 
    AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY. Any water supply on or available to the premises other than the public potable water supply, including, but not limited to, water from another purveyor's public or private potable water supply, treated effluent, wastewater or industrial fluids. 
    BACKFLOW. The reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either backpressure or backsiphonage. 
    BACKPRESSURE. The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances under pressure into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than the intended source. 
    BACKSIPHONAGE. The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply from any source other than its intended source caused by the reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. 
    BACKFLOW PREVENTER. An assembly or means designed to prevent the reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either backpressure or backsiphonage. 
(1)  AIR GAP. The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the vessel. An approved air gap shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically, above the overflow rim of the vessel, and in no case less than one inch. 
(2)  DOUBLE CHECK BACKFLOW ASSEMBLY. An assembly of two independently operating approved check valves with resilient seated shut-off valves on each end of the check valves, plus properly located test cocks for the testing of each check valve. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by a recognized laboratory and approved by the Department for backflow prevention assemblies. To be approved these devices must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. 
(3)  PRESSURE VACUUM BREAKER ASSEMBLY. An assembly containing an independently operating loaded check valve and an independently operating loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve. The assembly shall be equipped with properly located test cocks and resilient seated shut-off valves located at each end of the assembly. 
(4)  REDUCED PRESSURE BACKFLOW ASSEMBLY. An assembly of two independently acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically operating, mechanically independent differential pressure relief valve located between the check valves and, at the same time, below the first check valve. The unit shall include properly located test cocks and resilient seated shut-off valves at each end of the assembly. The entire device shall meet the design and performance specifications as determined by a recognized laboratory and approved by the Department for backflow prevention assemblies. To be approved, these devices must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. 
    CONTAMINATION. An impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree, which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease. 
    CROSS-CONNECTION. Any physical connection or arrangement of piping or fixtures between two otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the other non-potable water or industrial fluids through which, or because of which, backflow may occur into the potable water system. This would include any temporary connections, such as swing connections, removable sections, four-way plug valves, spools, dummy section of pipe, swivel or change-over devices or sliding multiport tube. 
    POLLUTION. The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic or biological) in the water which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual hazard to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect the waters for domestic use. 
    TESTER, RECOGNIZED. A person who has proven his or her competency to the satisfaction of the Department. Each person certified to make competent tests or to repair, overhaul and make reports on backflow prevention assemblies shall be conversant with the applicable laws, rules and regulations and have had experience in plumbing or pipe fitting or have other qualifications which are equivalent in the opinion of the Department. 
    WATER, POTABLE. Any water, which, according to the city, meets nationally recognized standards for human consumption. 
    WATER, NON-POTABLE. Water, which is not safe for human consumption. 
    WATER, SERVICE CONNECTION. The terminal end of the service line from the public potable water system at its point of delivery to the user's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection shall mean the downstream end of the meter. Unprotected takeoffs from the service line will not be permitted upstream of any meter or any backflow prevention device located at the point of delivery to the user's water system. SERVICE CONNECTION shall also include water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the public potable water system. 
§ 10-7-3 - APPROVAL. 
(A)  Each backflow preventive assembly required hereunder shall be approved by the Department prior to installation and shall be installed by and at the expense of the user. 
(B)  The Department may approve backflow assemblies when the devices have received approval from the Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research of the University of Southern California, American Water Works Association (A.W.W.A.), and the manufacturer has a parts and service center located within Arizona, Nevada or California 
§ 10-7-4 - INSTALLATION OF DEVICES. 
(A)  Assemblies shall be installed at the service connection or near the property line, but in all cases before the first branch line leading off of the service line and in an accessible location approved by the Department. All assemblies shall be shown and specified on all required building and engineering plans, and approval shall be obtained prior to issuance of building or engineering permits. All assemblies shall be installed according to standard detail. 
(B)  Backflow preventive assemblies shall have at least the same cross-sectional area as the water service or meter. In those instances where a continuous water supply is necessary, or if the water supply cannot be temporarily interrupted for testing of assemblies, then two sets of backflow preventive assemblies shall be installed in parallel. 
(C)  No bypass shall be installed around backflow preventive assemblies. 
(D)  Double check valve assemblies may be installed below ground in a vault if approved, in writing, on a case-by-case basis, by the Department. Double check valve assemblies installed in vaults shall have sufficient clearance provided to permit testing in place or removal for maintenance, as prescribed in the standard details. Copies are available upon request from the Department. 
(E)  A reduced pressure principle backflow preventive assembly shall be installed above ground. Assemblies installed shall be accessible for testing as not to endanger the tester. Under no conditions except as provided for herein will backflow prevention assemblies be installed less than 12 inches or more than 24 inches above grade level. 
(F)  All pressure type backflow preventive assemblies which are designed for periodic field testing shall be equipped with gate valves on both the upstream and the downstream side of the assembly. In addition, test cocks shall be provided and located so that test equipment may be connected to the assembly at points that the pressure in each pressure zone may be detected, and, in addition, a test cock shall be located upstream of the upstream gate valve, as close as possible to the upstream gate valve. 
(G)  Backflow assemblies shall be protected from freezing by a method acceptable to the Department. 
§ 10-7-5 - PREMISES OR SYSTEMS REQUIRING APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTIVE DEVICES. 
(A)  An approved backflow preventive assembly of the type specified in this section shall be the minimum installation of each service connection, (whether from a fire hydrant, temporary, regular or other water service connection) to the following type of premises or systems:

§ 10-7-6 - APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTIVE DEVICES. 
(A)  As designated in § 10-7-3, the standard installation at each service connection to premises or each system requiring an approved backflow preventive assembly shall be a model and size approved by the Department. 
(B)  The term APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTIVE ASSEMBLY means an assembly approved by the Department and may mean an assembly that has been manufactured in full conformance with the standards established by the American Water Works Association - A.W.W.A. C506-78 most recent revised publication Standards for Reduced Pressure Principle and Double Check Valve Backflow Prevention Assemblies , and has met completely the laboratory and field performance specifications of the Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (FCCCHR) of the University of Southern California established by specifications of backflow prevention assemblies - Section 10 of the most current issue of the Manual of Cross-Connection Control , which will be available for inspection. 
(C)  Backflow preventive assemblies which may be subject to backpressure or backsiphonage that have been fully tested and have been granted a certificate of approval by FCCCHR may be listed on the current list of Approved Backflow Prevention Assemblies , which will be made available upon written request to the Department. 
§ 10-7-7 - MAINTENANCE, TESTING AND RECORDS. 
(A)  The user shall maintain accurate records of tests and repairs made to backflow prevention assemblies and provide the Department with copies of the records. The records shall be on forms approved by the Department and shall include the list of materials or replacement parts used. 
(B)  The user shall notify the Department 15 days in advance when the annual tests are to be done, so that an official representative may witness the tests if so desired by the Department. 
(C)  Following the installation or any repair, repiping, overhaul or relocation of an assembly, the user shall have it inspected by the Department, tested and provide the Department with results of the test, before the certificate of occupancy is issued. 
(D)  Testing, maintenance and repairs to the assemblies shall be made at the customers expense by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester who is approved by the Department and assisted by public works to prescribe test methods or to certify or approve persons to conduct tests. It shall be the duty of the user to see that these tests are made at least once a year, on the anniversary date of the initial inspection. 
§ 10-7-8 - INSPECTIONS. 
    The user's system must be open for inspection, at all reasonable times and in all emergencies, to authorized representatives of the Department to determine whether cross-connections or other structural or sanitary hazards, including violations of these regulations, exist. When a condition becomes known, the Department may deny or immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing a physical break in the service line until the user has corrected the condition in conformance with this article. 
§ 10-7-9 - DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE. 
    Service of water to any premises may be discontinued by the Department if a backflow preventive assembly required by this article is not installed, tested and maintained; if it has been found that a backflow preventive assembly has been removed or bypassed or if a cross-connection exists on the premises. Service will not be restored until the conditions or defects are corrected. The city may also terminate a user's service upon 20 days notice, in writing, in a non-emergency. 
§ 10-7-10 - EXISTING DEVICES AND USERS. 
(A)  If the Department determines that a user's backflow preventive assembly does not meet current standards, the user shall retrofit his or her assembly so that it will meet current standards. 
(B)  Users with water service prior to the effective date of this article may be subject to all requirements imposed by this article as determined by the Department. 
§ 10-7-11 - DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY. 
    This article shall not create any liability or duty on the part of the city or any of its officers or employees.

CHAPTER 11: - WASTEWATER 
ARTICLE 11-1: - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

§ 11-1-1 - PURPOSE. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a safe, clean and healthy environment, at the same time providing for the maximum possible beneficial use of the city's facilities through: 
(A)  The adequate regulation of sewer construction; 
(B)  Sewer use and industrial wastewater discharges; 
(C)  Procedures to prevent the introduction of pollutants that would interfere with the treatment plant operations and be incompatible with the environment; 
(D)  Improving the feasibility of recycling and reclamation of municipal wastewater and publicly-owned treatment works residue; and 
(E)  Enforcing all applicable laws relating to discharges, as required by the state, county and federal regulatory agencies. 
§ 11-1-2 - SCOPE. 
(A)  The provisions of this chapter apply to the direct or indirect discharges of all water-borne wastes to facilities of the city. 
(B)  This chapter provides for, but is not limited to: 
(1)  The regulation of sewer construction in areas within the city; 
(2)  The quantity and quality of discharged wastes; 
(3)  The degree of waste pre-treatment required; 
(4)  The setting of waste discharge fees to provide for equitable distribution of costs; 
(5)  The approval of plans for sewer construction; 
(6)  The issuance of permits for industrial wastewater discharge and other miscellaneous permits; and 
(7)  The establishment of penalties for violation of this chapter. 
(C)  The city reserves the right to establish and require implementation of Best Management Practices. 
§ 11-1-3 - WASTE TREATMENT POLICY. 
    The policy of the wastewater treatment plant is to obtain the highest and best use of the city's sewage system in the conveyance, treatment and disposal of domestic and industrial sewage. The use of the city's sewage system for industrial wastewater discharges is subject to further regulation by the city. The city is committed to a policy of wastewater reclamation and re-use in order to provide an alternate source of water supply; to reduce overall costs of wastewater treatment; and to protect public health and environment. These concerns may require more stringent quality requirements on industrial wastewater dischargers than required by other government regulatory agencies. To comply with the regulations and requirements of the federal government, state and county and to permit the city to meet increasingly higher standards of treatment plant effluent and POTW residual quality, provisions are made in the chapter for the regulation of industrial waste discharges. This chapter establishes quantity and quality limitations on industrial wastewater discharges which may adversely affect the city's sewage system, treatment process or effluent quality of the POTW. Methods of cost recovery from industrial wastewater discharges are also established where the discharges may impose disproportional collection, treatment or disposal costs to the city. 
§ 11-1-4 - DEFINITIONS. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    ACT. The term ACT means Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
    APPROVED TESTING METHODS. The measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of water and wastes in accordance with analytical procedures as established in 40 C.F.R. part 136, as revised October 26, 1984. 
    AZPDES PERMIT. The Arizona Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit, issued to the city by ADEQ which imposes federal standards. 
    BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES or BMPs . Schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to implement the prohibitions listed in § 403.5(a)(1) and (b). BMPs also include treatment requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control plant site run off, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. (40 CFR § 403.3 (e)). The city reserves the right to establish and require implementations of Best Management Practices. 
    B.O.D. Denoting BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND . The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20°C expressed in milligrams per liter, mg/l by weight. 
    BRANCH SEWER. A sewer that collects sewage from one or more lateral sewers. 
    BUILDING DRAIN. The drain pipes and their hardware within a building and extending five feet beyond the foundation. 
    BUILDING SEWER. Sometimes referred to as the building or house service, is the private service line that extends from the building drain to the point of connection to the city's main line, including the apparatus used to make the connection to the city's main line. 
    CATEGORICAL PRE-TREATMENT STANDARD. The Federal Categorical Pre-Treatment Standards issued in accordance with § 307 of the Clean Water Act, as amended in 1977. 
    C.F.R. The Code of Federal Regulations. 
    CLEAN WATER ACT. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
    COMBINED SEWER. A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    CONTROL MANHOLE. A special manhole positioned as an integral part of the building sewer on an industrial site to facilitate the sampling of wastes from the facility. 
    DEPARTMENT. The Utilities Department. 
    DEVELOPER. Any person engaged in organizing and financing of a sewage collecting system within an area tributary to a trunk sewer of the city sewer system. Such may be either a subdivider or a legally constituted improvement district. 
    DIRECTOR. The Utilities Director or the Utilities Director's authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    DISCHARGE. Water-borne pollutants released to a receiving stream directly or indirectly or to a sewerage system. 
(40 C.F.R. § 240.101(e)) 
    EFFLUENT. Wastewater, treated or untreated, that flows out of a treatment plant, sewer or industrial outfall. Generally refers to wastes discharged into surface waters. 
(EPA 3/88 Glossary of Environmental Terms EPA 87-017) 
    ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY. Also designated as EPA. The federal governmental agency charged with the protection of the environment. 
    GARBAGE. Solid waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    INFLOW MEASUREMENT. The volume of water that passes through a given cross-section of a channel during a unit of time. This flow, measured in cubic feet per second, is the amount of water fed to the stream from surface and groundwater run-off. Discharge varies according to velocity of flow, which in turn depends upon gradient (down stream slope, usually expressed in feet per mile), volume of water, load of rock particles being carried, shape of channel and cross-section area of the channel (DOI 4/70). 
    INDIRECT DISCHARGE. The introduction of pollutants into the wastewater treatment plant from any non-domestic source regulated under the Clean Water Act, § 307(b), (c) or (d). 
    INDUSTRIAL COST RECOVERY. The charges collected from industrial users of a publicly-owned treatment works to repay the proportionate federal and local share of the construction costs of the treatment works allocated to their use. 
    INDUSTRIAL DISCHARGE. Any introduction into the POTW of a non-domestic pollutant which is produced by a source which would be subject to any categorical standards or pretreatment requirements if the source were to be discharged to the POTW, or contains any substance or pollutant for which a discharge limitation or prohibition has been established by any categorical standard or pretreatment requirement. 
    INDUSTRIAL USER. Any non-domestic user of the sewer system which either discharges or produces a waste which is or potentially could be discharged into the wastewater treatment plant which would be subject to any categorical standard, pre-treatment standard or local limit. 
    INDUSTRIAL USER DISCHARGE PERMIT. The permit granted by the city which each industrial user must first obtain prior to causing or allowing any industrial discharge to the sewer system. 
    INDUSTRIAL WASTES. Any liquid, free flowing waste, including cooling water, resulting from any industrial or manufacturing process or from the development, recovery or processing of natural resources with or without suspended solids excluding uncontaminated water. 
    INTERCEPTOR SEWER. A sewer that receives flow from a number of other large sewers or outlets and conveys the sewage to a point for treatment or disposal. 
    INTERFERENCE. A discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge from other sources, both inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal and therefore is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's AZPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent state or local regulations): § 405 of the Clean Water Act, the Solid Waste Disposal ACT (SWDA) (including Title 11, more commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), and including state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA), the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act, 40 C.F.R. § 403.3(i). 
    INSPECTOR. A person authorized by the wastewater treatment plant Director to inspect wastewater generation, conveyance, processing and disposal facilities. 
    LATERAL SEWER. A sewer which discharges into a branch or other sewer and has no other common sewer tributary to it. Sometimes referred to as a STREET SEWER because it collects sewage from individual homes and business. 
    LOCAL LIMITS. Enforceable local requirements developed by POTW's to address federal standards as well as state and local regulations. These limits apply to any and all entities that contribute flow to a POTW. 
(EPA Manual Pre-treatment Program Local Limits Guidance, March 22,1988) 
    MAIN SEWER. For the purposes of these regulations, MAIN SEWER (sometime called the MAIN LINE ) refers to the public sewer line whereby private sewer connections are made and may include laterals (street laterals), branch sewers, main lines and interceptors. MAIN SEWER does not refer to any portion of the consumers' private sewer (building drain, building sewer and the connection to the public sewer or any portion thereof). 
    NATIONAL PRE-TREATMENT STANDARD. Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with § 307(b) and (c) of the Act, which applies to industrial users. This term includes prohibitive discharge limits established pursuant to 40 C.F.R. § 403.5. 
    NATURAL OUTLET. Any outlet into a watercourse, ditch or other body of surface or ground water. 
    NEW SOURCE. Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pre-treatment standards under § 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to the source if the standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that the building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which another source is located; or the building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or the production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent factors, the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
(40 C.F.R. § 403.3(k)(1)) 
    PASS THROUGH. Any discharge that introduces pollutants in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's AZPDES permit. 
    PERSON. Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, state, municipality, Indian tribe, political subdivision of the state or federal governmental agency or any other legal entity, including their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    pH. A measure of the acidity (0, most acid) or alkalinity (14, most alkaline) of a liquid or solid on a scale of 0-14; pH of a neutral solution is 7.0. 
    POINT OF TIE-IN. The location of the consumer's (property owners') privately owned service connection on the city main sewer. 
    POINT OF TRANSITION. The point at which sanitary sewer ownership and responsibility changes from private to public or vise versa. 
    POLLUTANT. Dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal and agricultural waste discharged into water. It does not mean sewage from vessels or water, gas or other material which is injected into a well to facilitate production of oil or gas, or water derived in association with oil or gas production and disposed of in a well, if the well, used either to facilitate production or for disposal purposes, is approved by authority of the state in which the well is located and, if the state determines that the injection or disposal will not result in degradation of ground or surface water resources. 
(40 C.F.R. § 401.11(f)) 
    POTW RESIDUALS. All effluent or solids including sludge, scum, screenings and grit which are the by-product of wastewater treatment operations and which must be discharged into the environment for ultimate disposal or re-use. 
    PRE-TREATMENT. A process used to reduce, eliminate or alter the nature of wastewater pollutants from non-domestic sources before they are discharged into publicly-owned treatment works. 
(EPA, 3/88, "Glossary of Environmental Terms," Office of Public Affairs (A-107), Washington, DC 20460, EPA 87-017, March 1988. 
    PRE-TREATMENT REQUIREMENTS. All of the duties imposed upon POTW users by the Director. 
    PRIVATE SEWER. Are sanitary sewer lines and apparatus (building drain, building sewer and sewer tap) which is owned by the consumer (property owner) and which originates on the consumers property and which may extend out into the public right-of-way or public utility easement, whichever the case may be, and terminates at the sewer connection, and includes the connection. 
    PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE. Garbage that has been shredded to a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    PUBLIC SEWER. Are sanitary sewer lines that are owned and or operated by the City of Tolleson or other entities and which are not otherwise considered by the Department as being private. 
    PUBLICLY-OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTW). Any device or system used in the treatment (including recycling and reclamation) of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature which is owned by a state or municipality (as defined by § 502(4) of the Clean Water Act of 1977). This definition includes sewers, pipes or other conveyances only if they convey wastewater to a POTW providing treatment. 
(40 C.F.R. § 260.10) 
    SANITARY SEWAGE. Any and all waste substances, liquids or solids, but excluding storm, surface, ground waters and industrial wastes. 
    SANITARY SEWER. A sewer which carries liquid and water borne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally to a municipal treatment plant. 
(EPA 11/82) 
    SEWAGE. The waste and wastewater produced by residential, commercial and industrial establishments and discharged into the sewers. 
    SEWAGE SYSTEM. A network of wastewater collection, conveyance, treatment and disposal facilities interconnected by sewers and owned by the city. 
    SEWER CONNECTION. The apparatus (e.g. including but not limited to saddle and associate hardware) used by the consumer to make a tie-in to the city's public sewer system on the city operated main sewer. Commonly referred to as the TAP. 
    SIGNIFICANT INDUSTRIAL USER. All industrial users subject to categorical pre-treatment standards under 40 C.F.R. § 403.6 and 40 C.F.R. Chapter I, Subchapter N; and any other industrial user that discharges an average of 25,000 gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater); contributes a process waste stream which makes up 5% or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant or is designated as such by the control authority as defined in 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(a) on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pre-treatment standard or requirement (in accordance with 40 C.F.R. § 403.8(f)(6). 
    SIGNIFICANT NON-COMPLIANCE. Any violation of pre-treatment requirements (limits, sampling, analysis, reporting and meeting compliance schedules and regulatory deadlines). 
    SLUG LOAD. Any pollutant discharged to the sewer system in the volume or strength as to cause interference. In particular, any pollutant concentration, quantity or flow rate which during any period of 15 minutes or more is greater than five times the average 24 hour concentration, quantity or flow rate of the pollutant during normal operation. 
    STANDARD INDUSTRIAL CLASSIFICATION CODE (S.I.C.). A coded classification of industries based upon economic activity developed by the U.S. Department of Commerce, as published in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual , 1982, Office of Management and Budget. 
    STORM SEWER or STORM DRAIN. A sewer which carries storm and surface waters drainage and groundwater, but excludes sanitary sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
    SURFACTANT. Surface active chemicals which tend to lower the surface tension between liquids, such as between acid and water (EPA 3/83a); surface active agents used in detergents to cause lathering (EPA 3/88). 
    SUSPENDED SOLIDS. Solids measured in milligrams per liter that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids and which are largely removable by a laboratory filtration device or other conventional means. 
    TERMINAL MANHOLE. A manhole that is placed for the purpose of extending the public sanitary sewer (city owned main line) beyond the right-of-way to more effectively serve the community. 
    TRUNK SEWER. A sewer that transports wastewater from collecting sewers to the treatment plant. A TRUNK SEWER does not ordinarily service individual properties but rather receives tributary branches and serves a larger territory. 
    USER CHARGE. Fees collected for the treatment of wastewater resulting in proportionate distribution or operation, maintenance and replacement cost. 
    WASTEWATER DEPARTMENT. Those officers and agents of the city supervising sewer operations for the city. 
    WATERCOURSE. A channel in which a flow of water occurs continuously or intermittently. 
§ 11-1-5 - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS; WASTE DISCHARGE REQUIREMENTS. 
    Except as provided herein, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described water or wastes to any public sewer: 
(A)  Any storm, surface water, ground water, roof run-off, sub-surface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water to any sanitary sewer; 
(B)  Any discharge containing temperatures in amounts which will inhibit biological activity resulting in interference, or allowing the influent at the wastewater treatment plant to exceed 104°F; 
(C)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(D)  Any garbage that has not been property shredded; 
(E)  Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastic, wood, grits, such as brick, cement, carbides or any other solid or viscous substances capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works; 
(F)  Any waters or wastes containing a toxic, poisonous or corrosive substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant; 
(G)  Any waters or wastes containing any pollutant released at a flow rate or pollutant concentration that will cause interference with the wastewater treatment plant; 
(H)  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance; 
(I)  Any waste which may contain fats, oils or grease in quantities so as to require special handling; 
(J)  Any surface active chemical which would tend to lower the surface tension between liquids, such as between acid and water; any surface active agents used in detergents to cause lathering; 
(K)  Any waters or wastes that cause a pass through resulting in the wastewater treatment plant violating any requirements, including petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil products or mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass through; 
(40 C.F.R. § 403.5(b)(6)) 
(L)  Any waste having a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0 or having any corrosive or detrimental characteristics that may cause injury to wastewater treatment or maintenance personnel or may cause damage to the structure, equipment or other physical facilities of the sewage system; 
(M)  Any water added for the purpose of diluting a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with a pre-treatment standard or local limit established by the city; 
(N)  Any waste containing over 0.1 milligrams/liter of dissolved sulfides; 
(O)  Any waste requiring an excessive quantity of chlorine or other chemical compound used for disinfection purposes which would result in an excess of five-one hundredths residual; 
(P)  Any waste producing excessive discoloration of wastewater or treatment plant effluent; 
(Q)  Any wastewater containing the EPA limits included in this chapter, except as superseded by local limits; 
(R)  Any quantities of radioactive material wastes; 
(S)  It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited upon public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human excrement, garbage or other waste; 
(T)  It is unlawful to discharge to any stream or watercourse in the city any sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with provisions of this chapter; 
(U)  No run-off from roofs and no surface drains for rainwater shall be connected to any sanitary sewer. No surface or storm water, seepage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters shall be permitted to enter any sanitary sewer by any devices or method whatsoever; 
(V)  Discharge of a substance which creates a fire or explosive hazard in the treatment works is prohibited. The recent revisions to the general pre-treatment regulations further clarify this prohibition by specifying that discharges with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than 140°F or 60°C, using the Pensky-Martens Standard D-93-79 or D-93-80 are prohibited; and/or 
(W)  It is unlawful for any hauled wastes, including industrial wastes, to be discharged into the city's sewer system from any area being served either directly or indirectly by the city. 
(X)  Any waste containing over 250 mg/l by weight of BOD (five day) and 250 mg/l by weight suspended solids content. 
§ 11-1-6 - LIABILITY OF USER. 
    Any residential, commercial or industrial user who unlawfully discharges, or causes the discharge of industrial wastewater which causes damage to the wastewater treatment plant, interference, pass through, upset or any other damages resulting in costs to the wastewater treatment, shall be liable to the city for all damages occasioned thereby. This chapter is not intended to create, nor does it create, any private right of action in any person. When requested, a user must submit information on the nature and characteristics of its wastewater within the time period specified in the request. A commercial or industrial user must submit information on the nature and characteristics of its wastewater within five days. 
(40 CFR § 403.16(3)) 
ARTICLE 11-2: - APPLICATIONS, PERMITS, PLANS AND INSPECTIONS 

§ 11-2-1 - APPLICATION FOR SERVICE. 
    No sewer connection to the city sanitary sewer system shall be made or used by any person, except upon written application furnished to the city by the owner, or his or her authorized agent, of the premises to which sanitary sewer service is to be furnished. A permit from the city is required prior to any connection. 
§ 11-2-2 - WASTEWATER DISCHARGE PERMIT. 
(A)  Except as provided in § 11-4-5, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any industrial wastewater directly or indirectly to sewage facilities owned by the city without first obtaining a city permit for industrial wastewater discharge. The duration of an industrial wastewater discharge permit shall not exceed 12 months. 
(B)  The permit for industrial wastewater discharge may require: 
(1)  Pre-treatment of industrial wastewater before discharge; 
(2)  Restriction of discharge to certain hours of the day; 
(3)  Payment of additional charges to defray increased costs to the city created by the wastewater discharge which shall be collected through the use of industrial cost recovery and user charges, as defined herein; and 
(4)  Other conditions as may be required to effectuate the purpose of this chapter. 
(C)  No person shall discharge industrial wastewater in excess of the quantity or quality limitations set by the permit for the industrial user discharge permit. Any person desiring to discharge wastewater or use facilities which are not in conformance with the industrial user discharge permit shall apply to the city for an amended permit. The city reserves the right to develop and implement certain local limits through the permitting process. No user shall in any way attempt to dilute a discharge as a substitute to achieve an applicable pretreatment standard unless expressly authorized. 
(D)  An industrial user may claim information submitted as confidential by stamping the words "Confidential Business Information" on each page containing the information and demonstrating to the Director's satisfaction that trade secrets and confidential business information would be endangered by making the information public. Data on industrial effluent quality may not be given confidential treatment. 
(E)  The city may, in addition, require that the discharge of certain wastewater be limited to specific sewers within the city, and peak flows or discharges may require restriction or regulation. The industrial user discharge permit may also prohibit certain wastewater components. Due to the differences of various business and industrial users, a list of examples of prohibited components is not feasible. 
§ 11-2-3 - CONSTRUCTION PLANS. 
(A)  No person other than employees of the city or persons contracting to do work for the city shall construct or cause to be constructed, or alter or cause to be altered, any public sewer, lateral sewer, house connection or industrial connection sewer, sewage pumping plant, pollution control plant or other sewage works within the city where existing or proposed wastewater flows will discharge directly or indirectly to facilities of the city without first obtaining approval of sewage construction plans from the Director. 
(B)  The contractor shall submit for approval by the city and the Engineering Divisions of the county environmental services division and the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality detailed construction plans and the specifications and other details as required to describe fully the proposed sewage facility. The plans shall have been prepared under the supervision of and shall be signed by an engineer of suitable training who is registered in the State of Arizona. 
(C)  Construction plans and specifications for sewage facilities shall conform to the Maricopa Association of Governments Uniform Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction , as adopted by the Council as well as those of other regulatory agencies, i.e. county, state and federal and the Department. 
(D)  An approval of plans for sewage construction shall expire one year after date of approval unless construction has been initiated. 
§ 11-2-4 - NON-TRANSFER OF PERMITS AND APPROVAL. 
    Approval of plans for sewage construction, trunk sewer connection permits and industrial user discharge permits are not transferable from one person to another person or from one location to another location. 
§ 11-2-5 - INSPECTIONS. 
(A)  Inspections. Inspections of each facility that is involved either directly or indirectly with the discharge of wastewater to the city's sewage system shall be made by the Director or his or her designee as deemed necessary. 
(1)  These facilities shall include, but not be limited to, sewers, sewage pumping plants, pollution control plants, all industrial processes, industrial wastewater generation, conveyance and pre-treatment facilities, devices and connecting sewers and all similar sewage facilities. Inspections shall be made to determine that the facilities are maintained and operated properly and are adequate to meet the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Access to all of the above facilities or to other facilities directly or indirectly connected to the city's sewage system shall be given to authorized personnel of the city at all reasonable times, including those occasioned by emergency conditions. Any permanent or temporary obstruction to easy access to the sewage facility to be inspected shall be promptly removed by the facility user or owner at the written or verbal request of the Director or his or her designee and shall not be replaced. 
(3)  No person shall interfere with, delay, resist or refuse entrance to an authorized city inspector attempting to inspect any wastewater generation, conveyance or treatment facility connected directly or indirectly to the city's sewage system. 
(B)  Plans and specifications. It shall be the joint responsibility of the contractor and the industrial user to file with the Director or his or her designee one set of each phase of construction plans, i.e. preliminary design plans, amended plans, final as-built plans. 
(C)  Construction inspections. All sewers to be attached directly or indirectly to a city sewer shall be inspected by personnel of the city during construction. The city shall be notified at least 48 hours prior to cutting into the city's sewer. In making a connection to the city sewer, no physical alteration of the city's facilities shall commence until an inspector is present. No wastewater shall be discharged into any sewage facility tributary to the city facility prior to obtaining inspections and approval of sewage construction by the city. Following satisfactory completion of construction, the city will issue a construction inspection certificate upon request. 
§ 11-2-6 - AVAILABILITY OF RECORDS. 
    All records pertaining to an industrial user's monitoring activities shall be made available to the Director or the Director's designee for the purpose of examination and copying as set forth in 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(0) or as amended. These records shall be retained by the industrial user for a minimum of three years, as required by 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(2) or as amended. 
ARTICLE 11-3: - PRELIMINARY TREATMENT REQUIREMENTS 

§ 11-3-1 - INDUSTRIAL PRE-TREATMENT. 
(A)  Industrial users are required to meet all applicable local, state and federal discharge limits on any pollutant. This requirement applies to those standards promulgated by EPA after this chapter is actually adopted. The city will review the federal standards and amend this chapter as needed to ensure the enforceability of standards on local users. 
(B)  The federal or state standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed under this chapter, shall replace the limitations as set forth in this chapter. 
(C)  An industrial wastewater pre-treatment system or device shall be required by the Director to treat industrial flows prior to discharge to the sewer when: 
(1)  It is necessary to restrict or prevent the discharge to the sewer of certain waste constituents; 
(2)  To distribute more equally over a longer time period any peak discharges of industrial wastewater; or 
(3)  To accomplish any pre-treatment result required by the Director. 
(D)  All pre-treatment systems or devices shall be approved by the Director. All pre-treatment systems shall require an engineering design and have plans prepared and signed by an engineer of suitable discipline licensed in the State of Arizona. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes, containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients; except that the interceptor shall not be required for a building used for residential purposes. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city and shall be so located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at the owner's expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(E)  A device shall be provided for the purpose of neutralizing or reducing the amounts of phenols, metals or pesticides prior to their discharge into the city's sewer system so that the discharge meets set standards. 
(F)  In addition, the Director may also require the installation of a pH probe with recorder at a point prior to any industrial discharge entering the city's collection system. This device shall be properly installed and maintained by the industrial discharger at his or her expense. The admission into the public sanitary sewers of any waters or wastes having characteristics exceeding the following limits shall be subject to the review and approval of the city, and, where necessary, in the opinion of the city, the owner shall provide, at his or her own expense, the preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the objectionable characteristics to within the following allowable limits: 
(1)  Five day B.O.D. of 250 milligrams per liter by weight; 
(2)  Suspended solids content of 250 milligrams per liter by weight; 
(3)  Any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in this section; 
(4)  A pH range of 6.5 to 9.0 s.u.; 
(5)  An average daily flow of 2% of the average daily flow of the city. In addition to all other requirements, each industrial user who discharges an industrial discharge into the sewer system shall also: 
(a)  Obtain an industrial discharge permit from the Director. Any application for a permit or an amended permit shall contain the information stipulated in 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(b)(1) through (b)(7) and C.F.R. § 403.12(c)(1) through (c)(3) as amended. Any person intending to begin any new industrial discharge, modifications or any additional industrial discharge not already allowed pursuant to an existing permit, shall first obtain a new or amended industrial discharge permit, as applicable, from the Director prior to initiating the discharge; 
(b)  Comply fully with all requirements and conditions of this chapter and of any industrial user permit. Once a permit is issued no industrial user shall make any discharge in violation of this chapter or of the industrial user permit; 
(c)  Provide all the pre-treatment necessary to comply with the categorical standards and pre-treatment requirements required by this article; 
(d)  Maintain a continuous discharge record which clearly identifies the: 
1.  The dates and times of all industrial discharges; and 
2.  Chemical nature, concentration and volume of all discharges. 
(e)  Provide the Director with all the same self monitoring reports and notices which the industrial user is required to submit to the POTW or any other authority in accordance with provisions of 40 C.F.R. § 403.12. In particular, the industrial user shall meet the requirements of: 
1.  Baseline monitoring reports 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(b); 
2.  Compliance schedule progress reports 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(c); 
3.  Reports on compliance with categorical pre-treatment standard deadline 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(d); 
4.  Periodic reports on continued compliance 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(e); 
5.  Notice of potential problems, including slug loading 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(f); and 
6.  Notification of changed discharge 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(j). 
(G)  All reports and any other documents relating to indirect discharges shall be signed by an authorized representative of the industrial user as dictated by 40 C.F.R. § 403.12(1). 
(H)  All industrial users are required to develop a slug control plan which outlines discharge practices (including non-routine batch discharges), describes stored chemicals and contains procedures both to notify the POTW immediately of slug discharges and to prevent adverse impacts from any accidental spill. 
(I)  Industrial users are required to develop a compliance pre-treatment standard. This should be done in the shortest time feasible and within any deadline established by state or federal standards. All pre-treatment systems or devices shall be approved by the Director and by the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality. 
§ 11-3-2 - APPROVAL. 
    Plans and specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for approval by the city and to all appropriate regulatory agencies with jurisdiction. No construction of facilities shall begin until the approvals are obtained in writing. 
§ 11-3-3 - MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES. 
    Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the property owner at his or her own expense and subject to inspection by the Wastewater Department. 
§ 11-3-4 - MANHOLES. 
    When required by the Wastewater Department, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling of wastes, and it shall be installed in a manner as to prevent the discharge of any storm water, surface water, ground water, roof run off, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water. A manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Wastewater Department. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the owner's expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
§ 11-3-5 - TESTS AND ANALYSIS. 
(A)  All tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes shall be determined in accordance with the latest Approved Testing Methods , 40 C.F.R. part 136, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided for in § 11-3-4 or upon suitable samples taken at a control manhole. Periodic measurements of flow rates, flow columns, B.O.D. and suspended solids for use in determining the annual industrial wastewater treatment surcharge and the measurements of other constituents believed necessary by the Director shall be made by all industrial wastewater dischargers unless specifically relieved of the obligation by the Director. All sampling analysis and flow measurements of industrial wastewater shall be performed by an independent laboratory or by the laboratory of the industrial discharger approved by the Director and licensed by the Arizona Department of Health Services. Prior to submittal to the city of data developed in the contracted laboratory of an industrial discharger, the results shall be certified by a responsible administrative official of the industrial discharger under the penalty of perjury. 
(40 C.F.R. § 403.12(n)) 
(B)  Those industrial wastewater dischargers required to make periodic measurements of flow volumes and constituents shall make these determinations at a frequency and in a manner as determined by the Director. Measurements to certify the quantities of waste flows and waste constituents reported by industrial dischargers will be conducted on a random basis by personnel of the Wastewater Department. 
(C)  Industrial waste dischargers, prior to receiving a connection permit, shall provide the city with a chemical, mineral and bacteriological breakdown of the proposed waste discharge. 
§ 11-3-6 - PRE-TREATMENT PROGRAM ENFORCEMENT AND RESPONSE GUIDELINES. 
(A)  The goal of the pre-treatment program for the city is to obtain compliance with all applicable laws and regulations by those regulated dischargers into the publicly-owned treatment works or POTW. These enforcement response guidelines and penalties shall be interpreted in the interest of obtaining compliance with all applicable laws and regulations by dischargers into the POTW. 
(B)  ENFORCEMENT RESPONSE shall include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Contact by inspector; 
(2)  Notice of violation; 
(3)  Increased monitoring and testing; 
(4)  Administrative orders: modification of permits, fines, other appropriate orders; 
(5)  Order to show cause - formal meeting requiring the discharger to appear and answer either specific allegations or indicate why further enforcement should not occur; 
(6)  Publication of significant violators and imposition of fines; 
(7)  Civil action including injunctive relief; 
(8)  Termination of service; and 
(9)  Criminal investigation and action. 
(C)  In determining any enforcement response, the wastewater treatment plant Director shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  Previous compliance history, length of violation; 
(2)  Number of violations; 
(3)  Seriousness of effects to facilities; 
(4)  Potential effects of the violation to the public health; 
(5)  History of the violation; and 
(6)  Any other relevant factors as part of determining what enforcement action is to be taken including the above-stated goal to obtain compliance. 
ARTICLE 11-4: - LIABILITY AND DAMAGES 

§ 11-4-1 - RESPONSIBILITIES AND LIABILITIES. 
(A)  The city shall not be responsible for the installation, maintenance or inspection of the consumer's service line piping or apparatus or for any defects therein. 
(B)  The city shall have the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or piping are installed in a manner as to prevent cross connection or backflow. 
(C)  Under normal conditions, the consumer shall be notified of any anticipated interruption of service. 
(D)  The city shall not be responsible for the negligence of third persons or forces beyond the control of the Wastewater Department resulting in any interruption of service or damage to the property of the consumer. 
(E)  The city may refuse service to any prospective consumer when the capacity of the sewer system will not permit additional loads being placed thereon. 
§ 11-4-2 - CONSUMER RESPONSIBILITY. 
(A)  Building or house sewer connections on the consumer's premises shall be so arranged as to provide service to one lot. If additional service is required, it will be considered as a separate and individual account. 
(B)  The consumer's house or building service line, sewer connection and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer, at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner and in accordance with the city rules and regulations and in full compliance with the regulations of the county's and state's Departments of Health. 
(C)  The consumer shall safeguard the city's property placed on the consumer's premises and shall permit access to it only by the authorized representatives of the Sewer Department. 
(D)  In the event that any loss or damage to the property of the city or any accident or injury to persons or property is caused by or results from the negligence or wrongful act of the consumer, his or her agents or employees, the cost of necessary repairs or replacements shall be paid by the consumer to the city and any liability otherwise resulting shall be assumed by the consumer. The amount of the loss or damage or the cost of repairs may be added to the consumer's bill and, if not paid, service may be discontinued by the Sewer Department. 
(E)  The city may discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: 
(1)  To prevent fraud or abuse; and 
(2)  The consumer's willful disregard of or refusal to comply with this chapter or other rules as may be adopted by the Council. 
(F)  The city may discontinue service when, in the opinion of the city, an actual or threatened discharge presents an imminent or substantial danger to the health and welfare of the people, to the environment or the process of its wastewater treatment plant or to its violating of any condition of its AZPDES permit. If, after notification to discontinue discharge, any person fails to do so voluntarily, the city will physically sever the sewer connection to prevent or minimize the damage to the treatment plant. 
(G)  When service to a consumer shall require the laying of any city sewer lines or the installation of any other city property on, under, across or over the consumer's property, the consumer will grant to the city an easement, right-of-way or license for the installation. 
(H)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the consumer shall be responsible for all sewer lines and repairs thereto up to the point of tie-in with the city owned main line. 
§ 11-4-3 - PRIVATE SEWAGE SYSTEMS. 
(A)  Except as provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or maintain within the city any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
